This paper presents MLE+, a tool that leverages EnergyPlus and Matlab to facilitate the integrated design, co-simulation, and analysis of energy-efficient building automation and control systems.

This study explores the use of LSTM and RNN machine learning models to forecast groundwater table response to storm events in the coastal city of Norfolk, Virginia, finding that LSTM networks trained on storm-only data perform best in real-time forecasting scenarios.

This study explores the potential of a Random Forest machine learning method to serve as a computationally efficient surrogate for physics-based models in predicting real-time, street-scale urban pluvial flooding in coastal cities.

This paper presents F1/10, an open-source, affordable, and high-performance 1/10 scale autonomous vehicle testbed designed to augment research and education in autonomous systems and make the field more accessible.

This work presents a derivative-free approach to trajectory synthesis for autonomous racing overtakes, framing the problem as one of Bayesian Inference over Composite Bezier Curves which successfully outperforms existing methods in closed-loop analysis.

This paper introduces the Gauss-Legendre Rectangle (GLR) algorithm, a principled two-stage integration method that accurately estimates collision risk for autonomous racing overtakes by accounting for vehicle geometry and trajectory uncertainty, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines.

This paper presents a comprehensive overview of the HALO safety architecture for a full-scale autonomous racing vehicle, including a failure mode analysis and runtime monitoring methods to mitigate risks from various software and hardware faults.

This paper introduces the Trajectory-to-Action Pipeline (TAP), a scalable and automated method for extracting Scenario Description Language labels from large trajectory datasets to support AV safety analysis and edge case detection.

This special issue contains a selection of original papers extending earlier results from the 15th ACM/IEEE International Conference on Cyber-Physical Systems (ICCPS), covering various aspects of CPS research with both methodological rigor and practical impact.

This paper introduces and demonstrates hyperspectral tomography, a novel laser diagnostic technique capable of simultaneous 2D imaging of temperature and water-vapor concentration at up to 50 kHz in a practical aero-propulsion engine.

This work presents a combined numerical and experimental study on the air-cooling of a lithium-ion battery pack, developing and validating a 2D CFD model that accurately captures the cooling dynamics under various practical flow conditions.

This paper reports the development and demonstration of a novel tomography technique based on hyperspectral absorption spectroscopy that enables simultaneous imaging of temperature and species concentration with a reduced number of projections.

This work studies the thermal management of a multi-cell Li-ion battery module both experimentally in a wind tunnel and computationally with a high-fidelity 2D CFD model, obtaining reasonable agreement between simulations and measurements.

This work discusses a 3D diagnostic based on tomographic chemiluminescence, developing a hybrid reconstruction algorithm and an experimental approach to quantify its accuracy and spatial resolution for resolving 3D flame structures.

This work investigated and demonstrated a method using a guiding laser to correct for beam steering effects, significantly enhancing the accuracy of particle image velocimetry measurements in turbulent reactive flames.

This work describes the design and implementation of a customized fiber-based endoscope setup to overcome limited optical access and enable four-dimensional flame measurements within a ground vehicle testbed to study fire dynamics.

This work extended the reconstruction integrating view registration (RIVR) method to 3D measurements of highly turbulent reactive flows, demonstrating that it effectively enhances the reconstruction accuracy of thin flame fronts and key flame properties.

This paper reports the development and validation of a two-dimensional two-states model for real-time analysis of thermal behaviors in large-scale Li-ion battery packs, filling a niche between computationally expensive detailed models and 1D lumped models.

To reduce uncertainties in 3D3C velocity measurements, this work developed a regularized tomographic particle image velocimetry method that significantly enhances accuracy by incorporating the conservation of mass into the reconstruction process.

This paper presents DeepCache, a principled cache design for deep learning inference in continuous mobile vision that exploits temporal locality in video streams to improve model execution efficiency without requiring model modification.

This paper presents the first empirical study on 16,500 popular Android apps, using a new static tool to demystify how they exploit deep learning, what they use it for, and what their models look like.

Leveraging a large web usage dataset, this paper examines client-only solutions for improving mobile browser speed, finding that a new approach called speculative loading can significantly improve performance where caching and prefetching are limited.

This paper presents an empirical analysis of app usage behaviors from millions of users of a leading Android marketplace in China, revealing interesting patterns in app management activities and network traffic generation.

By examining the internals of web browsers on smartphones, this work finds that over half of visited webpages are not mobile-optimized and that resource loading, not compute-intensive operations, contributes most to browser delay.
This paper introduces Proto, a new instructional OS that runs on commodity hardware and uses an incremental, app-driven approach to teach modern OS features through engaging, media-rich applications.

This paper investigates Apple Silicon's unified memory architecture for on-device LLM inference, finding through extensive benchmarks that its large unified memory makes it both cost-effective and efficient against NVIDIA GPUs for ultra-large models.

This paper presents WhisperFlow, a novel framework that uses both model and system optimizations to enable efficient processing of streaming speech on resource-constrained client devices using large speech foundation models like Whisper.

This paper describes VOS, a first-of-its-kind instructional OS that runs on commodity hardware and uses an "inverse engineering" method to teach modern OS features through the progressive enabling of engaging, media-rich apps.
This paper proposes AnA, a system that refactors autonomous driving systems to guide perception with driving knowledge, reducing collisions by 2x and compute usage by 44% on challenging benchmarks.

This exploratory study investigates the complex correlations between sense of belonging, belonging uncertainty, and other factors like engineering identity and use of support resources among first-year engineering students.

This study explores the effectiveness of two distinct project-based learning approaches—Student-Identified and Industry-Provided—in an introductory Building Information Modeling course, finding that both were effective but a hybrid model may be optimal.

This study evaluates the effectiveness of educational interventions, contextualized around future construction industry careers, in enhancing the awareness and interest of middle school students from an underrepresented community in developing digital skills.

This study explores whether priming universalism values in construction project owners can increase the perceived importance of including underrepresented firms when selecting a general contractor, testing the hypothesis on a sample of engineering and architecture students.

This paper synthesizes lessons learned from developing and teaching a Case-Based Learning course in Construction Engineering and Management with industry partners, identifying factors that foster student learning and highlighting the benefits of practitioner interaction.

This study measured velocity and turbulence across a fringing coral reef, finding that drag coefficients over coral were three to five times greater than over a sandy bottom, with a local balance between turbulent kinetic energy production and dissipation.

This study quantifies how an eelgrass bed alters its hydrodynamic environment, finding that it reduces near-bottom mean velocities by 70-90% and wave heights by 45-70% compared to an adjacent unvegetated region.

By quantifying the pumping activity and respiration of the glass sponge Aphrocallistes vastus, this study reveals that the energetic cost of pumping is much higher than previously estimated, suggesting that current-induced passive flow is highly beneficial.

This study collected velocity and turbulence data over various intertidal surfaces to determine how benthic flow affects oyster larval recruitment, finding that the natural oyster reef had significantly higher hydrodynamic roughness and turbulence compared to restoration sites.

This study demonstrates that restored intertidal oyster reefs can effectively attenuate wave energy in shallow coastal bays, reducing wave heights by an average of 30-50% under various tidal and wind conditions.

This review identifies and synthesizes long-term monitoring data from a selection of natural and nature-based features projects to provide a literature-based performance evaluation and better inform their design criteria for coastal protection.

By making side-by-side turbulence and soundscape measurements over oyster reefs, this study found a significant relationship between flow noise and turbulent kinetic energy, suggesting that reef turbulence and sounds may attract oyster larvae in complementary ways.

By comparing field observations with different prediction models, this study shows that accounting for canopy flow modifications and seagrass flexibility is crucial for accurately predicting wave dissipation in dense seagrass meadows.

This research applies a GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis to Norfolk, VA, to understand the impacts of urban stormwater flooding on disabled populations and help target resources for hazard mitigation and emergency response.

This paper reports a monolithically grown germanium/silicon avalanche photodetector with a record-high gain–bandwidth product of 340 GHz and a sensitivity of −28 dBm at 10 Gb/s, rivaling commercial III–V compound devices.

This paper reports on photodetectors fabricated on microstructured silicon that exhibit high responsivities of 92 A/W at 850 nm and 119 A/W at 960 nm, explained by a proposed generation-recombination gain mechanism.

Through concurrent photoluminescence and infrared spectroscopy studies, this work concludes that the SiH2 surface species is essential to the visible luminescence in porous Si, as its desorption coincides with a sharp reduction in PL intensity.

This study shows that the appearance of silicon dihydride (SiH2) on the surface of porous Si coincides with an increase in photoluminescence intensity, in contrast to the weak luminescence observed with predominant silicon monohydride (SiH) termination.

This paper provides a brief review of avalanche photodiode fundamentals and describes significant advances in materials and device structures that have improved their performance for high-bit-rate, long-haul fiber optic communications.

This paper develops a matrix-based quantum kinetic theory for impact ionization that goes beyond the conventional Born approximation, enabling the microscopic treatment of electron-electron scattering essential for modeling avalanche photo-diodes.

This paper reports the epitaxial growth, fabrication, and characterization of nearly strain-free, all-BGaInAs pin photodiodes on GaAs substrates, demonstrating that boron incorporation effectively reduces strain while extending the operating wavelength.

This work simulates and experimentally characterizes an edge-coupled, 1550 nm AlInAsSb-based single-photon avalanche detector, reporting avalanche breakdown probabilities greater than 85% at an over-bias of less than 2.5%.

This work investigates the growth of AlInAsSb digital alloys on both InP and InP-on-Si templates, confirming high-quality material and achieving low dark currents and high gains from PIN diodes grown on both substrates.

This study systematically compares the impact of different passivation techniques on the performance of AlInAsSb p-i-n avalanche photodiodes, finding that ALD-Al2O3 deposited at 200 °C is most effective at suppressing dark current.

By coupling mechanical testing with targeted microscopy, this study shows that mobile hydrogen-deformation interactions are not an intrinsic requirement for hydrogen-induced intergranular fracture in nickel, as it also occurs at cryogenic temperatures where such interactions are precluded.

Using crack surface marker-band analysis and a fracture mechanics model, this study establishes that the substantial reduction in fatigue life of pre-corroded 7075-T6511 is nearly independent of corrosion exposure time after an initial sharp degradation.

This research on fatigue crack formation from a corroded 7075-T651 surface reveals that the process involves a complex interaction of elastic stress concentration from pit macro-topography and plastic strain concentration from local micro-topography.

Through a combined experimental and modeling approach, this study indicates that hydrogen diffusion alone is insufficient to explain observed intergranular fracture depths in a Ni-Cu superalloy, with phase field simulations suggesting that sub-critical crack growth begins early in the failure process.

This study quantifies hydrogen environment-assisted cracking of Monel K-500 using slow-rising stress intensity loading, finding that the alloy is susceptible to intergranular cracking under cathodic polarization and that this susceptibility correlates with a critical crack tip diffusible hydrogen concentration.

This study examines how fiber laser surface treatment (LST) affects the distribution of β phase and intermetallic particles, as well as the surface integrity and defect formation, in the corrosion-susceptible AA5456 aluminum alloy.

This study presents a new test method for inducing controlled corrosion fissures in simulated fastener holes of 7050-T7451 aluminum alloy, finding that galvanic coupling with an SS316 cathode significantly accelerates corrosion compared to chemical exposure alone.

This study examines the role of hydrogen-metal interactions in the cracking susceptibility of additively manufactured 17-4 PH stainless steel, revealing that AM alloys have lower diffusible hydrogen content but increased hydrogen diffusivity compared to wrought materials.

This paper develops the method of principal geodesic analysis to describe population variability for complex geometric shapes represented by medial axis parameters, which lie in a nonlinear Riemannian symmetric space rather than a Euclidean vector space.

This study uses whole-brain resting-state fMRI to characterize functional connectivity abnormalities in autism, demonstrating that a machine learning classifier can distinguish individuals with autism from controls with high accuracy, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic metric.

This paper proposes using Riemannian geometry for the statistical analysis of diffusion tensor data, developing methods for computing averages and modes of variation that preserve the positive-definite constraint of the tensors.

This paper describes the use of deformable m-reps, a multiscale medial representation, to effectively capture prior geometric information for the segmentation of anatomic objects in 3D medical images.
To clarify age-related brain development in autism, this large longitudinal study examines changes in cortical thickness over time in autistic and typically developing males using MRI scans.
This work proposes RealDeal, an image-to-image diffusion model that enhances the realism of generated brain MRIs by adding fine anatomical details, sharp edges, and realistic imaging noise.
The paper introduces MedIL, a novel autoencoder that uses implicit neural representations to generate medical images at arbitrary resolutions, preserving fine details without prior resampling.
This work proposes RealDeal, an image-to-image diffusion model that enhances the realism of generated brain MRIs by adding fine anatomical details, sharp edges, and realistic imaging noise.
This paper presents LDDMEm, a method and software that decouples diffeomorphic shape analysis from image registration by embedding arbitrary deformation vector fields into the LDDMM framework.
This work proposes a novel diffusion model designed to generate realistic point-based shape representations that preserve point correspondences, as demonstrated on hippocampal shape data.
This paper introduces a generalized framework for Local Differential Privacy (LDP) protocols, leading to two new optimized protocols that provide better utility for frequency estimation.
This tutorial surveys the technical underpinnings, current research, and open problems of Local Differential Privacy (LDP) as used in practice by major technology organizations.

This paper investigates the unintended privacy risks of machine unlearning by proposing a novel membership inference attack that exploits model output differences to infer if a data sample was removed.
This paper proposes SVIM and SVSM, two new protocols for locally differentially private frequent item and itemset mining in set-valued data, which significantly improve utility over existing methods.
This paper proposes GraphEraser, a novel machine unlearning framework for graph data that uses new graph partitioning algorithms and a learning-based aggregation method to preserve model utility.
This paper initiates the new research direction of network-aware differential privacy, identifying opportunities at the intersection of networking and DP related to network security and topology.
This paper designs a highly effective white-box membership inference attack against diffusion models by using model gradients as the attack feature, achieving near-flawless performance.

This work proposes a two-stage, curriculum learning-inspired framework for differentially private image synthesis that first trains a diffusion model on simple "central images" before fine-tuning with DP-SGD.
This paper proposes a unified benchmark for differentially private tabular data synthesis, revealing a significant utility-efficiency trade-off among state-of-the-art methods.

This paper introduces DPImageBench, a unified benchmark for differentially private image synthesis that corrects flawed evaluation protocols and reveals key findings, such as the variable impact of pretraining.
This chapter advocates for case study research as a reliable and credible methodology for analyzing social situations in higher education for sustainable development.

This paper argues that traditional Life-Cycle Assessment (LCA) is ineffective for responsible research and innovation (RRI) and calls for an anticipatory approach that is not retrospective and emphasizes stakeholder engagement.

This paper introduces a novel framework for anticipatory Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) that incorporates technology forecasting and social engagement to guide emerging technologies like photovoltaics toward lower environmental burdens.

This paper presents the Sustainability Education Framework for Teachers (SEFT), which uses four interconnected ways of thinking—futures, values, systems, and strategic—to build sustainability literacy.
This paper explores the concept of "T-shaped" expertise for complex problem-solving and presents an exploratory study evaluating its emergent attributes in two different STEM educational programs.

Drawing on extensive interviews, this book dispels three common myths about regional innovation and proposes a new assessment method that incorporates sustainability and social values beyond simple economic growth.
This research uses content analysis to explore how STEM students from different universities responded to a cross-campus online discussion forum focused on societal and global level macroethics.
This paper uses a mixed-methods approach to identify areas of convergence, such as program design, and divergence between the ASEE divisions for engineering leadership and entrepreneurship.
This paper reviews literature on innovation ecosystems to develop a more robust model for wearable medical devices that addresses the trade-offs between profitability and health outcomes.
This letter investigates the response of additively manufactured refractory high-entropy alloys to helium ion bombardment, showing that compositional complexity can limit helium bubble effects.

This study investigates how defects introduced by ion irradiation can be used to tune both tensile and compressive strain in two-dimensional MoS2, identifying sulfur vacancies as the most favorable defect type.

This work uses heavy ion irradiation and photoluminescence spectroscopy to demonstrate that defect densities in two-dimensional MoS2 can be controlled to tailor optical properties by binding excitons.

This paper demonstrates a scalable approach to achieve twist-dependent properties by growing nanocrystalline hexagonal boron nitride on silicon carbide, yielding strong non-linear optical effects and low thermal conductivity.

This study systematically investigates the effect of Pt catalyst metal content and carbon support type on PEMFC performance and durability, finding that local Pt content is more important than average content for durability.

Using scanning tunneling microscopy, this study reveals and quantifies the tip-induced etching and linear growth kinetics of vacancy islands on 2H-TaS2, a first step toward scanning probe nanolithography.

This work uses monochromated electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) in a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) to perform atomic-resolution spectroscopic analysis of magnons in 2D antiferromagnetic Fe2O3.

This study proposes using multiple advanced characterization tools to obtain both localized optical and structural data for atomic-scale determination of exciton binding energy in defected 2D semiconductors.
This work proposes using localized vibrational EELS to study phonon damping in amorphous materials by decoupling the contributions of boundary scattering and anharmonic interactions.

Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarrays (chIP-chip), this study determined the genome-wide location of 1,139 RNA polymerase binding sites in Escherichia coli, including 721 previously unknown sites.
This study presents an in silico, model-driven analysis of heterogeneous data for the entire Escherichia coli genome, estimating promoter strengths and revealing large-scale chromosomal organization.
This paper develops a scalable formalism to analyze the metabolic demands of protein synthesis in prokaryotes, which can be integrated with existing genome-scale metabolic models.

Using wavelet analysis, this study detects significant long-range periodic patterns in 163 microbial chromosomes, indicating that a nonrandom, multi-scale organization is linked to genome size and composition.
This paper describes and assesses the transition of a hands-on biomedical engineering lab to remote instruction during COVID-19 using asynchronous lectures and gamified simulations.

This paper reflects on eight years of outcomes from a summer REU Site in systems bioengineering and biomedical data sciences, highlighting the need to train a diverse workforce in quantitative skills for "big data" analysis.

This abstract describes a three-year REU Site focused on multi-scale systems bioengineering and biomedical data sciences, which combines experimentation with computational analysis to train undergraduates in disease research.
This work-in-progress paper describes a collaborative, principle-focused curriculum design process for a BME undergraduate program aimed at addressing new ABET outcomes like ethics and inclusivity.
This work uses a large dataset of RNA-small molecule binding data to derive physicochemical "STaR rules" that define a chemical space enriched for RNA binders to accelerate drug discovery.
This preliminary study evaluates student learning outcomes and engagement by comparing pre-recorded versus in-person final presentations in a Systems Bioengineering course.

This paper reviews applications of deep learning in biology and medicine, finding that while promising, it has yet to revolutionize the field due to unique challenges posed by complex biomedical data.
This paper proposes feature squeezing, an inexpensive strategy to detect adversarial examples in deep neural networks by comparing model predictions on original and feature-reduced inputs.

This chapter reviews the Random Forest (RF) machine learning technique, highlighting its advantages for bioinformatics in handling small sample sizes, high-dimensional feature spaces, and complex data structures.
This paper introduces TextAttack, a modular Python framework for adversarial attacks, data augmentation, and adversarial training in NLP designed to democratize research and improve model robustness.
This paper presents DeepWordBug, a black-box algorithm that generates adversarial text by applying character-level transformations to important words, effectively evading deep learning classifiers.
This paper presents Finch-Zk, a black-box framework that detects and mitigates LLM hallucinations without external knowledge by using fine-grained cross-model consistency checking.
This paper proposes AIDE, a novel data synthesis framework that uses an attribute-guided, multi-hop process to expand a small seed dataset for task-specific LLM fine-tuning.

This work demonstrates that reinforcement learning emerges in LLMs at inference time, proposing a multi-round "ICRL prompting" framework where the model improves its responses by maximizing a scalar reward signal.

This paper introduces a hierarchical prompting approach for decision transformers that uses retrieval augmentation to learn global and adaptive soft tokens for context-aware, few-shot policy generalization.
This work proposes ATLA, an augmented adversarial trigger learning method that uses a weighted loss to more efficiently learn generalizable jailbreak prompts and extract system prompts from LLMs.

This article provides an extensive review of the use of shape memory alloys (SMAs) for seismic response control in civil structures, covering their unique properties, material models, and applications.
This study proposes two semi-active control methods, a direct adaptive control method and a neuro-fuzzy controller, for the seismic protection of buildings using MR dampers.
This study performs a sensitivity analysis to determine the optimal design parameters for a novel superelastic-friction base isolator (S-FBI) used for seismic protection of highway bridges.

This paper performs a sensitivity analysis to assess the effectiveness of a shape memory alloy (SMA)/rubber-based isolation system for the seismic protection of bridges against near-field earthquakes.

This paper investigates the seismic performance of a sliding-type base isolation system with a shape memory alloy (SMA) device, considering temperature effects and using a genetic algorithm for optimization.

This paper proposes and analyzes a latticed long-stroke restrainer with buckling-restrained shape memory alloy (SMA) bars (LLSR) that significantly enhances stability for seismic protection of bridges.
This paper presents a decision-making workflow, in the form of a logic graph, to evaluate how an emerging technology contributes to the resilience of a civil infrastructure system.

Following Part I's proposal of a qualitative workflow for evaluating emerging technologies, this paper presents a graph-theoretic analysis of the workflow and applies it to several case studies in civil engineering.

This study experimentally investigates the cyclic response, failure behavior, and reparability of a hybrid superelastic friction damper (SFD) that combines shape memory alloy cables with a friction-based system.
This study explores the performance of a promising self-centering shape memory alloy (SMA) cable bracing system through shake table tests on a four-story steel frame building.

This working group paper explores lessons learned from the shift to online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic to imagine a post-pandemic academic landscape and improve future teaching practices in computing education.

This study analyzes student engagement by gender on the Piazza online discussion forum to investigate whether women are less likely to participate in computer science courses where they are a minority.

This working group paper explores why instructor-developed computing education tools see limited adoption, hypothesizing that discoverability, adaptability, and institutional barriers contribute to the constant reinvention of software.

This working group explores the educational shift caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, aiming to identify valuable new practices that can be carried forward to improve post-pandemic teaching in computing education.

This observational study analyzes the collaboration trends of 189 students in a computer science algorithms course, offering insight into how group size and membership evolve when students are given freedom to self-select.
This study examines the programming language preferences and performance of 268 students in an upper-level algorithms course to understand student outcomes when given a choice of language.
This study surveys instructors at 50 large public universities to explore how and where computing is integrated into STEM and non-STEM undergraduate programs for non-majors.

This paper surveys 44 computer science instructors on their use of auto-graders, finding a preference for customizable tools and a need for integrated solutions with robust core features and extensibility.

To define biofidelity targets for human surrogates in reclined postures, this study evaluated the kinematic and injury response of five reclined post-mortem human subjects (PMHS) in frontal sled tests.
This study uses frontal crash finite element simulations to investigate how occupant size, seat recline, and knee bolster position affect submarining risk and injury metrics for reclined occupants.

This study uses frontal crash finite element simulations to investigate how seat cushion angle affects submarining risk and lumbar spine loads for reclined occupants in autonomous driving environments.

This study performs a preliminary assessment of two occupant FE models to examine restraint interactions, kinematics, and protection challenges for reclined occupants in frontal collisions in automated vehicles.
This study uses postmortem human subjects (PMHS) in frontal impact sled tests to investigate the kinematics and mechanisms of thoracolumbar spine loading and injury for reclined occupants.
This study evaluates local bone microstructural properties at the anterior iliac spine using micro-CT to better understand the wide variation in iliac wing fracture tolerance under seatbelt loading.

This study explores female iliac wing fracture tolerance under frontal lap belt loading and combines the data with previous male data to develop new, more robust injury risk functions for the anterior pelvis.

This study uses a DOE with three finite element occupant models to examine the relationship between lap belt tension and force at the iliac wing, developing preliminary transfer functions to predict pelvic loads.

This study evaluates the effectiveness of pressure sensors inserted into lumbar intervertebral discs of postmortem human subjects for detecting compression, flexion, and combined loading conditions in simulated vehicle crashes.

This study evaluates the biofidelity of obese human body models by comparing their kinematics to obese postmortem human surrogates in frontal sled tests, using a finite element model of the test buck to define boundary conditions.

This paper introduces HAMLET, a hierarchical deep neural network for multimodal human activity recognition that uses a novel attention mechanism to fuse spatio-temporal features for robust robot collaboration.

This paper presents a new dynamical systems approach for human-robot teams that enables a robot to perceive human group motion, anticipate future actions, and contingently coordinate its own movements.

This work introduces Multi-GAT, a graphical attention-based approach for human activity recognition that hierarchically learns complementary multimodal features and uses a novel message-passing mechanism to capture cross-modal relations.
This chapter discusses recent work, applications, and practical challenges in human-robot teaming, drawing on approaches from joint action and dynamical systems to achieve fluent coordination.

This study investigates the efficacy of motion capture versus wearable sensors for recognizing fine and gross-grained human motion in manufacturing, finding that motion capture yielded higher accuracy for both.

This paper introduces FuseCodec, a neural codec for speech tokenization that unifies acoustic, semantic, and contextual representations through strong cross-modal alignment and globally informed supervision to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

This paper introduces Energy-Based Transformers (EBTs), a new class of models that enable System 2 Thinking by framing prediction as energy minimization, demonstrating faster scaling and improved performance on language and vision tasks.

This paper introduces a novel gesture recognition system for human-robot collaboration that leverages a vision-language model guided by retrieval-augmented generation and chain-of-thought to improve adaptability and accuracy.
This work is the first to use physiological measures, gaze, and facial expressions from an in-person, human-robot supervisory interaction study to model and predict human trust in a robot partner.
This article describes a technique for injecting faults into a system's VHDL behavioral-level model to perform early, simulation-based evaluation of fault tolerance for safety-critical systems.
This paper develops two new dependability metrics for the assessment of safety-critical systems: steady-state safety (S_ss) and the Mean Time To Unsafe Failure (MTTUF).

This paper presents the Vital Framework (V-Frame), which uses formal methods and information redundancy to build fail-safe, safety-critical systems from commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware and software.

This paper presents the first known analysis of the Advanced Train Control Systems (ATCS) generator polynomial, providing evidence of its minimum Hamming distance to support its use in vital railway communication systems.
This work-in-progress paper discusses an integrative approach to embedded systems courseware, including a new bridge course that links introductory embedded computing with advanced RTOS concepts.

This paper discusses a major curriculum update in Electrical and Computer Engineering that moves from isolated courses to an integrated spectrum of topics to improve student comprehension and retention.

This paper presents the development of concept-linking inventories designed to assess student understanding of the relationships between electrical circuits, electronics, and signals & systems in a revised, integrated curriculum.

This paper demonstrates a hybrid-phase-transition field-effect transistor using vanadium dioxide (VO2) that exhibits steep, reversible, gate-controlled switching at room temperature by harnessing the material's abrupt insulator-to-metal transition.

This article demonstrates that synchronized charge oscillations can be achieved in coupled vanadium dioxide (VO2) relaxation oscillators by inducing a non-hysteretic, reversible metal-insulator phase transition via a negative feedback mechanism.

This paper demonstrates a dynamical system of coupled vanadium dioxide (VO2) relaxation oscillators that exploits the material's insulator-metal transition to efficiently solve the vertex coloring of graphs, a computationally hard problem.

This study shows that the voltage-induced metal-insulator transition in epitaxial VO2 devices is caused by the Joule heating effect, with electrothermal simulations showing good agreement with measured DC and transient characteristics.

This paper reports the growth of ultra-thin (1.5 nm) VO2 films with abrupt metal-insulator transitions, identifying control of island coalescence and minimization of cation interdiffusion as crucial for achieving this behavior.

This work proposes FIMA, a scalable ferroelectric compute-in-memory annealer based on a FeFET array that accelerates the solving of Boolean Satisfiability (SAT) problems and is compatible with modular memory architectures.

This work demonstrates that second harmonic injection (SHI) in Oscillator Ising Machines can induce "spin freezing," a phenomenon that impedes computation by preventing oscillators from reaching lower-energy states.

This work presents a theoretically grounded framework for configuring Oscillator Ising Machines (OIMs) as probabilistic bit (p-bit) engines by using a novel interplay between first- and second-harmonic injection.

This paper reviews the outstanding challenges and recent innovations in ferroelectric memory technology, a promising candidate for Big Data applications due to the discovery of ferroelectricity in hafnium dioxide (HfO2).

This work introduces the dynamical Ising machine (DIM), a physics-inspired system that, like the Oscillator Ising Machine, minimizes the Ising Hamiltonian but exhibits different dynamical properties to enhance computational performance.

This study summarizes a practical approach for calculating inter-rater reliability (IRR) in qualitative coding when using non-specialized software like Microsoft Word and Excel, offering recommendations for research teams.

This paper explores how undergraduate engineering students in research experiences (UREs) perceive research and researchers, using identity and epistemic cognition as concepts to understand their views on knowledge creation.

This paper describes the use of analytical memo-writing in a mixed-methods grounded theory study to identify key elements from undergraduate research experiences (UREs) that can be translated into the classroom.

This study explores how elementary teachers provide verbal support for science and engineering practices (SEPs) during an NGSS-aligned curricular unit that integrates science, engineering, and computational thinking.

This longitudinal study aims to quantitatively measure how the stigma of mental health conditions within engineering culture is negatively correlated with the help-seeking attitudes of undergraduate students.

This study performs a qualitative analysis of introductory engineering course syllabi from 13 institutions to understand what habits, mindsets, and technical skills are valued and communicated to first-year students.

This study uses thematic analysis of interviews with engineering undergraduates to explore the specific mechanisms through which engineering culture can harm students' mental well-being and limit their help-seeking attitudes.

This paper details two breadboard-based laboratory experiments designed to explicitly teach and assess students’ use of various troubleshooting strategies in circuits courses to methodically identify and repair faults.

This case study explores how two fifth-grade science teachers implicitly and explicitly support the integration of STEM and computer science disciplines through verbal supports during a CS-focused lesson.
This paper presents a novel EEG-based brain-computer interface (BCI) system using an Emotiv EPOC headset and online learning algorithms to classify thoughts and control a Lego Mindstorms robot.

This paper proposes and evaluates a software-based sonar sensor for smart phones that uses the device's own microphone and speaker to accurately measure distances to objects without requiring custom hardware.
This paper presents a code-first platform for rapid prototyping of wearable devices, where the required hardware is generated by analyzing the software application code written by the developer.

This book provides a hands-on guide to modern ethical hacking techniques, from network traffic capture and reverse shells to fuzzing and SQL injection, for aspiring penetration testers and security researchers.

This paper presents a large-scale measurement study on Android I/O delay, finding that reads can be significantly slowed by concurrent writes, and proposes a pilot solution that reduces app launch delay by prioritizing reads.
This paper describes Meme Magic, a series of six sprint-based assignments that provide progressive exposure to Java programming by having students build a fully-functional graphical meme generator.
This work-in-progress paper examines student interaction patterns with online lecture videos and introduces a custom video player designed to promote active learning and provide instructor feedback.
This paper proposes a real-time data compression algorithm for unreliable wireless sensor networks that exploits temporal locality to reduce the number of transmitted bytes and conserve energy.

This investigation focuses on the bond performance between ultrahigh-performance concrete (UHPC) and normal-strength concrete (NSC) for bridge deck overlays, demonstrating good long-term performance under various conditions.
This paper introduces CrackPix, a deep fully convolutional neural network for robust, pixel-level crack detection in concrete infrastructure, overcoming the limitations of coarse, patch-level models.

This paper evaluates commercially available remote sensing technologies for their potential to improve the efficiency and safety of highway bridge condition assessment compared to current labor-intensive inspection techniques.
This paper focuses on increasing the robustness of deep learning-based crack detection models across different construction materials, moving beyond models tailored only to concrete or asphalt.

This paper proposes a new structural identification method that uses variational mode decomposition (VMD) to decompose a dynamic response signal into distinct modal responses for identifying modal properties.
This work introduces a strategy for identifying unseen subsurface damage in structural components by fusing traditional finite element simulations with graph neural networks (GNNs).

This study introduces a novel iterative updating strategy for digital twins, using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict structural behavior and bridge the gap between physical observations and virtual modeling.

This research proposes a novel approach using Convolutional Neural Networks and transfer learning to extract visual deformation measurements from speckle pattern images for adaptive digital twin frameworks.
This project develops and evaluates STRUCT-AR, a mobile augmented reality (AR) application designed to help engineering students visualize and interact with complex 3D structural behaviors.

This study explores the use of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNNs) for semantic segmentation of urban flood extent from real-world surveillance camera images, achieving high accuracy but identifying challenges like specular reflection and low illumination.
This paper reviews the importance of the terahertz frequency band and summarizes efforts to span the "terahertz technology gap," with an emphasis on solid-state integrated diode circuits.

This paper presents a thin film lithium niobate electro-optic phase modulator that demonstrates an unprecedented measured response up to 500 GHz due to precise index matching between the RF and optical modes.
This paper presents a 100-MESFET planar grid oscillator that combines power quasi-optically to produce 21 W of effective radiated power at 5 GHz with 20% efficiency.

This paper presents the design and spectral performance of freestanding resonant metal-mesh bandpass filters for the far-infrared, demonstrating high transmission, strong stop-band rejection, and scalability.

This paper describes the design and characterization of a broadband quasi-optical terahertz detector using a zero-bias Schottky diode on a sinuous antenna, achieving high responsivity from 150-900 GHz.

This paper reports a novel approach for broadband THz phase shifting based on spatially-resolved photoconductivity modulation (SRPM), where changing the illumination area on a hybrid structure tunes the phase.

This work presents the first metal-to-metal diffusion-bonded Gallium Arsenide quasi-vertical Schottky diode heterogeneously integrated onto high-resistivity silicon, demonstrating its suitability for high-frequency applications.

This paper reports an improved process flow for fabricating heterogeneously integrated gallium arsenide Schottky diodes on silicon membranes, focusing on high packing density, co-fabrication of vias, and process simplification.
This paper presents a wideband 90-125 GHz stacked power amplifier in a 130 nm InP HBT process, achieving 18.3% peak PAE and 15.3 dBm output power by aligning load line phases.

This paper describes the development of wide-band switches and true-time delay (TTD) phase shifters using distributed microelectromechanical system (MEMS) transmission lines for phased-array applications.

This paper presents the design and optimization of distributed MEMS transmission-line phase shifters for U-band and W-band, demonstrating high figures of merit and identifying performance limitations.

This paper describes an integrated W-band monopulse radar receiver for tracking applications, based on dielectric-lens-supported slot-ring antennas integrated with subharmonic mixers, achieving excellent monopulse patterns.
This paper presents the design and measurement of a V-band 2-bit switched-line phase shifter that uses SP4T RF-MEMS switches, demonstrating an average insertion loss of 2.5 dB from 55-65 GHz.
This paper presents a double-slug tunable matching network based on a distributed MEMS transmission line, implemented with a new minimal-contact RF-MEMS varactor that largely eliminates stiction.

This paper reports the first millimeter-wave implementation of a prototype "quasi-reflectionless" diplexer, based on the reflectionless filter concept and utilizing a silicon-on-insulator micromachining platform.

This paper describes a proof-of-concept "quasi-reflectionless" filter with a 150 GHz roll-off, implemented on a micromachined silicon-on-insulator (SOI) substrate and exhibiting a return loss greater than 15 dB.

This study models disease outbreaks using dynamic bipartite graphs generated from large-scale urban traffic simulations, finding that the scale-free nature of the locations network allows for highly efficient outbreak detection.

This study uses three different individual-based simulation models to examine the effectiveness of targeted layered containment (TLC) strategies for mitigating an influenza pandemic in a large urban population.

This paper proposes offloading mobile data traffic by exploiting opportunistic communications in Mobile Social Networks (MoSoNets), investigating the target-set selection problem to minimize cellular data usage.
This case study investigates the target-set selection problem for offloading cellular traffic through opportunistic communications in Mobile Social Networks (MoSoNets) to reduce data delivery costs.
This paper describes EMBERS, an automated, 24x7 system that successfully forecasts civil unrest in Latin America by using open-source indicators like tweets, news, and economic data.

This paper presents GenHAI, a novel generative probabilistic model for modeling sequences of MRSA test results during a single hospitalization to help mitigate the risk of hospital-associated infections.

This paper initiates the study of sample complexity for opinion formation in networks, presenting a polynomial time optimization framework to quantify the total samples needed for opinion convergence in linear regression models.

This paper proposes UFID, a unified framework for black-box, input-level backdoor detection on diffusion models that is motivated by a causal analysis of the attack's effect on the input-to-output path.
This paper develops the VaxHesSTL framework, a hybrid GNN-RNN model, to predict spatio-temporal vaccine hesitancy at the ZIP Code level using insurance claims and other public data.

This work proposes SimPO, a simple and effective preference optimization algorithm that uses the average log probability of a sequence as a reference-free implicit reward to align large language models.

This paper investigates using large language models with diversely attributed prompts to generate high-quality training data, finding it enhances model performance, reduces bias, and improves efficiency compared to simple prompts.

This paper proposes a self-training approach for text classification that uses only class label names by leveraging pre-trained language models to generate and generalize from category-indicative pseudo-labeled data.

This paper presents a zero-shot learning approach for NLU tasks where a unidirectional language model generates class-conditioned text to be used as training data for fine-tuning a bidirectional model.

This paper proposes a flexible weakly-supervised method for neural text classification that uses a pseudo-document generator for model pre-training and a self-training module for refinement to address the lack of labeled data.

This work introduces Self-Alignment Optimization (SAO), a fully self-synthetic framework for LLM alignment where the model generates its own prompts, responses, and preferences for preference optimization.
This paper introduces DeSA, a two-stage training framework for LLM agents that improves search and answering by decoupling the optimization of search behavior from final answer generation.

This work presents TruthRL, a reinforcement learning framework that directly optimizes LLM truthfulness by using a ternary reward to distinguish correct answers, hallucinations, and abstentions, thereby improving factual correctness and uncertainty recognition.

This work proposes AdaDecode, a method to accelerate LLM decoding by adaptively generating tokens at intermediate layers when prediction confidence is high, enabling parallel execution of subsequent computations.

This study on LLM reasoning surprisingly finds that reinforcement learning using only negative samples (NSR) can be highly effective, improving performance by suppressing incorrect generations and refining the model's prior knowledge.

This review covers recent developments in the large-scale synthesis and electronic device application of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), discussing obstacles and advances in their electronic transport properties.

This paper proposes using transfer learning with Bayesian optimization-aided sampling (BOAS) to create accurate neural network models for analog mixed-signal (AMS) circuits with a significantly reduced number of expensive SPICE simulations.

This article presents a fractional-N digital multiplying delay-locked loop (MDLL) featuring a background two-point DTC calibration to simultaneously correct gain and offset errors for a low-jitter, low-spur architecture.

This paper proposes and verifies a complete analog mixed-signal circuit design automation flow that uses transfer-learned neural network models to go from specification to silicon with minimal human interaction.

This article presents a fractional-N digital multiplying delay-locked loop (MDLL) that uses injection-error scrambling and a background third-order DTC delay equalizer to mitigate spurs while maintaining a low phase noise floor.

This paper introduces the concept of a transient hyperlogic circuit, which adds a 'paradoxical' state to traditional logic to efficiently handle conflicts and solve NP-hard problems like Boolean satisfiability.

This article presents a 10-bit fully synthesizable stochastic time-to-digital converter (STDC) design that uses common-mode time dithering and passive approximate adders to reduce area and power costs.

This research presents hybrid analog-digital computing platforms enabled by memristor-based quadratic programming circuits, demonstrating over 2000x speed-up on real-time control and machine learning algorithms.

This paper presents a 10-bit fully synthesizable stochastic TDC (STDC) in 12nm FinFET that uses common-mode time dithering and a passive approximate adder to lower implementation cost while maintaining high linearity.
This review updates progress in thermoelectrics, focusing on charge and heat carrier transport, strategies to improve the figure of merit ZT, and new discussions on device physics and applications.

This paper develops a general method to compute thermodynamic and thermal properties of crystals from first-principles calculations by using harmonic and anharmonic force constants to extract bulk thermal conductivity.

This work demonstrates that indium doping in nanostructured SnTe creates resonant levels that enhance the Seebeck coefficient, leading to a significantly improved thermoelectric figure-of-merit (ZT) of ~1.1.

This paper uses first-principles calculations to reveal a link between resonant bonding and low lattice thermal conductivity in materials like lead chalcogenides, explaining their strong anharmonic scattering and low thermal conductivities.
This paper reports the first experimental observation of coherent phonon heat conduction by measuring a linear increase in thermal conductivity with the thickness of finite-thickness superlattices.

This paper introduces THERMACOND, an open-source Fortran90 code for ab initio calculations of phonon thermal transport in crystalline materials by solving the linearized phonon Boltzmann transport equation.

This article summarizes the fundamentals of heat flow in solid materials, including phonon scattering and the role of chemical bonding, and reviews theories for modeling thermal conductivity for thermoelectric applications.

This paper introduces ALATDYN, a lattice dynamics software package that calculates elastic, thermodynamic, and thermal transport properties of crystalline materials from their force and potential energy data.

This study uses classical molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the sintering mechanisms and temperature dependence of coalescing cubic boron nitride (c-BN) nanoparticles at high temperatures.
This work develops and employs a neuroevolution machine learning potential (NEP) to study the high-temperature lattice distortion and elastic constants of the entropy-stabilized oxide MgNiCoCuZnO5.

This paper presents M3DETR, a novel 3D object detection architecture that unifies multiple point cloud representations and feature scales using transformers to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the KITTI and Waymo datasets.

This paper presents an audio-visual deepfake detection method that uses a Siamese-inspired network to analyze the similarity of affective cues between audio and visual modalities, achieving high AUC on the DFDC and DF-TIMIT datasets.

This paper presents TraPHic, a novel LSTM-CNN hybrid network for predicting trajectories of heterogeneous road agents in dense traffic by modeling weighted and horizon-based interactions, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

This paper presents M3ER, a multiplicative multimodal emotion recognition method that robustly combines facial, textual, and speech cues by learning to emphasize reliable modalities and generate proxy features for noisy ones.

This paper presents a novel approach for traffic forecasting that uses a two-stream graph-LSTM network on a dynamic geometric graph to predict both road-agent trajectories and high-level behaviors like overspeeding.

This work proposes the first method to promote safety in in-context reinforcement learning (ICRL) by having the agent not only maximize reward but also minimize a cost function during its parameter-update-free adaptation process.

This paper provides initial theoretical support for why RL pretraining can enable in-context reinforcement learning (ICRL) by proving that a global minimizer of the pretraining loss can enable in-context temporal difference learning.

This survey is the first to catalog and classify existing multi-robot navigation solvers for constrained social mini-games (SMGs) using a unified taxonomy, defining their properties and evaluation protocols.

This paper presents a decentralized approach using discrete-time control barrier functions to ensure safe and deadlock-free multi-robot navigation in constrained social mini-games like doorways and intersections.

This review discusses catalytic fast pyrolysis as an efficient process to convert lignocellulosic biomass into liquid hydrocarbon fuels, focusing on the challenge of removing oxygen from the resulting bio-oil.

This study evaluates various carbon-supported metal catalysts for the vapor-phase hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol, finding that bimetallic Pd-Fe catalysts exhibit enhanced activity while maintaining high selectivity to benzene.
This study shows for the first time that controlling the particle shape of supported Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is critical for maximizing the number of active B5 sites for ammonia decomposition.

This study uses in situ and operando spectroscopy to identify the active single-atom complex in Ir/MgAl2O4 catalysts during low-temperature CO oxidation, revealing a unique reaction mechanism involving Ir(CO)3.

This study investigates hydrogen production from the aqueous phase reforming of glycerol over carbon-supported Pt-Re catalysts, finding that Re addition significantly increases glycerol conversion but at a loss of hydrogen selectivity.

This work combines in-situ spectroscopy and machine learning potentials to show that supported Pt nanoparticles on Al2O3 reversibly change shape from 3D hemispheres to 2D rafts with increasing temperature.

This paper introduces diluted atomic layer deposition (DALD), a scalable method for synthesizing supported single-atom catalysts by using a diluted precursor mixture to precisely control metal loading.
This study reports that exchanging small amounts of zinc into Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts leads to a marked increase of over 80% in methanol production from the partial oxidation of methane.
This study examines the validity and reliability of a five-principle gamification model for digital health interventions by having independent raters evaluate 17 web- and mobile-based apps.

This paper explores the construct of gamification for technology-based behavioral interventions, defining its core features and proposing a model for its application to enhance engagement and adherence.

This paper describes how an inquiry-learning tutor uses an expert knowledge base to recognize content in free-entry student collaborative conversations with high accuracy, supporting problem-solving activities.

This paper evaluates the effectiveness of a pathfinding program visualization (PV) on student algorithm development in an undergraduate Artificial Intelligence course, analyzing artifacts produced with and without the PV.
This paper introduces DiSCS, a new differential sequence segmentation algorithm that finds and clusters meaningful periods of student activity from noisy log data in open-ended learning environments.
This paper presents a model for compressive stress generation in polycrystalline thin films where an increase in surface chemical potential from vapor deposition drives atoms into grain boundaries.

This study uses real-time stress measurements during Volmer-Weber thin film deposition to reveal a generic compressive-tensile-compressive stress evolution resulting from the competition between stress generation and relaxation mechanisms.

This paper derives extensions to the Stoney formula for substrate curvature to account for configurations with thin substrates or large deformations, broadening its applicability for experimental interpretation.
This study uses in-situ spectroscopic light scattering to monitor ripple evolution on ion-bombarded Si(001), allowing for the measurement of the surface migration energy as 1.2±0.1 eV.

This article reviews the fundamental physical origins of intrinsic stresses in Volmer-Weber thin films, covering compressive stresses from surface-stress effects and tensile stresses from island coalescence and grain growth.

This work uses machine learning to identify Ni-Fe as a promising metallic thermoelectric alloy and experimentally demonstrates a high power factor, making it a candidate for active cooling applications.
This report provides the first analysis of the equilibrium phase coexistence and microstructure in the L10 + L12 eutectoid region of bulk Fe-Pd, establishing L1' as a distinguishable phase.
This paper reports and analyzes the complex nanometer-scale wetting of L10 twin and antiphase boundaries by the L12 phase in the two-phase coexistence region of magnetic Fe-Pd alloys.

This paper reports for the first time the thermoelectric and transport properties of the intermetallic compound YbZn11, using band structure calculations and experimental measurements on Al-doped samples.
This paper provides direct evidence from x-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy for the existence of the tetragonal L1' phase, first predicted by Shockley, in a bulk Fe-Pd alloy.

This paper reviews high-temperature shape memory alloys (HTSMAs) with transformation temperatures above 100°C, categorizing them into three groups and discussing the criteria for their application in various industries.

This manuscript reviews the effects of major processing parameters in laser powder bed fusion on build quality and material properties, serving as a guide for modifying parameters to achieve specific design goals.

This paper demonstrates a method for achieving spatial control of functional response in a 4D-printed metallic structure by using selective laser melting to create designed variations in thermal history and precipitate structure.

This work investigates the effect of B2 nanoprecipitates on the superelastic response of FeMnAlNi single crystals, finding that precipitate size, volume fraction, and composition strongly influence the material's properties.
This work provides a comparative study of the cytotoxicity and corrosion resistance of nickel-titanium (NiTi) and titanium-niobium (TiNb) shape memory alloys for biomedical applications.

This study uses transmission electron microscopy to reveal a heterogeneous microstructure with several metastable phases, including a novel orthorhombic phase, in a laser-processed metastable Ti25Nb alloy.

This study examines the effect of raster orientation on the mechanical properties of large-scale 3D printed short carbon fiber-reinforced PLA, finding that a quasi-isotropic layup can improve weak properties.
This work develops a computational framework using a Bayesian approach and the Eagar-Tsai model to generate probabilistic printability maps for exploring the process space in laser powder bed fusion.

This paper uses a novel excitable reaction-diffusion model to show that seemingly random corrosion processes are driven by the spatial distribution of micrometer-scale intermetallic particles that trigger or block corrosion waves.

This study shows that Ampk phosphorylation of Ulk1 is a required step for targeting mitochondria to lysosomes during exercise-induced mitophagy in skeletal muscle, a process preceded by mitochondrial oxidative stress.

This study uses whole transcriptome analysis to map macrophage polarization over the first week of myocardial infarction (MI), revealing a unique pro-inflammatory, ECM-degrading signature at day 1 that shifts over time.

This paper reports the identification and characterization of a novel mitochondrial uncoupler that, unlike canonical uncouplers, does not depolarize the plasma membrane, making it a valuable tool for studying mitochondrial respiration.

This paper describes a novel MitoTimer reporter gene that encodes a mitochondria-targeted fluorescent protein that shifts from green to red when oxidized, allowing for in vivo assessment of mitochondrial stress and damage.

This study uses a validated kinetic model integrating β-adrenergic signaling with excitation-contraction coupling to perform a systems analysis of how the signaling network controls cardiac myocyte contractility.

This article reviews recent advances in the discovery of candidate drugs that stimulate cardiomyocyte proliferation in pre-clinical animal models, emphasizing the need for basic research to translate these findings into effective therapies.

This study uses flexible mesh nanoelectronics to show that the self-assembling peptide RADA16 reduces arrhythmogenic automaticity and improves vascularization of transplanted human iPSC-cardiomyocytes in rat hearts.

This study uses high-content microscopy to track single-cell dynamics of neonatal rat cardiomyocytes, revealing a stress-induced decision between hypertrophy and apoptosis that is governed by a biphasic population-level response.

This study uses single-nucleus multiomics and a deep learning model to define the segment-specific gene regulatory networks controlled by the transcription factor MEF2C that direct heart tube morphogenesis.

This study uses a computational network model and experimental validation to show that pharmacological inhibition of DYRK1A promotes cardiomyocyte cell cycle re-entry and improves heart function after ischemia/reperfusion injury.

This study uses conversations around science journals to explore how young, low-income African American children construct their identities relative to the practices of science and the dominant narrative of "doing school."

This paper analyzes turn-of-the-century teaching manuals to access historical classroom practices, showing how the blackboard was transformed into a teaching necessity for large-group learning in nineteenth-century England.

This paper investigates how vertebrate paleontology technicians, or 'fossil preparators,' construct their work in terms of creativity and artistry, challenging the typical portrayal of technicians as invisible manual laborers.

This study uses Bakhtin's construct of chronotopes to analyze the spoken narratives of young Black children around their science journals, exploring the space-time relationships that constitute their identification with science.

This book investigates the skilled and creative labor of fossil preparators, arguing for a new model of science that acknowledges the often-unrecognized work and workers behind foundational scientific evidence.

This chapter outlines how the discipline of science and technology studies (STS) can provide historians with methodological approaches and theoretical frameworks to access key aspects of the Earth sciences.

This paper explores whether REU program evaluation can be designed as a multi-purpose tool to not only assess the program but also provide research data and foster student learning through reflection.

This article reflects on the chaos in the US research and education apparatus following the inauguration of the 47th president, drawing parallels to historical instances of engineering and authoritarianism.

This paper proposes a model for analyzing how scientific practitioners' conceptions of time reflect the personal, professional, and epistemic values that guide their decisions in the construction of data.

This work-in-progress paper introduces a project to study how a summer REU program in materials science relates to undergraduate students' sense of identity, belonging, and understanding of the research process.

This paper introduces sampling dead block prediction, a technique that uses program counters to accurately predict when a last-level cache block is dead, significantly reducing LLC misses with less state than previous predictors.

This paper proposes the In-Memory Pointer Chasing Accelerator (IMPICA), which leverages the logic layer of 3D-stacked memory to accelerate linked data structure traversal by performing it inside main memory.

This work experimentally characterizes and analyzes the significant latency variation for fundamental DRAM operations across the cells of a single chip, proposing optimizations to exploit this common-case behavior.

This paper introduces SLOs-Serve, a system that uses a dynamic programming algorithm to optimize the serving of multi-stage LLM requests by customizing token allocations to meet stage-specific service level objectives (SLOs).

This work proposes EdgeRAG, a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) system for edge devices that addresses memory constraints by pruning embeddings and generating them on-demand, significantly reducing latency.

This paper argues that redesigning the host-NIC interface is necessary to benefit from emerging cache-coherent interconnects, as current access patterns lead to extraneous communication and limit performance.

This paper presents the first large-scale, fleet-wide characterization of Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs) in a modern cloud environment, providing insights into their behavior and characteristics "in the wild."

This work proposes vPIM, an efficient virtual address translation scheme for scalable, multi-stack processing-in-memory (PIM) systems that optimizes memory network contention and reduces translation time with pre-translation.

This paper argues that the current application-layer gateway approach to IoT connectivity is not scalable and proposes a new architecture that disentangles network connectivity, in-network processing, and user interface functions.

This paper introduces Tock, a new operating system for low-power microcontrollers that uses hardware protection and the Rust language to provide fault isolation, memory protection, and dynamic memory management.

This paper surveys the application of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) in the Internet of Things (IoT), where they can capture complex interactions within sensor topologies to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

This large-scale empirical study explores how software developers use Unsafe Rust in real-world libraries, finding that while the keyword is used in less than 30% of libraries, over half cannot be entirely statically checked.

This paper presents SurePoint, a high-fidelity indoor localization system that uses ultra-wideband radio with frequency and spatial diversity and an efficient broadcast ranging protocol to achieve sub-meter accuracy.

This paper investigates data-efficient indoor event detection by using signature voltage patterns from a PV module, proposing an intelligent on-board algorithm that prioritizes sampling points to improve accuracy and efficiency.

This paper presents Atlas, a private and accurate personalized federated learning framework for IoT applications that uses a layer importance mask to preserve user privacy without compromising model accuracy.

This research leverages commercial indoor air quality sensors and machine learning to detect and classify plant-emitted volatile organic compounds (VOCs), establishing a foundation for advanced plant-based environmental sensors.

This study reveals that axon injury elicits a back-propagating calcium wave that causes the essential nuclear export of HDAC5, which in turn enhances histone acetylation to activate a pro-regenerative gene program.

This paper reviews common pitfalls in the application of clustering to high-throughput biological data, such as failing to consider multiple methods, and presents methods to avoid them to prevent wasted resources.

This study uses quantitative phosphoproteomics to analyze collagen receptor signaling networks, identifying SHP-2 phosphorylation as a candidate downstream signaling node of the DDR2 receptor and its lung cancer mutants.

This study uses luciferase fragment complementation imaging to show that different EGF receptor agonists produce unique temporal signatures for the recruitment of downstream signaling proteins, which could explain their differing biological effects.

This study uses a systems-based approach to understand the molecular basis of variable patient response to the antiarrhythmic drug mexiletine, building a predictive statistical model to personalize treatment for long QT syndrome.

This paper reviews current and emerging informatics technology developments for cancer research, spanning molecular characterization, image analysis, and therapeutics, and identifies themes for the next generation of research.

This paper introduces DANSy, a linguistic approach that represents the human proteome as an n-gram network of protein domains to uncover the abstract rules of domain combinations that determine protein functionality.

This paper introduces PTM-POSE, a tool to explore the interplay between post-translational modifications (PTMs) and splicing, revealing how splicing diversifies PTMs and potentially rewires protein-interaction networks.

This study integrates mechanistic modeling and structure-based analysis to define the principles governing avidity in bivalent protein interactions, using the tandem SH2 domain family as a multivalent archetype.

This research applies the concept mapping method to develop a comprehensive framework of 50 processes for integrating and evaluating social sustainability considerations during the planning and design of construction projects.

This paper shows through a series of eight experiments that when trying to make improvements, people systematically default to searching for additive transformations and consequently overlook advantageous subtractive changes.

This paper describes a framework for sustainable whole systems design, organizing 20 elements identified from a literature review into categories of processes, principles, and methods to enable its widespread application.

This research provides evidence and a methodology for evaluating the impact of process mapping on organizational transparency, finding that it can increase transparency by 5% to 27% in the studied applications.

This paper outlines a detailed lean modeling protocol for evaluating the delivery processes of green building projects, which are often laden with hidden waste and difficult to model with current techniques.
This paper tests an improv theater-based intervention designed to increase psychological safety on student engineering design teams using a randomized controlled trial.
This article argues for a climate adaptation approach for frontline communities that prioritizes need-based distributive justice, informed by an understanding of place-based racial history.

This research finds strong evidence for a "recycling bias" and "reduction neglect," where most people erroneously perceive recycling as the most sustainable action to manage waste, while under-appreciating waste reduction.

This online experiment finds that a multifaceted risk perception questionnaire for coastal infrastructure adaptation imposes more cognitive strain on participants without providing different input than a single question, potentially discouraging public participation.

This study finds that using a future-framed project description leads infrastructure professionals to propose significantly longer design lives, suggesting a simple way to lessen present bias in design.

This paper proposes a scalable, hybrid multi-party computation protocol for privacy-preserving distributed linear regression on high-dimensional data, using a new Conjugate Gradient Descent algorithm suitable for secure computation.

This paper designs and implements a Distributed Oblivious Random Access Memory (DORAM) data structure optimized for two-party secure computation, significantly improving access time, memory overhead, and initialization time over previous constructions.

This paper proposes new, custom protocols for two-party threshold ECDSA key-generation and signing that are proven secure against malicious adversaries using only standard ECDSA-related cryptographic assumptions.

This paper extends a previous two-party threshold ECDSA scheme to arbitrary thresholds, proving it secure against a malicious adversary under only the Computational Diffie-Hellman assumption in the Random Oracle model.

This paper shows how the classical square-root ORAM of Goldreich and Ostrovsky can be modified to provide an efficient solution for hiding memory access patterns in multi-party computation, overcoming the high costs of prior schemes.

This paper revisits the reduction of Oblivious Linear Evaluation (OLE) to Oblivious Transfer (OT), proposing a new method based on the Chinese Remainder Theorem that improves communication cost and is secured against malicious receivers.

This paper investigates the conditions for creating multiparty realizations of NIZKs in the random oracle model, showing a fundamental barrier to constructing efficient, black-box protocols secure against all-but-one corruptions.

This paper introduces input-revealing identifiable abort (IRIA), a weaker notion of identifiable abort for secure multiparty computation that can be achieved with small overheads through a technique called vindicating release.

This paper presents a three-round protocol for threshold ECDSA signing with malicious security that combines an intermediate signature representation with an efficient statistical consistency check and a two-round vectorized multiplication protocol.

This paper initiates the study of fully-secure coin tossing extension (CTE) protocols, proving that statistical, black-box secure CTE with superlogarithmic stretch requires superconstant rounds, and then constructing a constant-round computational protocol.

This paper develops and validates a novel in vitro culture system using acellular normal and fibrotic human lung matrices to investigate how disease-specific extracellular matrix influences fibroblast phenotype.

This paper describes an engineered polyethylene glycol-maleimide hydrogel that exhibits improved reaction kinetics and a wider range of Young's moduli, making it advantageous for cell encapsulation and in-situ delivery.

This study investigates the intrinsic mechanisms of mechanotransduction in matrix stiffness-induced myofibroblast differentiation, finding that it is mediated by MKL1 nuclear translocation and its binding to the α-SMA gene promoter.

This study shows that the structural stability of fibronectin's central cell-binding domains can be modulated to control integrin specificity, thereby directing stem cell differentiation in 2D and 3D environments.

This review discusses the signaling pathways and spatiotemporal crosstalk between macrophages and fibroblasts, the primary cells involved in the biomaterial-mediated foreign body response and fibrous encapsulation.

This study analyzes lung-associated lymph nodes from patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD), finding that active, antigen-specific adaptive immune responses are shared among patients with progressive fibrotic ILD, including IPF.

This study measures the structural stiffness of the capsule and extracellular matrix surrounding the developing Wolffian duct, hypothesizing that this biomechanical property is a major regulator of the organ's morphogenesis.
