This paper integrates a multiscale computational model with experiments to predict how biomechanical and biochemical cues in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) alter cell fate decisions, leading to microvascular remodeling.

This study uses parallel ATAC- and RNA-sequencing to show that impaired fibroblast mechanoperception, modeled by Thy-1 loss, elicits a near-complete shutdown of the developmental transcription factor HOXA5.
This paper reviews recent literature to highlight the importance of food loss and waste (FLW) reduction as a complementary solution to enhance both food security and environmental sustainability.

This paper explores how the food-energy-water (FEW) nexus paradigm provides opportunities for water resources researchers to engage in interdisciplinary research and apply their unique skillset to manage linked systems.

This review provides an overview of the impacts of climate change on agricultural water management, including effects on water requirement, availability, and quality, and the resulting transitions in crop and livestock production.

This paper overviews general concerns about the originality and contributions of socio-hydrology, arguing that while the field promotes considering humans in water systems, its current trends may make it less inclusive and interdisciplinary.
This study proposes an end-to-end forecasting framework that couples a crop growth model with a decision model to translate seasonal climate forecasts into user-related information for farmers.

This paper presents GNN-SWS, a novel end-to-end graph neural network surrogate model that emulates rainfall-driven hydraulic behavior across stormwater systems for real-time prediction and flood mitigation.

This study proposes a novel multi-fidelity graph neural network (MFGNN) framework that integrates numerous low-fidelity simulations with a few high-fidelity runs to create accurate flood hazard maps with limited data.

This study develops a framework combining geospatial analysis with Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) to facilitate a detailed, localized suitability analysis for Direct Air Carbon Capture and Storage (DACCS) implementation in Virginia.
This study introduces a novel methodology using a Convolutional Neural Network (U-Net) to downscale Global Digital Elevation Models (GDEMs) for enhanced, high-resolution urban flood modeling.
This study uses a three-dimensional finite-element model of the biceps brachii to show that nonuniform muscle fascicle shortening is caused by variations in fascicle lengths and curvature.

This work develops and evaluates a new method for creating three-dimensional finite-element models from MR images that represent complex muscle geometry and the variation in moment arms across fibers within a muscle.
This study uses fast-acquisition MRI to quantify the volumes and lengths of 35 lower limb muscles in 24 healthy subjects, determining how muscle architecture scales with subject height and mass.

This study develops and validates methods to construct subject-specific biomechanical models from MR images, quantifying the accuracy of muscle-tendon lengths and moment arms estimated from the models.

This article reviews how MRI is revolutionizing the field of musculoskeletal modeling by providing novel methods for acquiring data on anatomy, muscle architecture, and joint motions from living subjects.

This paper introduces a novel shape-based functional index using wearable sensors and Principal Component Analysis to objectively assess pediatric motor function in patients with neuromuscular disorders like DMD and SMA.
This study develops and deploys an automated artificial intelligence (AI) model to segment and quantify hamstring musculotendon injury and edema from MRI scans of collegiate football athletes.

This multi-center cross-sectional study investigates whether electrical impedance myography (EIM) parameters are associated with muscle structure measured by MRI, histology, and transcriptomics in patients with FSHD.

This study introduces a multi-scale machine learning framework that leverages whole-body MRI and clinical data to predict regional, muscle, and functional disease progression in FSHD, creating a 'digital twin' for individual patients.

This study uses subject-specific 3D finite element models to reveal that the regional distribution of fatty infiltration, not just the total amount, modulates the force-generating capacity of the tibialis anterior muscle in FSHD.

This article presents a roadmap of optical communications, inviting 16 experts to provide their perspectives on the diverse and rapidly changing field, from global networks to datacenter interconnects.

This paper studies free-space optical MIMO transmission using repetition Q-ary PPM to combat fading on turbulent channels, analyzing error probability and constrained channel capacity for Rayleigh and log-normal fading models.

This paper presents a nonrecursive Volterra series transfer function (VSTF) approach for solving the nonlinear Schrödinger wave equation, providing a tool for designing optical systems and equalizers to compensate for dispersion and nonlinearities.

This paper studies optical repetition MIMO transmission with multipulse PPM, showing that this power-efficient format naturally obtains full spatial diversity for combating fading on turbulent atmospheric channels.

This paper develops new monopulse processing approaches for direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation of two unresolved Rayleigh targets, using the Cramer Rao lower bound to give insight into optimal boresight pointing.
This paper addresses the inaccuracy of the ISRS-GN model for non-rectangular signals by developing a new PLI estimation model for arbitrary spectral-shaped signals in C+L-band optical networks.

This paper introduces a modulation-format-dependent nonlinear noise model that accounts for the impact of arbitrary, non-rectangular pulse shapes on fiber nonlinearity, improving NLI estimation accuracy.

This paper proposes an ISRS-Enhanced PLI-Aware (IE-PLIA) routing algorithm for multi-band elastic optical networks that dynamically adjusts routing costs based on physical layer impairments influenced by ISRS.

This paper investigates the use of angle diversity receivers (ADRs) and optical reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (ORISs) to mitigate link blockages in multiuser VLC systems, showing significant SNR gains.

This paper introduces a novel, channel-based resource allocation framework for multi-band over space-division multiplexing optical networks that addresses ICXT, ISRS, and nonlinear impairments to optimize performance.

This paper proposes a methodology to apply Bayesian networks for structural system reliability reassessment, incorporating multiple failure sequences and correlations between component-level limit states.

This paper develops two efficient first-order reliability analysis algorithms for complex multidisciplinary engineering systems with feedback coupling, using a decoupling approach to reduce computational effort.

This study investigates and demonstrates probabilistic analysis and optimization tools for the multidisciplinary design of aerospace systems, including a reusable launch vehicle and a Navy missile system.
This paper discusses the development and evaluation of teamwork skills in a hybrid thermal fluids laboratory course, which serves as an ideal platform for practicing essential engineering skills.
This paper discusses the use of instructional technology tools, including Matlab Grader and Zoom, to enhance learning and provide real-time feedback in a hybrid graduate-level Vibrations course.

This paper describes a new scaffolded laboratory sequence for undergraduate engineering, including a Mechanics Lab designed to supplement a lecture-based theory course and build skills for later labs.
This paper discusses the benefits and challenges of using guided peer review for technical writing in a large laboratory course to teach and assess experimental design and communication skills.

This paper describes the development and implementation of a sophomore-level laboratory course in Experimental Design and Technical Writing to improve communication skills and provide an experiential learning component.
This paper details a model-based approach using statistical signal processing to identify wireless users by exploiting nonlinearities and imperfections in their RF transmitters as a unique signature.

This study uses systems serology to show that the selective placental transfer of antibodies to the fetus is mediated by digalactosylated Fc-glycans, which favor the transfer of NK cell-activating antibodies.

This paper provides an early progress report on several Cancer Patient Digital Twin (CPDT) pilot projects, yielding insights into the opportunities and challenges in personalizing cancer treatment through computational modeling.

This study engineered CHO cells with synthetic genetic circuits to achieve simultaneous and independent small-molecule control of fucosylation and galactosylation, two critical N-glycosylation attributes of monoclonal antibodies.

This study employs an integrative, multi-dimensional omics analysis to dissect the temporal dynamics of N-glycosylation in CHO cell fed-batch cultures, identifying key pathways and factors influencing glycoform production.

This paper presents a flexible computational pipeline that uses multiplexed imaging and interpretable machine learning to quantify and analyze spatial relationships in the tumor microenvironment that are predictive of cell states and clinical phenotypes.
This study uses interaction inference on single-cell RNA-sequencing data from melanoma patients to identify cellular interactome network motifs that predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors.

This study develops a kinetic-dynamic model using single-cell transcriptomics to identify that a LAG3+ CD8+ T cell subset drives breast cancer reduction in bispecific antibody armed T cell (BAT) therapy.

This study analyzes cellular and molecular features in post-COVID patients, identifying two distinct restrictive lung disease phenotypes underpinned by divergent type 1 immune networks and T cell responses.

This review discusses progress in relating the functional properties of the glomerular capillary wall to its unique structure, including a hydrodynamic model that predicts hydraulic permeability based on morphometric findings.
This study shows that resistance to the EGFR kinase inhibitor WZ4002 develops through aberrant reactivation of ERK signaling, and that inhibiting MEK or ERK restores drug sensitivity.

This study demonstrates that ERK1/2 signaling directs the mesenchymal character of NSCLC cells and that blocking this pathway is sufficient to prevent EMT and heighten therapeutic responses to EGFR inhibitors.

This review highlights the complexities of cell signaling regulation by protein phosphorylation, describing it as a multivariate, heterogeneous, and context-dependent process that requires specialized measurement techniques to study.
This paper describes p53Ψ, a transcriptionally inactive p53 isoform generated by alternative splicing that can reprogram cells toward a metastatic-like state by enhancing motility and invasion.

This study combines iterative immunofluorescence imaging and mutual information analysis to show that cell-to-cell variation in ERK activity plays a conserved, dominant role in the heterogeneity of EMT in pancreatic cancer cells.

This study investigates the synergistic therapeutic potential of simvastatin and irinotecan against glioblastoma, finding through RNA-Sequencing that their combined activity converges on the TGF-β signaling pathway.

This work uses iterative immunofluorescence imaging and mutual information modeling to show that cell-to-cell variation in ERK activity plays a dominant role in controlling EMT heterogeneity in pancreas cancer cells.

This study shows that in pancreatic cancer, hypoxic fibroblasts leverage histone methylation and NF-κB activation to secrete growth factors that promote epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in malignant cells.

This work presents an attack-resilient state estimator for cyber-physical systems with noise and modeling errors, showing that an attacker cannot destabilize the system by exploiting the model-reality gap.

This article discusses the design and implementation of attack-resilient cyber-physical systems, with a focus on attack-resilient state estimators that can handle the complexity and heterogeneity of modern control systems.

This paper presents a control-level methodology for autonomous ground robots to guarantee resilience against malicious sensor attacks by using a recursive filtering technique that leverages information redundancy.

This paper describes a framework for controlling a cooperative heterogeneous wireless robotic network of aerial and ground vehicles, presenting strategies for decentralized connectivity and autonomous communications relay.

This paper investigates an online planning problem for energy-efficient UAV operations, using a model predictive controller to estimate energy costs and a self-triggered scheduling policy to determine replanning times.

This paper proposes a Control Lyapunov and Barrier Function (CLF-CBF) enabled MPCC framework for safe mobile robot navigation that enforces safety constraints derived from a free-space corridor and adapts CBF parameters using a SAC policy.

This paper proposes a method to determine the optimal sequence of discrete-time references for a system to track a continuous-time trajectory with arbitrary sampling, minimizing the weighted L2 distance between them.
This paper proposes a novel sampling-based planning framework for autonomous photography that incorporates a new evaluation metric to enhance image quality and minimize the number of photos needed.

This work proposes a lightweight Schwarz-Christoffel Mapping (SCM) framework to close the sim-to-real gap by geometrically mapping control and planning policies from an expert teacher to a degraded learner.

This paper proposes a distributed task and motion planning (TAMP) framework for human-robot emergency response, where a heterogeneous robotic system coordinates with a medic to efficiently find and assist victims.
This paper reports 9 novel mutations in the EIF2B genes, which cause a heritable white matter disorder, and uses homology modeling to analyze their impact on the eIF2B protein complex.
This study investigates the risk factors and potential mechanisms of hollow-organ abdominal injuries in belted occupants during frontal automobile collisions by analyzing field survey data.

This article reviews the inherited disorders of GABA metabolism, including GABA-transaminase deficiency and succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase (SSADH) deficiency, highlighting their clinical phenotypes and diagnostic methods.

This pilot study measured aerosolized particles in the breathing zone of dental operators, finding that a microscope and drape provided the lowest levels of aerosols compared to loupes with or without a face shield.

This article reviews the diagnosis and treatment of neurotransmitter disorders, covering disorders of monoamine synthesis, glycine catabolism, pyridoxine dependency, and GABA metabolism, and emphasizes the importance of CSF analysis.

This study analyzes US crash data from 1998-2021 to evaluate seat belt effectiveness in preventing injuries to pregnant motor vehicle occupants and investigates modifying vehicle- and occupant-specific factors.
This study investigates whether sex-based anatomical differences, measured on CT scans, contribute to the increased risk of lower extremity injuries for females in frontal car crashes.

This study compares crash scene and hospital-reported injury information for child passengers in New Jersey, exploring the congruency of injury frequency, severity, and location by age and restraint type.
This retrospective cohort study using NASS-CDS data finds that intact window glazings in a vehicle after a collision predict a low risk of moderate or greater severity injury in pediatric occupants.

This study compares the performance of feed-forward neural networks (FFNN) and neural machine translation (NMT) models for estimating injury severity from ICD codes, finding that NMT is more accurate.

This paper demonstrates an on-the-fly machine learning approach using mean shift theory to rapidly analyze high-throughput diffraction data and delineate structural evolution in the search for rare-earth-free permanent magnets.

This work uses atom probe tomography to show that the nanostructure and coercivity of alnico permanent magnets are sensitive to alloying elements and the crystallographic orientation during spinodal decomposition.

This inelastic neutron scattering study of the antiferromagnetic topological insulator MnBi2Te4 reveals long-ranged and frustrated magnetic interactions, suggesting proximity to various magnetic phases.

This paper demonstrates an adaptive genetic algorithm to predict and solve the complex crystal structures of intermetallic compounds, identifying the hard magnetic phase and origin of high coercivity in Sm2Co17.

This study uses high-field magnetization measurements to show that the magnetization of MnBi2Te4 and MnSb2Te4 occurs in stages, with the low-field state consisting of ferrimagnetic blocks with both uniform and staggered components.

This study of the ferrimagnetic kagome metal YMn6Sn5.45Ga0.55 finds that its intrinsic anomalous Hall effect is three-dimensional, demonstrating that the Hall response does not originate from 2D Chern gaps.
This study demonstrates that doping the kagome ferrimagnet TbMn6Sn6 with Cr drives it toward magnetic compensation, resulting in giant coercive fields and an enhanced intrinsic anomalous Hall effect.

This paper proposes an efficient DFT-based method that combines constrained DFT+U with crystal field theory to accurately calculate the magnetic anisotropy energy of light rare-earth magnets like SmCo5.

This paper shows how enforcing Hund’s rules in density functional theory calculations can mitigate self-interaction errors and improve the accuracy of magnetocrystalline anisotropy predictions for rare-earth materials.

This study shows that in 2D skyrmion bicrystals, grain boundaries can undergo large amplitude oscillations driven by particle motion, a behavior not accounted for in traditional models of grain growth.

This paper describes the parallel synthesis and screening of a library of 146 nanoparticles decorated with small molecules, discovering a series with high specificity for endothelial, macrophage, or pancreatic cancer cells.
This study develops a novel, second-generation VCAM-1-targeted nanoparticle imaging agent with enhanced affinity that enables real-time detection of inflammatory activation in atherosclerosis.
This study develops a novel VCAM-1–targeted multimodal nanoparticle that uses phage display–derived internalizing peptides to chaperone and trap imaging agents inside VCAM-1–expressing cells.
This summative review analyzes the current efforts, gaps, and challenges in the early detection of sporadic pancreatic cancer, outlining a collaborative strategic pathway for the future of the field.

This study validates plectin-1 (Plec1) as a novel and specific biomarker for pancreatic cancer, showing its expression increases during carcinogenesis and its usability as an imaging target in a murine model.

This study conducts an in-depth analysis of tissue morphology and molecular pathways in Black and White women with early-stage HR+ breast cancer to elucidate the biological factors driving outcome disparities.

This study investigates how the tumor microenvironment and circulating factors are associated with response to nivolumab and cabozantinib in advanced renal cell carcinoma patients from the Checkmate 9ER trial.
This first-in-human phase 0 study evaluates the ability of the radiolabeled peptide PTP-01 to target cell surface plectin (CSP) in pancreatic tumors, despite their dense desmoplastic stroma.
This article reviews the discovery and validation of cell surface plectin (CSP) as a novel therapeutic target for pancreatic cancer, highlighting its role in proliferation, migration, and invasion.

This study constructs an Ad5-based vector with a chimeric Ad3 knob to retarget gene delivery to the Ad3 receptor, circumventing CAR deficiency and increasing gene transfer efficiency to ovarian cancer cells.

This review discusses adenoviral gene therapy for cancer, covering strategies like mutation compensation and replication-competent agents, and developments in tumor-specific targeting and infectivity enhancement.

This study demonstrates that a recombinant adenoviral vector using the tumor-specific survivin promoter can drive high levels of reporter gene expression in multiple tumor cell lines and primary melanoma cells.

This study evaluates the use of the secretory leukoprotease inhibitor (SLPI) promoter in an adenoviral vector to achieve selective transgene expression in ovarian cancer cells both in vitro and in vivo.

This article discusses the use of viral-based RNA interference (RNAi) as a platform to model and correct both recessive and dominant human genetic neurodegenerative diseases in a broad range of animal models.
This paper discusses using healthcare disparities as a tool to teach BME undergraduates about the importance of social justice, empathy, and other non-technical proficiencies in biomedical design.

This paper describes an introductory-level, student-taught biomedical neuroengineering course designed to expose first-year undeclared engineering students to the applications, research, and career opportunities in the field.

This paper describes a team-based, multi-disciplinary humanitarian engineering project designed to teach engineering design and address real-world challenges by incorporating technical, social, and cultural issues.

This paper describes the work of an ASEE subcommittee that developed tenets for creating inclusive classrooms that actively incorporate antiracist pedagogy as part of the Year of Impact on Racial Equity.

This paper provides a historical context of municipal solid waste management (MSWM) in the United States, tracing its evolution from the lack of organized public works in the 1800s to the development of modern systems.
This collection of essays questions contemporary, Western-centric definitions of science, technology, and innovation (STI) by exploring what these concepts might mean from an African perspective.

This paper presents the capacity factor analysis (CFA) model, a tool for assessing a community's capacity to manage and sustain access to water supply and sanitation (Watsan) infrastructure in developing countries.

This paper describes a graduate option in Systems Engineering that integrates technical and ethical training through the use of realistic case studies to foster reflection on the moral implications of technology.

This research develops a decision model using Capacity Factor Analysis to help select sustainable drinking water supply and greywater reuse systems for developing communities, with a case study in Indonesia.

This research uses stakeholder interviews in Norfolk, Virginia, to characterize how social equity is being integrated into coastal climate adaptation planning to address environmental justice and historical disparities.

This research proposes a regional portfolio agriculture model to identify crop choices and compositions that align with microclimate variations, enabling farmers to assess tradeoffs between financial returns and production risks.

This paper discusses a team-based Ethics case study project that brings together diverse high school, HBCU, and PWI students to normalize immersion in STEM and build self-efficacy through peer-to-near-peer collaborations.

This study formulates and analyzes a mathematical model using optimal control theory to find the right balance of water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) interventions to mitigate the spread of waterborne diseases.
This paper explores the use of Convolutional Neural Networks as a promising deep learning alternative to complex mechanistic models for providing accurate and timely forecasts of algal blooms.
This study investigates how to improve online advertising efficacy by modeling user behavior to predict advertising response and probabilistically serving ads based on those behaviors.
This paper proposes an extension to the Markowitz model that uses dimensionality reduction to forecast efficient frontiers, accounting for the nonstationary behavior of asset returns and covariances.

This article revisits the discussion on the annualized calculation of standard deviation in finance, presenting a new example that illustrates the inherent bias in this common risk measurement practice.
This article proposes an innovative approach to segmenting financial market time periods into discrete, persistent, and recurrent states to formalize and evaluate state-based decision-making models.
This paper examines the current and future state of systems engineering education, identifying evolving industry demands and proposing a curriculum that better aligns with these needs.

This paper presents an innovative, state-based approach to investment portfolio design that uses a Markovian process and optimization to make asset allocation decisions based on market state membership.
This paper reports the fabrication of a novel, lightweight carbon nanotube-polystyrene foam composite that demonstrates very effective electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding properties.
This study develops conductive carbon-nanofiber-filled polymer-foam structures, targeting their use for lightweight and effective electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding applications.

This second edition of The Handbook of Photonics explores recent advances in the field, covering photonics materials, devices, and systems, with new sections on optical fiber technology, nanotechnology, and polymeric optical materials.

This study investigates the formation of self-organized conical micro/nano structures on various metal surfaces by ultrafast laser irradiation, exploring the influence of laser parameters and gaseous environments.

This comparative study investigates the electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding properties of carbon nanofiber- and multi-walled carbon nanotube-filled polystyrene composites, finding that carbon nanotubes are more effective at low filler loadings.
This paper describes a high-resolution, deep-UV 266 nm laser-based integrated LIBS, fluorescence, and Raman (LFR) system developed for probing lunar and planetary simulants and geological materials.

This paper presents a compact, handheld chemical sensor that integrates deep-UV Raman and laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) using a single 266 nm laser and an autofocus mechanism for mixture detection.

This study presents the first demonstration of using laser ablation to recover gold from electronic waste in the form of micro- and high-value nanoparticles, identifying the ablation threshold with a two-temperature model.

This study advances the green recycling of silver from silicon solar cells by using laser ablation to selectively remove and recover it as microparticles and nanoparticles, with a CNN model for process automation.

This paper demonstrates a waveguide-coupled germanium photodiode on a scalable silicon platform with an optoelectrical 3-dB bandwidth of 265 GHz, surpassing the performance of state-of-the-art III-V devices.

This paper demonstrates two modified uni-traveling carrier photodiode (MUTC) structures that incorporate a "cliff" layer to achieve high saturation current, reaching a bandwidth product of 3456 GHz·mA.
This paper reviews the performance of high-power, high-linearity modified uni-traveling carrier photodiodes, which are key components for microwave photonics and optics-based analog links.

This paper demonstrates a miniaturized, chip-based optical frequency division system that uses soliton microcombs to generate ultra-low-noise microwave and mmWave signals on an integrated photonic platform.

This paper demonstrates a thin-film lithium niobate (TFLN) photonic computing circuit that leverages efficient electro-optic conversion and spatial scalability to perform inference tasks with high speed and low energy consumption.

This paper describes a chip-scale, universal millimeter-wave frequency synthesizer that uses dual, microresonator-soliton frequency combs and high-speed photodetection to generate tunable electronic signals from DC to >1000 GHz.
This research explores how to design sustainable and high-quality human computation games for commonsense data collection by implementing and analyzing two social games on Facebook and PTT.

This paper introduces MMToM-QA, a new multimodal benchmark for evaluating machine Theory of Mind, and proposes BIP-ALM, a novel method that uses Bayesian inverse planning accelerated by language models to engineer this capacity.

This paper demonstrates a reinforcement learning agent with a compositional recurrent neural network that can perform zero-shot generalization to satisfy previously unseen LTL formulas in both symbolic and Minecraft-like domains.

This paper presents a grounded semantic parser that learns to translate natural language commands into executable Linear Temporal Logic (LTL) formulas for robotic execution without direct annotation or correction.

This paper presents a method for inferring diverse 3D models of human-object interactions from single 2D images by using action-conditioned modeling and commonsense knowledge priors extracted from large language models.

This paper introduces CLASS, a method for learning behavioral representations for robot manipulation from heterogeneous demonstration data using supervised contrastive learning with weak supervision from similar action sequences.

This paper proposes OAfford, a novel one-shot 3D object-to-object affordance grounding approach for robotic manipulation that combines vision foundation models and point clouds for effective generalization.
This paper introduces Moving Out, a new physically-grounded human-AI collaboration benchmark, and BASS, a novel method to enhance agent diversity and understanding for complex collaborative tasks.

This paper introduces Moving Out, a new physical human-AI collaboration environment designed to illustrate challenges in coordination, awareness, and action consistency, highlighting the failure of existing AI agents in these areas.

This paper introduces CaseEdit, a new dataset and pipeline for evaluating localized commonsense knowledge editing in small LLMs, and shows that null-space constrained methods like AlphaEdit are highly effective.

This review covers recent advances in generative molecular design, discussing model design choices, problem formulations for inverse design, and considerations for integrating these models into real discovery campaigns.

This paper describes a closed-loop, autonomous molecular discovery platform that integrates machine learning to experimentally realize 294 unreported dye-like molecules across three automated design-make-test-analyze cycles.

This paper presents a large dataset of 15,000 small molecule transfer free energies from water to cyclohexane, calculated using molecular dynamics, and uses it to train a deep learning model for predicting hydrophobicity.

This manuscript summarizes the proceedings of the Third Modeling Workshop on bioprocess modeling, discussing the current state and future directions of modeling from the molecular to the facility scale.
This work develops a graph-based neural network architecture and an automated data curation pipeline to predict the viscosity of binary liquid mixtures as a function of composition and temperature.

This community paper, developed from an NSF workshop, summarizes the MPS community's perspective on how to best capitalize on and contribute to the future of Artificial Intelligence in the mathematical and physical sciences.
This work proposes a new energy-based model approach for predicting changes in protein binding free energy (ΔΔG) by decomposing it into sequence-based and structure-based components.
This work proposes MolInteract, a simple and effective architecture-focused approach for multimodal molecular property prediction that uses an interaction layer to fuse 2D and 3D information.
This CAREER award supports research to design peptide-functionalized surfaces with tunable nanoscale patterns by understanding how molecules change their behavior when tethered to a surface.
This paper develops PepMNet, a hybrid deep learning model that uses a hierarchical graph approach to integrate atom-level and amino acid-level information for predicting peptide properties.

This computational analysis investigates the dependence of electron-phonon coupling and electron heat capacity on electron temperature for eight metals under strong electron-phonon nonequilibrium conditions.

This study uses a coupled atomistic-continuum model to investigate the kinetics and mechanisms of short-pulse laser melting and disintegration of thin metal films, revealing an interplay between melting front propagation and homogeneous nucleation.

This study uses a combined molecular dynamics and continuum model to investigate short-pulse laser ablation of metals, identifying three regimes of material response: melting, photomechanical spallation, and phase explosion.

This large-scale molecular dynamics study demonstrates that the mechanisms of laser ablation of organic solids strongly depend on the irradiation regime, with phase explosion dominating in the thermal confinement regime and spallation in the stress confinement regime.

This study develops a nonequilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) approach to investigate thermal boundary conductance at solid-solid interfaces, finding a significant temperature dependence not accounted for by mismatch models.

This large-scale mesoscopic simulation study finds that the thermal conductivity of carbon nanotube (CNT) aerogels, films, and fibers follows a nearly linear scaling law with respect to material density.

This integrated computational and experimental study establishes direct links between the dynamics of laser ablation of FeNi targets and the evolution of optical signals in pump-probe measurements, covering both spallation and phase explosion regimes.

This study combines time-resolved X-ray probing with large-scale atomistic modeling to gain unique insights into the ablation dynamics of thin gold films, mapping nanoscale density heterogeneities to distinct diffraction features.

This study numerically and theoretically investigates the thermal conductivity of three-dimensional disordered isotropic fibrous materials, deriving a theoretical equation for dense networks and a universal power law near the percolation threshold.

This molecular dynamics study investigates the femtosecond laser melting of a Pb nanoparticle embedded in an Al film, revealing that melting is driven by homogeneous nucleation within the superheated nanoparticle.

This paper studies the estimation of static games of incomplete information with multiple equilibria, proposing a flexible estimator and an algorithm for simulating all equilibria, with an application to stock recommendations.

This paper surveys and applies several statistical and machine learning techniques to the problem of demand estimation, proposing a robust and scalable method for combining underlying models via linear regression.

This article provides an overview of recent research on estimation methods for nonlinear models with both classical and nonclassical measurement errors, describing key ideas for identification and estimation.

This paper develops a theory of inference for player valuations in generalized second-price auctions, relying on the weaker assumption of no-regret learning rather than the traditional Nash equilibrium assumption.

This paper develops a functional differentiability approach for solving statistical optimal allocation problems, deriving Hadamard differentiability of the value functions and applying the functional delta method to obtain their asymptotic properties.
This article argues for the key role of absolute disclosure risk in the privacy risk assessment of public data releases, countering arguments that favor differential privacy.

This work introduces a competition model generalized from the Tullock contest to analyze the tension between human creators and generative AI, suggesting that a stable equilibrium between human and AI-generated content is possible.

This chapter reviews the econometric analysis of static and dynamic models of strategic interactions, focusing on identification and estimation methods for recovering structural parameters and making counter-factual policy forecasts.

This paper reviews recent computational approaches for the two-phase flow motion of dispersed particles, droplets, and bubbles, focusing on momentum transfer and turbulent diffusion in dilute systems.

This review covers advances since 2011 in the fabrication, design, and understanding of mechanically durable superhydrophobic surfaces, summarizing progress on improving resistance against various types of wear damage.
This paper reviews and investigates the drag of non-spherical particles of regular and irregular shapes, developing a modified Clift-Gauvin expression that integrates the Stokes and Newton regimes.
This paper describes a technique to fabricate inherently superoleophobic coatings by spray casting a self-assembling nanocomposite slurry of ZnO nanoparticles and a perfluoroacrylic polymer.
This paper reviews and develops new descriptions for the quasi-steady shape and drag coefficient of isolated deformable drops and bubbles, formulated in terms of local Weber and Reynolds numbers.

This study explores a novel Turbine-Integrated Isothermal Compressed Air Energy Storage (TICAES) concept for offshore wind, using a spray-based numerical model to assess the performance of near-isothermal compression and expansion.

This experimental study investigates the impact of freestream turbulence on the energy harvesting performance of a single semi-passive oscillating hydrofoil turbine, a potential renewable energy device for rivers.

This study uses a stepped optimization scheme with OpenFAST to minimize the levelized cost of energy for a semi-submersible floating wind turbine by optimizing its substructure under extreme environmental conditions.

This paper describes the construction and characterization of a novel, vertically oriented, axisymmetric-sector Inertial Particle Separator (IPS) wind tunnel designed to preserve realistic flow features for studying particle separation.

This study explores the structure-property relationships of additively manufactured 316L stainless steel, explaining its high strength and ductility through the presence of a fine cellular-dendritic substructure and high dislocation density.

This paper introduces MAPLE direct write (MAPLE DW), a new laser-based direct-write technique that combines LIFT and MAPLE to transfer and deposit electronic and sensor materials in air at room temperature.

This paper describes MAPLE DW (matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation direct write), a novel laser-driven technique for the direct writing of active and passive mesoscopic circuit elements like resistors and capacitors.

This study compares conventional pulsed laser deposition (PLD) and matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation (MAPLE) for depositing thin films of the biodegradable polymer PLGA, finding significant molecular weight changes in both techniques.

This paper reports a method to increase the adherence of diamond coatings on substrates with large thermal-expansion mismatches by creating a three-dimensional, thermally and compositionally graded interface.

This study utilizes strain rate jump testing to predict the incremental spin formability of Al alloys, investigating the effects of rapid strain rate changes on Portevin–Le Chatelier (PLC) instabilities and formability metrics.

This paper reviews and provides new thermophysical property data for several Nb-alloys, using physics-based models to compare their high-temperature performance with Ni-superalloys and other refractory alloys.

This study reviews the high-temperature constitutive responses of Nb-alloys and proposes a unified model combining the Larson-Miller parameter and Sellars-Tegart model to describe both tensile and creep deformation.
This work investigates the use of strain rate jump testing to predict the flow formability of Al alloys, focusing on how rapid changes in strain rate affect Portevin-Le Chatelier (PLC) instabilities.
This paper presents software reflexion models, a technique that helps engineers compare a high-level model of a software system with its source code to see where the models agree and differ.

This report outlines the future software challenge of ultra-large-scale (ULS) systems, which will be decentralized, continuously evolving, and constructed from heterogeneous parts, requiring new software engineering practices.
This paper argues for managing technical debt in software-reliant systems by developing economic models to understand and communicate the long-term effects of short-term expedients.

This paper presents software reflexion models, a technique that allows engineers to compare design and implementation artifacts by summarizing their consistencies and inconsistencies, supporting tasks like design conformance and change assessment.
This paper evaluates the potential of a new theory, which uses design structure matrices and real options, to inform software design by applying it to Parnas's classic KWIC designs.
This paper addresses the simulation-reality gap in validating Automated Driving Systems (ADSs) by proposing realism constructs to assure the construct validity of simulation-based testing methods.
This paper introduces semSensFuzz, a new fuzz testing approach for AI perception systems that uses semantic mutation of real-world test cases to efficiently reveal misinterpretations.

This work explores fuzzing as an automated test input generation technique for mobile robots, developing PHYS-FUZZ, which accounts for physical attributes to more quickly find failure-inducing scenarios.

This paper discusses how Software Defined Networking (SDN), by separating the data and control planes, can improve network management by allowing a centralized software program to control network behavior.

This paper describes Procera, a control architecture for software-defined networking (SDN) that includes a declarative policy language based on functional reactive programming to express dynamic, stateful network policies.

This paper presents Kinetic, a domain-specific language and control system that allows network operators to control their networks dynamically and automatically verifies the correctness of these control programs.
This paper presents CORONET, a fault-tolerant Software Defined Networking (SDN) architecture that can rapidly recover from multiple link failures in the data plane.
This study examines and analyzes five years of router, switch, and firewall configurations from two large campus networks to understand how network configuration evolves over time.

This paper presents Scallop, an SDN-inspired selective forwarding unit (SFU) for video conferencing that decouples media operations into a hardware data plane and a software control plane for improved scalability.
This paper presents Spotlight, a P4-based system that leverages a programmable data plane to detect pivot attacks by analyzing traffic patterns without relying on end hosts or middleboxes.

This paper presents ACORN, a distributed system that automatically translates user-level Python machine learning programs into network-level programs and deploys them with runtime programmability for in-network classification.

This paper proposes NAP, a high-level network programming language with a versatile approximate dictionary abstraction that allows programmers to easily use compact data structures on programmable data planes.

This paper presents Hydra, a system that uses runtime verification to check that every packet in a network is correctly processed by compiling properties written in a domain-specific language into executable P4 code.
This paper reports the use of chemically exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets as effective near-infrared (NIR) photothermal agents for applications like tissue ablation and drug release.
This study synthesizes and characterizes twelve different equiatomic five-metal high entropy carbides, finding that nine form true single-phase materials with significantly enhanced hardness.

This study fabricates and characterizes eleven high-entropy fluorite oxides with five principal cations, finding that eight possess single-phase solid solutions with high configurational entropies and can be sintered to high density.

This paper presents an unambiguous demonstration of the crossover from diffuse (particle-like) to specular (wave-like) phonon scattering in epitaxial oxide superlattices, manifested as a minimum in thermal conductivity.

This study measures the cross-plane thermal conductivity of single crystalline silicon phononic crystals, finding values over an order of magnitude lower than bulk Si, indicating that coherent phononic effects are responsible.

This study uses an ultrafast pump-probe technique to measure near-field heat transfer across metamaterial interfaces, demonstrating the thermal excitation of hyperbolic plasmon-polaritons in a CdO-based hyperbolic metamaterial.

This study performs independent measurements of the in-plane thermal and electrical conductivities of dilute AlCu thin films, finding that the Wiedemann–Franz law overpredicts the thermal conductivity by at least ~10%.

This study uses momentum-resolved electron energy-loss spectroscopy to demonstrate that polar vortex lattices in PbTiO3 spatially modulate the material's vibrational spectrum, with the vortex chirality imparting a unique asymmetrical spectral shift.

This study screens over fifteen million refractory high-entropy alloy combinations to select candidates with low neutron absorption and then characterizes the microstructural, thermal, and mechanical properties of three promising alloys.

This Primer describes the theory, design, and implementation of time-domain thermoreflectance (TDTR), a pump-probe metrology instrumental for measuring the heat transfer properties of bulk and nanostructured materials.

This study uses conditional deletion of the transcription factor Atoh1 to show that Merkel cells are essential for the proper encoding of light-touch responses mediated by Merkel cell-neurite complexes.
This study uses fMRI, behavioral testing, and somatosensory-evoked potentials to investigate the neural mechanisms underlying the distinction between self-produced touch and touch by others.
This article reviews the latest innovations in providing sensory feedback to prosthetic hands, arguing in favor of peripheral nerve interfaces to restore functionality and reduce cognitive burden.

This study uses an ex vivo skin-nerve preparation and model-based cluster analysis to show that the regularity of sustained firing can distinguish slowly adapting type I (SAI) and type II (SAII) touch receptors in mouse skin.

This work uses finite element models to show that the microstructure of fingertip ridges produces high, local stress concentrations at ridge tips, enhancing the contrast of stress signals for tactile edge perception.

This study uses digital image correlation to capture skin surface deformation during soft tissue manipulation, demonstrating that strain-based biomarkers can objectively measure increases in tissue mobility and align with self-reported pain.
This work describes a novel approach using digital image correlation to measure 3D cutaneous skin deformation and kinesthetic digit movements during active touch exploration of compliant materials.

This study investigates the demographic and technical factors that lead to more authentic-sounding AI-generated human voice clones by evaluating a library of cloned and authentic voices with human listeners.

This study uses 3-D digital image correlation (DIC) to reconstruct and analyze the spatiotemporal evolution of fingertip skin deformation during contact initiation, revealing rapid deformation and high compliance at low forces.

This study uses optical skin surface tracking and derived strain-based biomarkers to identify asymmetrical distinctions in bilateral soft tissue mobility that correspond with self-reported myofascial pain.
This paper describes the use of supramolecular, shear-thinning hydrogels for the direct 3D printing of high-resolution, multi-material structures into self-healing support gels.

This review examines biofabrication strategies for constructing 3D in vitro tissue models and functional tissue replacements, focusing on the development of processable biomaterials like supramolecular and photosensitive hydrogels.

This study develops a dual-cross-linking hyaluronic acid hydrogel system that combines shear-thinning guest-host bonds for 3D printing fidelity and covalent photopolymerization for long-term structural stability.

This review highlights recent advances in hyaluronic acid (HA) hydrogels for biomedical applications, covering new modifications for crosslinking, composite designs, and advanced processing techniques like 3D printing.

This paper presents a generalizable bioprinting method that enables 3D printing of hydrogel structures from nonviscous, photo-crosslinkable inks by crosslinking the material in situ immediately prior to deposition.

This study uses a 3D finite element COMSOL model to predict that focused ultrasound-mediated blood-brain barrier opening enhances glymphatic waste clearance by increasing both diffusion and convection.

This work develops a focused ultrasound (FUS) crosslinkable granular hydrogel system composed of FUS-responsive microgels and fibers, offering a novel, noninvasive method for stabilizing regenerative hydrogels.

This study develops and characterizes a polyethylene glycol-based granular hydrogel system without interparticle cross-linking that exhibits bulk stress-relaxing behaviors and is permissive to multicellular self-organization.
This paper reports a system for conformally encapsulating stem cells by depositing and crosslinking a modified hyaluronic acid hydrogel directly onto the cell plasma membrane.

This study describes the first use of an injectable, fibrous hyaluronic acid hydrogel composite to augment uterosacral ligament suspension (USLS) in a rat model, showing improved mechanical properties post-operatively.

This paper combines a successive approximation linear quadratic regulator (SALQR) with management periods and a finite element model to determine optimal, time-varying pump-and-treat policies for groundwater remediation with reduced computational demand.

This study develops a finite difference contaminant transport model with a distribution of mass transfer rates that provides significantly improved simulations of trichloroethene desorption from long-term contaminated soils.

This paper compares two constraint handling methods for genetic algorithms in optimal groundwater remediation design, finding that a multiplicative penalty method produces a set of feasible and near-optimal solutions.
This work develops a robust genetic algorithm (GA) approach for groundwater remediation design that accounts for hydraulic conductivity uncertainty by varying realizations between GA generations.

This paper combines differential dynamic programming with quasi-Newton approximations (QNDDP) and a finite element model to determine optimal time-varying pumping policies for groundwater remediation with reduced computational effort.
This work validates two versions of a three-nitrogen-pool (3P) model against field bioretention data, finding that the 3P-m model provides improved predictions of nitrogen transport and removal.

This case study in Virginia quantifies the impact of nonpoint source water quality trading (WQT) on an urban catchment, finding that it increased total phosphorus loading and that collocating buyers and sellers could mitigate this.

This study develops and evaluates six different nitrogen removal models (NRMs) for stormwater bioretention systems, calibrating and validating them against a year-long dataset to improve design optimization.
This study integrates a novel spatial social equity objective into a multiobjective optimization model for urban stormwater low-impact development (LID/GI) to address inequitable distribution.
This study compares nitrogen concentrations in leachate from biochar-amended and compost-amended roadside soils under simulated large storm events and increasing antecedent dry periods.

This work proposes a novel bi-level random forest approach to accurately predict near-term passenger train delays in the Netherlands, outperforming several alternative statistical and machine-learning models.

This paper proposes an efficient framework to bridge physics-based hurricane projections and outage risk models, finding that uncertainty in future hurricane frequency is the primary driver of uncertainty in outage projections.

This paper introduces an incremental sparsity-promoting compressive sampling approach for Polynomial Chaos (PC) expansions that breaks the dimensionality of the problem to achieve a sparser and more accurate recovery.

This paper uses survival analysis at multiple scales to model track geometry deterioration, finding that fine-scale models of isolated defects improve the prediction quality of coarse-scale segment-based models.

This paper proposes a near-optimal sampling strategy for the sparse recovery of polynomial chaos expansions that improves both local-coherence and cross-correlation properties of measurement matrices.

This paper presents the fundamentals of a Bayesian forecasting system (BFS) that produces a probabilistic forecast of a hydrologic predictand by decomposing total uncertainty into input and hydrologic uncertainty.

This essay presents a compendium of reasons for probabilistic forecasting in hydrology, arguing that it is scientifically more honest, enables risk-based warnings, and offers additional economic benefits over deterministic forecasts.

This paper introduces the bivariate meta-Gaussian density, a flexible model constructed from the normal quantile transform that can represent a full range of association between hydrologic variates with arbitrary marginal distributions.

This article presents a synthesis of an analytic-numerical Bayesian forecasting system (BFS) for producing short-term probabilistic river stage forecasts, detailing its components, estimation procedures, and operational attributes.

This paper presents the theory and development of the hydrologic uncertainty processor (HUP), a component of the Bayesian forecasting system that quantifies all non-precipitation-related uncertainties in river stage forecasting.

This paper presents experiments with the ensemble Bayesian forecasting system with randomization (EBFSR), which enables the generation of a large hydrologic ensemble forecast from a small meteorologic input ensemble.

This study prototypes a probabilistic National Blend of Models (NBM) using the Bayesian Processor of Ensemble (BPE) to address the challenges of combining, calibrating, and extending multiple NWP guidance products.

This paper formulates one- and two-stage stochastic models to quantify the uncertainty in severe weather watches and warnings, using transition probabilities to characterize all possible sequences of alarms and events.
This study reviews and evaluates eight resource-constrained scheduling (RCS) algorithms to identify shortcomings that must be addressed for their application in delay analysis.

This study proposes a new tiebreaker for resource-constrained scheduling heuristics and classifies their performance based on specific project characteristics, finding that the new tiebreaker enhances the performance of the late finish rule.
This paper uses Data Envelopment Analysis to assess the cost forecasting performance of construction projects, considering both the accuracy and timeliness of the forecasting methods.

This work investigates the physico-mechanical properties of concrete made with cupola furnace slag as a substitute for fine aggregate, finding favorable compressive strength when replacing 20% of the sand.

This paper illustrates the presence of "phantom float" in commercial scheduling software, which arises because existing resource-constrained scheduling methodologies neglect resource relationships between competing activities.

This work-in-progress paper describes a methodology using drawings to explore students' perceptions of engineering in introductory courses, aiming to facilitate meaningful reflection on their preconceptions.
This paper presents an experimental comparison of four unit-level software testing criteria, finding that mutation testing detected more faults than edge-pair, all-uses, and prime path coverage.
This paper presents a novel solution for integration testing of web applications using mutation analysis, defining new mutation operators and presenting a tool (webMuJava) that implements them.

This paper introduces, evaluates, and refines web mutation operators for targeting interaction faults in web applications, finding that mutation-adequate tests provide significantly higher coverage than traditional tests.

This paper explores a logic mutation approach to selective mutation by generating only specially engineered subsuming higher-order logic mutants, finding that this can be more efficient and effective than traditional mutation.
This paper presents and validates a queuing model of an asynchronous web server implemented using the proactor pattern, demonstrating its use to guide configuration and provisioning decisions.

This report summarizes the 4th International Workshop on Education through Advanced Software Engineering and Artificial Intelligence (EASEAI'22), which gathers researchers to discuss the integration of these fields in education.

This report summarizes the 3rd International Workshop on Education through Advanced Software Engineering and Artificial Intelligence (EASEAI'21), which brings together researchers to discuss the combination of these fields in education.
This report presents observations and analysis from the transition of a college software testing course from an in-person to a virtual learning semester during the COVID-19 pandemic.

This article reviews the current progress and future challenges in developing rare-earth-free permanent magnets, emphasizing the importance of understanding microstructure for improving coercivity and remanent magnetization.

This paper describes a highly selective and robust catalyst for cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation, consisting of Pt nanoclusters confined within the cavities of an amino-functionalized metal-organic framework (MOF).

This study creates fatigue-resistant, high-performance elastocaloric cooling materials by using additive manufacturing to form a nickel-titanium nanocomposite with extremely small hysteresis and repeatable performance over 1 million cycles.

This paper reports a non-oxide-based reactive metal-support interaction (RMSI) between platinum and 2D Nb2CTx MXene, where a Pt-Nb surface alloy forms at moderate temperature, exhibiting weaker CO adsorption.
This paper demonstrates noninvasive terahertz (THz) nano-imaging of encapsulated niobium transmon qubits, identifying sidewall loss and discontinuity as major coherence limiters.

This study synthesizes size-tunable B2-phase CuPd intermetallic nanocrystals and demonstrates a volcano-like trend in their performance for the electrochemical nitrate reduction reaction (eNO3RR) to ammonia.

This talk highlights recent advancements in understanding the contribution of surface oxides and Josephson junction barriers to decoherence in superconducting qubits, using transmission electron microscopy and spectroscopy techniques.

This study uses in situ Lorentz transmission electron microscopy to observe that helical domain reorientation under uniaxial stress is mediated by topological defects through "break-and-reconnect" or "dislocation gliding-annihilation" processes.

This study uses labeling experiments and DFT calculations to show that during the selective oxidation of alcohols over supported gold catalysts, oxygen atoms from hydroxide ions, not molecular oxygen, are incorporated into the alcohol.

This textbook introduces the quantitative treatment of chemical reaction engineering, covering both homogeneous and heterogeneous reacting systems and including numerous worked-out problems and real-world applications.

This paper examines the literature on selective oxidation of biomass-derived molecules over supported metal catalysts, comparing reaction rates in a consistent manner and providing recommendations for kinetic investigations.
This study evaluates commercial carbon-supported Ru and Pt catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, finding that Ru is more active at neutral pH while Pt is more selective to propylene glycol.

This study shows that a ReOx-promoted Rh/C catalyst is selective for the hydrogenolysis of secondary C-O bonds in polyols and cyclic ethers, proposing a bifunctional mechanism involving acid-catalyzed ring-opening and metal-catalyzed hydrogenation.

This study revisits the influence of Ni particle size on CO2 methanation over Ni/CeO2, finding that the turnover frequency is independent of particle size and that ceria's main benefit is enhancing Ni reducibility.

This paper maps the conceptual efforts to apply Science, Technology, and Society (STS) to engineering education, analyzing the discourse of ASEE and mentoring experiences to understand how STS informs design and research.

This work-in-progress paper examines the character of STS programs embedded in engineering schools, comparing them to standalone courses as a powerful model for providing engineering students with crucial nontechnical skills.

This paper underscores the importance of nontechnical engineering skills learned through Science, Technology, and Society (STS) and explores how generative AI can be used as an active learning tool to refine written communication.
This paper analyzes the design, purpose, and execution of STS minors in STEM-focused institutions to understand how they are designed to provide critical education and attract engineering students.

This paper moves beyond preliminary discussions to introduce faculty to a new narrative about the inevitability of AI, empowering them to become informed advocates for ethical AI practices in the undergraduate classroom.
This paper explores how a situated and competency-layering pedagogy can enhance the effectiveness of the Giving Voice to Values (GVV) framework for teaching ethical leadership in engineering.
This paper provides an overview of a new engineering ethics course that incorporates the Giving Voice to Values (GVV) framework to help students understand how to act on their personal ethics.
This work demonstrates a chip-based, low-noise microwave oscillator that uses two-point optical frequency division with a dark soliton frequency comb to down-convert an ultrastable optical reference.

This paper describes and investigates an integrated self-healing technique for improving the performance and yield of millimeter-wave power amplifiers against process variation, load mismatch, and transistor failure.

This paper presents an interference-robust, detector-first, near-zero power wake-up receiver (WuRX) that achieves high sensitivity and low power operation through a passive detector design and integrated offset compensation.

This paper proposes a sub-μwatt digital temperature compensation architecture that generates voltage and current references with a user-defined temperature response, allowing it to cancel non-linearities in the components it supplies.

This paper presents a detailed investigation of a method to reduce additive phase noise in regenerative frequency dividers, demonstrating a low-noise, octave-spanning divider in a 250-nm InP HBT process.

This survey provides a comprehensive and structured overview of recent advances in feature selection research from a data perspective, covering algorithms for conventional, structured, heterogeneous, and streaming data.
This paper proposes a deep anomaly detection model for attributed networks that uses a graph convolutional autoencoder to capture complex interactions between network structure and node attributes.

This paper proposes a self-supervised multi-channel hypergraph convolutional network to enhance social recommendation by leveraging high-order user relations, which are under-explored in existing models.

This survey provides a comprehensive and structured review of both traditional and frontier methods in learning causality and causal relations, highlighting the connections between causality and machine learning in the era of big data.

This paper investigates how to incorporate noisy and incomplete label information to improve attributed network embedding, proposing a joint optimization framework to learn more effective vector representations.

This survey provides a comprehensive overview of Graph Foundation Models (GFMs), unifying diverse efforts under a modular framework to guide research in this rapidly evolving field of general-purpose AI for structured data.

This paper proposes FedHERO, a federated graph learning framework with a dual-channel GNN and structure learner, designed to effectively handle node classification tasks on heterophilic graphs with varying neighbor distributions.

This paper introduces Inversion Quantification (IQ), a framework to quantify the degree to which post-hoc explanations rationalize predictions from the output, and proposes Reproduce-by-Poking (RBP) to mitigate this explanatory inversion.

This survey provides a comprehensive examination of scaling in LLM reasoning, categorizing it into multiple dimensions and analyzing how different scaling strategies contribute to improving reasoning capabilities.

This paper provides a brief survey of text classification algorithms, covering feature extraction, dimensionality reduction, existing techniques, and evaluation methods, and discusses their limitations and real-world applications.

This paper introduces HDLTex, a hierarchical deep learning approach for text classification that employs stacks of deep learning architectures to provide specialized understanding at each level of the document hierarchy.

This paper introduces Random Multimodel Deep Learning (RMDL), a new ensemble, deep learning approach for classification that solves the problem of finding the best deep learning architecture while improving robustness and accuracy.

This study uses mobile sensing (GPS) and in-situ self-reports to test clinical models of how state affect, depression, and social anxiety are associated with time spent at home among college students.

This paper proposes Patient2Vec, a computational framework that learns an interpretable deep representation of longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data, personalized for each patient, to predict future hospitalizations.

This paper presents WatchAnxiety, a transfer learning approach that uses smartwatch data to predict state anxiety in socially anxious college students, achieving 60.4% balanced accuracy in a real-world evaluation.
This paper presents SocialPulse, a real-time, on-smartwatch system that uses transfer learning to detect both in-person and virtual social interactions from foreground speech and conversational cues.
This monograph discusses recent advances in federated learning (FL), a decentralized machine learning setting, and presents an extensive collection of open problems and challenges in the field.

This paper proposes feature squeezing, a new strategy to harden deep neural networks by detecting adversarial examples through a comparison of model predictions on original and feature-reduced inputs.

This paper introduces the sequential Monte Carlo Localization method for mobile sensor networks, arguing that it can exploit mobility to improve the accuracy and precision of localization without additional hardware.

This paper demonstrates several techniques for improving the efficiency of the garbled-circuit technique for secure two-party computation, resulting in an implementation that is significantly faster and more scalable than previous approaches.
This paper analyzes wormhole attacks in wireless networks and proposes a cooperative protocol using directional antennas to prevent them by having nodes share directional information.

This paper evaluates the replicability and generalizability of inference-time methods for improving LLM reliability, finding that while promising, their performance varies significantly across different domains, tasks, and base models.
This work examines the reliability of prevalent bias metrics in assessing allocational harms from LLMs, finding that they fail to reliably capture group disparities in allocation outcomes.
This paper uses representation engineering to study censorship in LLMs, presenting a method to find a refusal-compliance vector that can detect and control the level of censorship in model outputs.
This paper conducts the first study of whether Large Language Models (LLMs) can infer natural language events from time series data, evaluating 18 LLMs on a new sports-based benchmark.
This paper adapts representation engineering techniques to study gender representation in LLMs, introducing a new method to extract and steer concept representations to mitigate gender bias.
This paper proposes Widar3.0, a Wi-Fi-based zero-effort cross-domain gesture recognition system that derives and extracts domain-independent features of human gestures from wireless signals.

This paper presents Widar2.0, the first Wi-Fi-based system that enables passive human localization and tracking using a single link on commodity devices by leveraging multi-dimensional signal parameters.
This paper proposes Widar, a Wi-Fi-based tracking system that simultaneously estimates a human's moving velocity and location at a decimeter level by building a theoretical model of CSI dynamics.

This article proposes a novel scheme for device-free passive detection of moving humans using Channel State Information (CSI) from multi-antenna Wi-Fi systems, exploring the full potential of both frequency and space diversity.

This work presents WiDance, a Wi-Fi-based user interface for interactive exergames that extracts complete motion-induced Doppler shifts from commodity Wi-Fi to infer motion direction without training.

This paper presents SCR, a new spoofing-resilient and communication-integrated radar sensing scheme that uses a novel chirp configuration and signal processing pipeline to reliably detect spoofing and communication signals.

This paper introduces RFScape, a novel framework that bridges neural scene representation and RF propagation modeling by learning per-object electromagnetic properties for flexible and accurate scene composition.
This paper proposes RFCanvas, a framework that fuses visual priors and few-shot RF measurements to accurately and responsively model RF channel propagation in dynamic environments.

This paper introduces KeyStub, a passive RFID-based keypad interface that uses multiple resonant stubs to discriminate discrete keystrokes by creating predefined impedance mismatches detectable by a commodity reader.

This paper proposes NeuroRadar, a neuromorphic radar sensor that jointly optimizes analog hardware and a spiking neural network computation model to achieve low-power wireless sensing for IoT systems.

This microcosm study investigates the biodegradation of weathered hydrocarbons in contaminated refinery soils, finding that biostimulation with nutrients and bioaugmentation with degraders significantly reduced hydrocarbon fractions.
This work demonstrates the enhanced biodegradation of phenol by a mixed microbial population in a solid-liquid two-phase partitioning bioreactor (TPPB) using solid EVA polymer beads.

This paper argues that Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) is weakly rooted in organizational theory and identifies key aspects for its empirical study, including risk commensuration, portfolio comprehensiveness, and communication.

This paper reviews the current challenges in managing petroleum hydrocarbon contaminated sites in Nigeria, highlighting fragmented regulatory instruments and the need for appropriate, risk-based policy.

This review analyzes the science and regulatory inclusion of bioavailability in assessing complex chemical mixtures in contaminated soils, identifying challenges and research needs for improving risk assessment frameworks.

This 7-year post-spill study monitored the recovery of infauna macrobenthic invertebrates in an oil-polluted tidal flat, finding a change in community structure and an improvement in species richness and number.

This laboratory study uses an integrated approach to show that compost and biochar amendments to contaminated soils significantly affect the bioavailability and toxicity of complex chemical mixtures, providing evidence for remediation end-point assessment.

This study uses empirical data from a mesocosm experiment to assess the ability of artificial neural network and random forest models to predict temporal bioavailability changes and toxicity of complex chemical mixtures in amended soils.

This 12-month mesocosm experiment investigates the effect of physicochemical factors and weathering on heavy metal and metalloid fractionation in multi-contaminated soils, providing insights into their mobility and bioavailability.

This chapter presents a case study of the Niger Delta, showing how constructive stakeholder engagement can be used to integrate community values into environmental regulation and sustainable development for oil-contaminated sites.

This paper presents BeWell, a comprehensive smartphone application that automatically tracks sleep, physical activity, and social interactions to monitor multi-dimensional wellbeing and provide intelligent feedback.

This study explores using smartphone sensors to detect sleep states and quality by collecting one month of data from 27 users. The resulting models achieved high accuracy in classifying sleep state, daily sleep quality, and overall sleep quality, with individual models outperforming general ones.

This article presents BeWell+, an enhanced smartphone app that monitors sleep, physical activity, and social interaction to promote wellbeing through ambient feedback on the device's wallpaper. The new version introduces community-adaptive feedback and wellbeing-adaptive energy allocation to address limitations of the original app.

This study investigates using passive sensing data from smartphones and Fitbits to infer loneliness levels and identify corresponding behavioral patterns in college students. Using statistical analysis, data mining, and machine learning on data from 160 students, the research successfully extracted behavioral patterns associated with loneliness.

This study presents a machine learning approach using passive sensing data from smartphones and fitness trackers of 138 college students to detect and predict depressive symptoms. The novel feature extraction technique achieved high accuracy in identifying students with depressive symptoms and predicting their onset 11-15 weeks in advance.

This pilot randomized controlled trial evaluates MoodRing, a mobile application that uses passively collected smartphone data to provide symptom feedback and coping strategies for adolescents with depression. The study aims to determine if the app, which includes components for the adolescent, parent, and clinician, improves the quality of depression management compared to treatment as usual.

This study explores the feasibility of using a multiwavelength optical sensor in an off-the-shelf wearable device to noninvasively track nutritional biomarkers in the blood. The device's ability to measure spectral absorption profiles of various nutrients is compared against a spectrophotometer to assess its potential for real-time dietary monitoring.

This 24-week study investigates whether the severity of anxiety in 55 adolescents can be predicted using passively sensed behaviors from Fitbits and mobile phones. The research finds that anxiety can be predicted with a low mean absolute error, with phone usage, mobility, and activity behaviors being particularly useful predictors.

This paper introduces the Sub-Action Interaction Network using Transformers (SAINT), a novel policy architecture for reinforcement learning in combinatorial action spaces. SAINT represents multi-component actions as unordered sets and models their dependencies using self-attention, consistently outperforming strong baselines in complex combinatorial environments.

This paper investigates the desirability of a circadian-aware, AI-driven scheduling application for college students by evaluating prototypes with varying levels of circadian awareness. While students overwhelmed by time management found the tool less helpful, the results indicate that students are receptive to AI schedulers that consider their circadian rhythms.

This work presents a combined ultrasound and photoacoustic imaging tool to provide real-time, image-guided delivery and monitoring of nanoparticle-labeled stem cells into the spinal cord. The system successfully guided needle placement and detected as few as 1000 gold nanosphere-tagged stem cells during delivery.

This study develops an ultrasound/photoacoustic (US/PA) imaging platform for the longitudinal tracking of stem cells delivered to the trabecular meshwork (TM) of the eye as a potential glaucoma therapy. Mesenchymal stem cells labeled with gold nanospheres were successfully injected and visualized in ex vivo porcine eyes, demonstrating the platform's potential to expedite clinical translation.

This study demonstrates that labeling mesenchymal stem cells with magnetic Prussian blue nanocubes (PBNCs) allows for magnetically steered delivery to the trabecular meshwork (TM) in the eye. This targeted approach significantly increased the delivery of stem cells to the entire circumference of the TM, a potential therapeutic strategy for glaucoma.

This paper presents a photoacoustic contrast agent for detecting human matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) in the tumor microenvironment using gold nanospheres functionalized with a DNA aptamer. The aggregation of these nanospheres in the presence of MMP-9 enhances the near-infrared optical absorption, enabling sensitive and selective detection via ultrasound-guided photoacoustic imaging.

This study develops a multimodal imaging approach using ultrasound, photoacoustic, and magnetic resonance imaging augmented with Prussian blue nanocubes (PBNCs) to guide and monitor stem cell therapies in the spinal cord. The technique enabled real-time needle guidance and detection of low concentrations of PBNC-labeled stem cells in ex vivo rat models.

This chapter reviews the role and advantages of ultrasound (US) and photoacoustic (PA) imaging for cancer detection, therapy guidance, and monitoring.
