It summarizes the key principles of this hybrid multimodal approach, which combines the benefits of optics and acoustics to provide both morphological and functional feedback.

This special research topic highlights cutting-edge imaging and diagnostic technologies for visualizing the complex spatiotemporal dynamics of the immune-tumor microenvironment. The collection of articles offers insights into mechanisms of resistance and guides the optimization of current and novel cancer immunotherapies.

This study demonstrates that surface-engineering cytotoxic T cells with drug-loaded nanoparticles enhances their delivery for a potent combinatorial cancer therapy. Using ultrasound-guided photoacoustic imaging, the targeted delivery of these nanoengineered cells was confirmed, facilitating precise image-guided delivery and increased nanoparticle accumulation in tumors.

This paper introduces the acoustic loudness factor (ALF), a novel benchmarking parameter for predicting the performance of small molecule dyes in photoacoustic imaging (PAI) without needing photoacoustic instrumentation. The study demonstrates that ALF can guide the design of dyes with enhanced photoacoustic signals and that improvements in ALF translate to in vivo PAI.

This paper introduces the Stool Stomper, a handheld mechanical device designed to standardize and accelerate stool sample preparation for the Kato-Katz technique used in diagnosing soil-transmitted helminth infections. In-country testing in Tanzania showed that the device reduced preparation and counting time while improving the consistency and accuracy of artificial egg counts.

This paper proposes a theoretical framework called CHARMED, which combines hindered and restricted models of water diffusion to characterize anisotropic water diffusion in brain white matter. The model uses both a hindered extra-axonal compartment and a restricted intra-axonal compartment to explain diffusion signals across a range of MRI b-values.

This paper presents a comprehensive approach to correct for patient motion and eddy current-induced distortions in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) data. The method uses a mutual information-based registration technique with a spatial transformation model that simultaneously optimizes parameters for distortion and rigid body motion.

This article provides a practical overview of transport-based techniques for signal and data analysis, which have shown state-of-the-art results in applications like content-based retrieval and machine learning. It covers the mathematical underpinnings of optimal mass transport methods, their numerical implementation, and demonstrates several applications.

This paper describes a multi-center project to create a large, demographically balanced MRI, clinical, and behavioral database of normal brain development in approximately 500 children from birth to 18 years. Using a uniform acquisition protocol, the project aims to provide a comprehensive resource for researchers and clinicians to better understand normal brain development.

This paper proposes the adaptive bases algorithm, a method for intensity-based nonrigid image registration that permits spatial adaptation of the transformation's compliance. This approach reduces the number of degrees of freedom in the transformation, which speeds up the process and improves convergence properties.

This study introduces a novel transport-based mathematical model to detect corrosive defects on metal substrates from infrared thermal images. A new detection technique is devised that uses the signed cumulative distribution transform (SCDT) and a subspace classifier to analyze 1D thermal signals and identify corrosive regions.

This paper proposes a framework for classifying point sets experiencing spatial deformations by employing the linear optimal transport (LOT) transform to obtain a linear embedding of the set-structured data. The method uses a nearest-subspace algorithm in the LOT space, demonstrating label efficiency and non-iterative behavior for classifying datasets with affine deformations.

This work describes an automated and quantitative facial weakness screening framework that uses a Bi-LSTM network to model the temporal dynamics of shape and appearance features from video. The technique is designed to help non-neurologists identify neurological deficits like facial weakness for emergency triage or chronic disease management.

This paper presents a new method for illumination-invariant face recognition based on modeling local gradient distributions using the Radon Cumulative Distribution Transform (R-CDT). The approach models lighting variations as a subspace in the R-CDT domain and performs recognition using a nearest subspace method, outperforming alternatives in challenging lighting conditions.

This paper proposes a novel dissimilarity measure for time series classification based on Optimal Transport, designed to handle warping distortions efficiently. The proposed method is shown to solve the classification problem under a deformation-based model and demonstrates its efficacy on simulated and real data at a reduced computational cost compared to DTW.

This paper proposes a novel iterative belief propagation-convolutional neural network (BP-CNN) architecture for channel decoding under correlated noise. The architecture alternates between a standard BP decoder and a trained CNN to progressively improve the decoding signal-to-noise ratio and achieve better performance.

This paper proposes a deep neural network (DNN) based power control method, PCNet, to maximize the sum rate of a fading multi-user interference channel using unsupervised learning. To improve generalization, the authors also present PCNet+ and an ensemble method, ePCNet(+), which consistently outperforms existing solutions.

This paper presents a design and analysis of physical layer quantization and transmission methods for wireless federated learning (FL), addressing both uplink and downlink communications. New convergence analyses for FEDAVG under non-i.i.d. data and finite-precision quantization reveal trade-offs between communication efficiency and learning performance.

This paper proposes a general framework for personalized federated multi-armed bandits (PF-MAB) that balances generalization and personalization in a mixed bandit learning problem. The proposed Personalized Federated Upper Confidence Bound (PF-UCB) algorithm is proven to achieve an O(log(T)) regret and is validated on synthetic and real-world datasets.

This paper investigates collaborative service placement in MEC-enabled dense small cell networks, where edge servers have limited resources and must judiciously decide which services to host. The authors formulate a service placement problem to maximize the number of offloaded tasks and propose both an optimal algorithm for small-scale scenarios and a low-complexity heuristic for large-scale networks.

This paper discusses the paradigm shift toward edge intelligence, where in- and near-sensor computing transforms traditional sensors into active data processing nodes. It presents the emerging device technologies, circuit architectures, and algorithmic frameworks for implementing the artificial intelligence of things, along with their capabilities, challenges, and strategic roadmaps.

This paper summarizes the 11th Mining and Learning from Time Series (MILETS) workshop, which aims to identify key challenges and explore recent advances in temporal data mining. The workshop covers a range of topics from classical methods to emerging techniques involving large language models (LLMs) to foster collaboration and highlight new research directions.

This paper provides a systematic review of recent advancements in graph prompting, a technique for adapting pre-trained graph learning models to downstream tasks without altering the model weights. It introduces representative graph pre-training methods and reviews mainstream graph prompting techniques, categorizing them based on their design of learnable prompts.

This paper proposes CSE-FSL, a novel communication and storage-efficient federated split learning method that addresses the high overhead of transmitting smashed data and gradients. CSE-FSL utilizes an auxiliary network for local client updates while maintaining a single server model, thereby avoiding frequent transmissions and reducing server storage requirements.

This paper proposes CHOOSE (CHain Of thOught Symbol dEtection), a CoT-enhanced shallow Transformer framework for wireless symbol detection that improves reasoning capacity without increasing model depth. By introducing autoregressive latent reasoning steps, CHOOSE enables lightweight Transformers to achieve detection performance comparable to much deeper models, making it suitable for resource-constrained devices.

This study analyzes in-depth investigations of 57 crashes involving pregnant occupants to understand factors associated with adverse fetal outcomes. The results show that fetal outcome is most strongly associated with crash severity and maternal injury, and that proper maternal belt-restraint use is associated with acceptable fetal outcomes.

This study surveyed emergency department (ED) directors at Level I and II trauma centers to describe current alcohol screening and brief intervention practices. The results show that while most ED directors support these practices, few use standardized instruments or have formal policies in place, citing barriers like lack of resources and training.

This study investigates the effect of subcutaneous fat depth on injury patterns in adult motor vehicle collision occupants using CT scans from 67 crash subjects. The findings suggest that increased subcutaneous fat depth is associated with significantly decreased abdominal injury severity in females.

This study generated a dataset describing in situ human brain motion under injurious rotational loading conditions using unembalmed post-mortem specimens instrumented with sonomicrometry crystals. The results provide crucial experimental data for validating computational models used to understand the mechanisms of traumatic brain injury.

This study of 92 adult pelvic CT scans found significant gender differences in bony pelvic geometry, including acetabular socket depth and femoral head width. These anatomical differences may provide biomechanical insight into why males have reduced tolerance for hip fractures in frontal motor vehicle collisions.

This secondary analysis of the CLOVERS trial evaluates the safety and clinical outcomes of administering vasopressors through peripheral intravenous catheters in early sepsis resuscitation. The study aims to identify factors associated with vasopressor route selection and assess the generalizability of peripheral vasopressor use in US hospitals.

This feasibility study presents a novel approach for measuring cervical spine intervertebral disc (IVD) pressure in whole-body post-mortem human subjects using minimally invasive sensors. The results demonstrate the feasibility and repeatability of measuring IVD pressure changes during various head and neck motions, providing valuable data for biomechanics research.

This phase 2b randomized clinical trial investigated whether intravenous acetaminophen increases days alive and free of organ dysfunction in critically ill patients with sepsis compared to a placebo. The study, conducted in 40 US hospitals, randomized adults with sepsis and respiratory or circulatory organ dysfunction to receive either acetaminophen or a placebo for five days.

This textbook provides guidance for the medical management of mass gathering events, covering topics from general deployment and staffing to complex issues like legal implications and managing adverse events. Written by an international group of contributors, it serves as an invaluable text for healthcare professionals, event planners, and security personnel involved in mass events.

This paper reviews the use of formal verification, a mathematical technique for proving system properties, to evaluate human-automation interaction (HAI). It discusses how the method has been used to assess usability, find potential mode confusion, and evaluate system safety in light of formally modeled human behavior.

This paper presents the enhanced operator function model (EOFM), an XML-based language for describing task analytic models to support the integration of human behavior into formal system verification. The authors provide the formal syntax and semantics of the EOFM and a method for automatically translating it into the input language of a model checker.

This paper presents a novel method for automatically generating task analytic models that include both normative and phenotypically erroneous human behavior from normative task models. This method allows engineers to use formal methods to evaluate how different types of human error can contribute to system failures.

This paper discusses a modeling effort that combined human factors engineering and formal methods to verify human-automation interaction with a programmable patient-controlled analgesia pump. The work highlights the limitations and tradeoffs involved in using a system architecture of decoupled models to perform formal verification of realistic systems.

This paper investigates the mathematical meaningfulness of the NASA Task Load Index (NASA-TLX), a standard method for assessing human mental workload. The analysis concludes that because the level of measurement of the six constituent dimensions is ordinal, neither of the two standard methods for computing an overall workload score is mathematically meaningful.

This research designed and evaluated a wearable vibrotactile display to provide intuitive orientation and communication cues for navigation by people with visual disabilities. An experiment with fully blind participants showed that the device, which communicates the three levels of situation awareness, improved navigation performance and was subjectively preferred.

This study examined the intramodal and crossmodal effects of visual and auditory perceptual load on dual-task interference in a virtual reality (VR) environment. Results showed that perceptual load and task type influenced intramodal interference, but no crossmodal interference was observed, suggesting a degree of independence between visual and auditory processing resources.

This article validates a formal method that combines task analytic modeling and statistical model checking to predict human error rates and the effect of negative transfer from design changes. The validation study, based on the OpenEMR electronic medical record system, addresses deficiencies of prior work by using a more realistic example and refining the prediction method.

This paper proposes an objective metric based on signal detection theory to evaluate the Veracity, or information quality, of explanations in explainable recommender systems. Veracity is decomposed into Fidelity (accuracy of information) and Attunement (reflection of user preferences), which are combined to calculate a sensitivity score that captures differences in explanation quality.

This study integrates a dynamic trust prediction model into a reinforcement learning framework to enhance human-agent collaboration in the Overcooked-AI environment. The agent's reward strategy is modified to account for real-time trust predictions, promoting trust-building actions and discouraging those that erode trust.

This work presents polypeptide organic radical batteries as a sustainable alternative to traditional lithium-ion batteries, addressing ethical and environmental challenges associated with mineral mining and disposal. These batteries utilize redox-active materials from sustainable sources that are designed to be stable during operation but degradable and reconstructible at their end of life.

This review discusses the rational design of biomaterials via peptide self-assembly, focusing on creating dynamic, physical hydrogels that mimic native tissue microenvironments for tissue engineering applications. It covers the design of assembling peptides and the molecular and macroscopic features that govern their assembly, morphology, and biological interactions.

This study combines coarse-grained Monte Carlo simulations and experiments to investigate how a comb-like polymer architecture affects complex coacervation. The results show that the comb architecture mitigates cooperative interactions between oppositely charged polymers, leading to less stable coacervates compared to linear-linear polymer pairs.

This paper reports the crystallization-driven self-assembly of fully degradable amphiphilic block copolymers derived from l-lactide, l-cysteine, and d-glucose. The resulting PLLA-b-PDGC-cys copolymers formed various micellar nanostructures in water, including spheres, cylinders, and bundled platelets, depending on the polymer composition.

This review discusses the molecular engineering of antimicrobial peptide (AMP)-polymer conjugates as a strategy to overcome the clinical challenges of AMPs, such as limited stability and toxicity. It highlights how non-linear polymer architectures and supramolecular assemblies can maximize bacterial killing while enhancing stability and compatibility with mammalian cells.

This work focuses on programming peptide assembly to create advanced biomaterials by exploring the influence of organic processing conditions and stereocomplexation. The research aims to control the structure and properties of peptide-based materials for various applications.

This work provides methods for treating subjects with coronavirus infections, particularly those with prothrombotic conditions like COVID-19, by administering an angiotensin (1-7) peptide or related agonists. It also describes compositions where these peptides are associated with degradable or nondegradable polymers for delivery.

This study compares conjugates of the antimicrobial peptide P9 with star-shaped and comb-like poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) architectures. The results show that comb-like conjugates exhibit increased helicity, solubility, antimicrobial activity, and proteolytic stability compared to star-shaped conjugates of similar composition.

This paper reports an innovative approach for targeted oral delivery of therapeutic peptides to injured tissues using milk-derived small extracellular vesicles (mEVs). By loading mEVs with a Connexin 43 peptide, the engineered nanocarriers demonstrated remarkable injury-targeting capabilities and significantly reduced infarct size in a mouse model of myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury.

This paper combines molecular dynamics, particle-particle, and particle-in-cell models to investigate the physics of ionic electrospray propulsion across nine orders of magnitude in length scale. The multi-scale model is applied to simulate beam emission from porous emitters, analyzing the impact of multiple emission sites on grid interception and beam neutralization.

This study uses grid-based Vlasov simulations to re-evaluate the one-dimensional collisionless plasma expansion into a vacuum, eliminating the statistical noise of particle-based methods. The simulations reveal that the expansion generates both ion-acoustic and electron Langmuir wave modes, and show that the isothermal electron fluid assumption is only valid within a quasi-neutral, self-similar region.

This study uses fully kinetic Particle-in-Cell simulations to investigate the neutralization process of pure ionic electrospray thrusters in bi-polar operation. The results indicate that beam neutralization is primarily achieved through ion bouncing within a potential well established between the beam front and the thruster exit.

This study presents a grid-based Vlasov model to simulate collisionless plasma expansion, aiming to reduce numerical noise and better study electron kinetic properties. The model is benchmarked against particle-in-cell simulations and analytical solutions, successfully capturing the anisotropic kinetic characteristics observed in previous PIC simulations.

This paper introduces Vlasolver, a parallel, multi-dimensional, grid-based Vlasov solver for plasma plume simulation. The paper details the model, algorithm, and parallelization strategies, and verifies the code's correctness and efficiency on two-stream instability and Landau damping problems.

This study develops a grid-based Vlasov simulation model to investigate the two-dimensional unmagnetized electric propulsion (EP) plasma beam emission process, eliminating particle noise to accurately resolve higher-order velocity moments. The simulations reveal that the electron velocity distribution function is non-Maxwellian, leading to near-constant electron temperature along the beam direction but near-adiabatic cooling in the transverse direction.

This paper investigates the statistical noise effects on particle velocity moments in fully kinetic Particle-in-Cell (PIC) simulations by comparing them with grid-based Vlasov simulations. By analyzing plasma expansion and instability problems, the study derives the scaling of PIC statistical noise in density, velocity, temperature, and heat flux, and discusses its limitations.

This study uses grid-based Vlasov simulations to investigate the impact of initial non-Maxwellian electron velocity distribution functions (eVDFs), specifically the Kappa distribution, on electric propulsion beam expansion. The results show a near-constant ion acceleration ratio and an anomalous electron temperature enhancement when starting with an initial Kappa velocity distribution.

This paper presents a charge and current deposition method for electromagnetic particle-in-cell simulations in 3D cylindrical coordinates that rigorously satisfies the continuity equation. The method is a direct extension of the Villasenor and Buneman method and eliminates edge errors by correctly computing the volumes swept by cylindrical sector charges.

This work uses a parallel, multi-dimensional, grid-based Vlasov-Poisson solver to study electron-scale physics in plasma expansion, a fundamental problem with applications in spacecraft wake formation and electric propulsion. The study focuses on how electrons, often treated as an equilibrium fluid, are actually non-equilibrium and anisotropic, and investigates the excitation of electron Langmuir waves.

This paper proposes an approach to synthesize control protocols for autonomous systems, such as UAVs, that accounts for uncertainties and imperfections in interactions with human operators. By modeling human-automation interactions as stochastic two-player games, the approach enables the synthesis of operator-dependent optimal mission plans and can provide informative feedback.

This paper presents two shielding approaches, centralized and factored, to guarantee safety in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) by monitoring agents' actions and correcting unsafe ones. Experimental results show that both approaches guarantee safety during learning without compromising policy quality, with factored shielding offering better scalability.

This paper presents DeepTake, a novel deep neural network framework that predicts a driver's intention, time, and quality of takeover when engaged in non-driving tasks in an automated vehicle. Using features from vehicle data, driver biometrics, and subjective measurements, DeepTake aims to ensure the driver can safely resume control when a takeover is required.

This paper proposes MEDIRL, a novel inverse reinforcement learning formulation for predicting the visual attention of drivers in accident-prone situations. The model learns a task-sensitive reward function from the eye fixation patterns of attentive drivers and outperforms existing models on several benchmark datasets, including the newly introduced EyeCar dataset.

This paper proposes an approach to synthesize control protocols for autonomous systems, such as UAVs, that accounts for uncertainties and imperfections in interactions with human operators. By abstracting interactions as Markov decision processes or stochastic two-player games, the method enables the synthesis of operator-dependent optimal mission plans.

This paper presents the first framework for robust permissive controller synthesis on Interval Markov Decision Processes (IMDPs) to guarantee that all compliant strategies satisfy specifications under uncertain dynamics. The problem is formulated as mixed-integer linear programs with two proposed encodings, a baseline vertex-enumeration method and a scalable duality-based method.

This paper introduces IrrMap, the first large-scale, ML-ready dataset for irrigation method mapping, consisting of 1.1 million patches of multi-resolution satellite imagery and auxiliary data. The dataset, which spans over 11 million acres in the western U.S., is accompanied by a complete generation pipeline to enable extension to new regions.

This paper develops a runtime shielding mechanism for reinforcement learning that provides probabilistic safety guarantees for systems with hidden parameters, such as a robot's mass or friction. The mechanism uses function encoders for real-time parameter inference and a shield that adapts online by forecasting future safety risks and accounting for uncertainty via conformal prediction.

This paper proposes a novel approach for generating counterfactual explanations in continuous action reinforcement learning by computing alternative action sequences that improve outcomes while minimizing deviations from the original. The method, evaluated in Diabetes Control and Lunar Lander domains, leverages a distance metric for continuous actions and accounts for policy constraints.

This study reviews ChatGPT, an AI technology from OpenAI, examining its applications, opportunities, and threats across 10 domains with a focus on business and education. An experimental study was also conducted to compare the performance and effectiveness of different GPT versions.

This paper addresses the profit-oriented disassembly line balancing problem, considering partial disassembly, hazardous parts, and uncertain task processing times. The authors use stochastic programming models and an exact-based solution method to design a serial line that maximizes revenue and balances workload under uncertainty.

This paper proposes using a joint precedence graph to address the disassembly line balancing problem for products with a high variety of end-of-life (EOL) states. The approach is shown to be beneficial for achieving an optimal line balance where traditional methods are used, as demonstrated with a pen and a laptop example.

This paper introduces a method inspired by word clouds to transform a standard liaison graph into a weighted liaison graph (WLG) for disassembly. The WLG graphically depicts both physical mates and disassembly precedence relations, allowing users to quickly comprehend the order of disassembly and component embeddedness.

This paper uses the Graph Model for Conflict Resolution methodology to model a common resource conflict and then applies social choice voting rules and a new "Related games" approach to analyze the outcomes. The proposed method adds a new analytical stage to sieve socially optimal outcomes from the graph model's equilibria.

This study addresses the challenge of restaurant selection by improving dinemait, an AI-powered mobile recommender application, with the goal of increasing user engagement and retention. Using a systems-based approach, the team evaluated the existing application and improved outreach features based on focus groups, surveys, and user data.

This project focuses on increasing pre-appointment patient engagement with the UVA Health System's secure patient portal to enhance the patient experience at a primary care clinic. To address the low completion rate of eCheck-In tasks, the study analyzed patient data and conducted surveys to identify barriers and inform potential solutions.

This study addresses emergency department (ED) crowding at UVA Health by proposing and simulating a redesign of the ED waiting room layout to improve patient flow and satisfaction. Using FlexSim HC software, the redesign, which creates "progression areas" to reduce returns to the main lobby, was shown to significantly decrease patient wait times and increase satisfaction.

This paper proposes an operational approach for multi-objective truck scheduling in a cross-docking system, considering truck breakdown probability, capacity constraints, and earliness penalties. The authors use genetic algorithms and particle swarm optimization to find near-optimal solutions that minimize total completion time and outbound truck earliness/tardiness.

This project partners with VIAble Ventures, a microbusiness run by the VIA Centers for Neurodevelopment, to increase online sales and expand employment opportunities for adults with autism. Using a systems approach, the team analyzed past transactions and redesigned the website to improve the user experience and drive sales growth.

This study examined injury distributions and risk trends for belted occupants in frontal automobile collisions using NASS-CDS data from 1998-2015. Logistic regression models revealed that newer model year vehicles (2009 and later) carry a lower risk of moderate to severe injuries compared to older vehicles.

This article reviews the attributes of human surrogates commonly used in injury biomechanics research, including human cadavers, volunteers, animals, dummies, and computational models. It assesses the merits of each surrogate relative to its ability to characterize living human response and injury in an impact environment.

This book provides a state-of-the-art overview of the applied biomechanics of accidental injury and its prevention, with chapters from renowned researchers covering various aspects of human injury assessment. The third edition is thoroughly revised and expanded, addressing topics such as injury mechanisms, human tolerance, and crashworthiness applications for adult and pediatric populations.

This study developed a strain-based probabilistic method to predict rib fracture risk using whole-body finite element (FE) models. The framework combines an age-adjusted ultimate strain distribution with collision exposure information to predict injury risk and the potential effectiveness of interventions like advanced seatbelts.

This study developed a methodology to investigate three-dimensional, in situ brain deformation during pure rotational loading of the head using sonomicrometry. A human cadaveric head-neck specimen was instrumented with an array of 32 sonomicrometry crystals to directly measure dynamic brain motion, providing data for validating finite element models of traumatic brain injury.

This study analyzed data from 282 impact tests to determine the cervical and lumbar spine forces and moments generated in belted occupants during low-to-moderate-severity frontal impacts. The results show that the spinal loads are well below established injury reference values and are within the range of loads tolerated during daily activities.

This online survey of 1,491 pregnant vehicle drivers in Australia investigated seatbelt use, positioning, comfort, and knowledge. While nearly all participants reported always wearing a seatbelt, only 41.4% positioned it correctly, and most had not received information on proper use during pregnancy.

This study evaluated the performance of the THOR-50M for Reclined Seating (THOR-50M-RS) anthropomorphic test device in nine frontal sled tests under reclined seating conditions. The results, including kinematics and injury metrics, were compared to tests conducted with post-mortem human subjects under the same conditions to assess the device's biofidelity.

This study uses data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (2011–2024) to evaluate geographic differences and trends in habitual seatbelt use, with a focus on pregnant females. A Bayesian regression model was used to analyze the effects of state, year, age, sex, pregnancy status, and enforcement type on self-reported seatbelt use.

This study developed new injury risk assessment curves for short-duration blast-induced pulmonary injury by analyzing data from over 1,100 large animal experiments. A two-variable nonlinear logistic regression was performed on the data for threshold injury and lethality in terms of pressure and duration for both incident and reflected pressure conditions.

This study investigates a possible correlation between high intramural wall stress and the development of atherosclerotic lesions in the carotid artery bifurcation. Using finite element models based on in vivo and cadaveric data, the analysis identified highly localized stress concentrations at the bifurcation point and in the sinus bulb, regions known to be prone to atherosclerosis.

This study investigates localized cavitation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as a potential damage mechanism in blast-induced traumatic brain injury. Experiments using instrumented post-mortem human subject heads in shock tubes indicated that cavitation may occur at pressure levels below those for a 50% risk of blast lung injury.

This study determined a brain fatality risk function for primary blast exposure to the head using anesthetized rabbits whose thoraces were protected. The fatality data from brain injury was analyzed using Fisher's exact test, showing that greater blast intensity was associated with a higher likelihood of fatality.

This study compared the viability of a 40-kg porcine cadaver model as a human surrogate for thoracoabdominal behind armor blunt trauma (BABT) response. By conducting 74 matched BABT impacts on postmortem human subjects and porcine cadavers, injury risk functions were generated and compared across species for lung, liver, and sternum locations.

This study investigated back muscle response over one hour of vertical whole-body vibration simulating a helicopter flight to better understand the high rates of back pain in aircrew members. Surface electromyography data collected from 14 subjects showed low muscle activity, with a significant increase in the multifidus muscle over time, suggesting a link to postural control.

This systematic literature review examines behind armor blunt trauma (BABT) studies with a focus on impact systems and the development of injury criteria for the thoraco-abdominal region. The review aims to identify articles covering thoraco-abdominal injuries, impact delivery systems, and the development of risk curves to enhance medical injury criteria.

This paper presents a matched-pair hybrid test paradigm using live and cadaver swine to develop regional human injury criteria for behind armor blunt trauma (BABT). By delivering BABT loading to liver and lung regions, the study characterized impact loading and correlated it with physiological responses and necropsy findings to establish injury metrics.

This study introduces and validates a biofidelic computational finite element (FE) model of the human pelvis to enhance the understanding of pelvic injury mechanisms under lateral loading. The mid-sized male model, featuring variable cortical thickness, was comprehensively validated against various experimental tests, showing good correlation in predicting biomechanical responses and fracture patterns.

This paper proposes a novel distributed inference algorithm for continuous graphical models by extending Stein variational gradient descent (SVGD) to leverage Markov dependency structures. The approach uses a set of structured local kernel functions defined on each node's Markov blanket, which alleviates the curse of dimensionality and enables decentralized inference.

This paper introduces SIMPLE, a novel gradient estimator for k-subset sampling problems. The proposed method aims to provide an efficient and effective way to handle optimization tasks involving the selection of a fixed-size subset from a larger set.

This paper proposes an efficient search-based algorithm for weighted model integration (WMI) on problems with tree-structured primal graphs. The algorithm exploits the sparse graph structure and context-specific independence to greatly improve computational efficiency compared to existing WMI solvers.

This work introduces probabilistically rewired message-passing neural networks (PR-MPNNs), which leverage differentiable k-subset sampling to learn to add relevant edges and omit less beneficial ones in a graph. Theoretical analysis shows how PR-MPNNs enhance expressive power and mitigate issues like over-squashing, with empirical results demonstrating competitive performance against traditional MPNNs and graph transformers.

This paper introduces MP-WMI, a scalable weighted model integration (WMI) solver based on message passing that addresses the limitations of existing solvers for hybrid probabilistic inference. MP-WMI is the first solver capable of exact inference on all tree-structured WMI problems and can perform inter-query amortization, dramatically outperforming existing solvers on a large set of benchmarks.

This work proposes a probabilistically sound approach for enforcing hard linear equality constraints in deep generative models (DGMs) to generate constraint-compliant and realistic data. The proposed gradient estimators allow the constrained data distribution to be differentiably learned, achieving superior generative performance and guaranteed constraint satisfaction across multiple benchmarks.

This dissertation addresses two fundamental challenges in neurosymbolic AI: enabling differentiable learning of deep neural networks under symbolic constraints and performing scalable, reliable probabilistic reasoning over expressive symbolic constraints. The work demonstrates how these neurosymbolic approaches achieve trustworthiness through explainability, uncertainty quantification, and domain-knowledge incorporation.

This paper develops a unified approach for count-based weakly-supervised learning, where weak labels dictate the frequency of each class over a set of instances. The core of the approach is a differentiable, exact, and efficient method to compute the probability of a specific count of true outputs, which is used to derive a count loss function.

This paper introduces a novel collapsed inference scheme for Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) that improves scalability and performance by revealing a connection between BNN inference and volume computation problems. The method performs Bayesian model averaging using collapsed samples, where a subset of weights are sampled and paired with a closed-form conditional distribution over the rest, achieving state-of-the-art uncertainty estimation.

This paper presents the largest federated learning study to date, involving 71 sites across six continents, to create an automatic tumor boundary detector for glioblastoma without sharing patient data. The resulting model showed a 33% improvement in delineating the surgically targetable tumor and a 23% improvement for the complete tumor extent over a publicly trained model.

This paper proposes a data-driven deep learning framework using a copula model and a deep belief network to forecast short-term power load. The framework first models the tail-dependence of power load on price and temperature using copulas and then uses a deep belief network to forecast hourly load, outperforming classical neural networks in case studies.

This study develops a novel parametric human body shape modeling framework for human-centered product design, based on 3D scan data of 250 subjects. The framework uses statistical analysis to correlate body shape variations with body size measurements, enabling an interactive modeling interface that generates a corresponding body shape model from user inputs.

This paper proposes using generative adversarial networks (GANs) to create large ensembles of synthetic microstructures for heterogeneous energetic materials. This approach supports a materials-by-design framework by enabling the meso-scale simulations required to quantify hot spot ignition and develop models for microstructure-dependent energy deposition.

This study shows that convolutional neural networks (CNNs) trained solely for the task of tumor segmentation on PET/CT images can predict the survival of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. The deep segmentation networks, without any other information, demonstrated predictive power comparable to or exceeding that of established clinical and radiomic prognostic factors.

This study advances the Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Neural Network (PARCv2) to model hotspot formation in crystalline energetic materials under weak-to-moderate shock loading. The improved architecture is capable of predicting strong shock responses and addresses the computational challenges of direct numerical simulations for these complex physical phenomena.

This paper presents the General Physics Transformer (GPhyT), a model trained on 1.8 TB of diverse simulation data that demonstrates foundation model capabilities for physics. GPhyT achieves superior performance across multiple domains, zero-shot generalization to unseen systems via in-context learning, and stable long-term predictions, opening a path toward a universal Physics Foundation Model.

This work accelerates the Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Network (PARC) for modeling energetic materials by projecting the original dynamics onto a lower-dimensional latent space, creating LatentPARC. This approach decouples the problem into learning complex geometric features and modeling dynamics in the reduced feature space, significantly decreasing training time while maintaining comparable accuracy.

This paper describes the Federated Tumor Segmentation (FeTS) Challenge, a competition designed to benchmark federated learning aggregation algorithms and state-of-the-art segmentation models on real-world, internationally distributed brain tumor data. The challenge provides a paradigm for fair, decentralized evaluation of healthcare AI algorithms, yielding benefits for adaptive weight aggregation and client sampling.

This work investigates a meta-learning approach to develop closure models for multi-scale material simulations by learning a reduced representation of micro-scale physics to accelerate meso-scale learning. Applied to shock-induced energy localization in a porous energetic material, the model learns a probabilistic latent representation of micro-scale dynamics as building blocks, outperforming a standard physics-aware model when meso-scale data is scarce.

This paper proposes the "validation square," a framework for validating design research and methods, which often rely on subjective statements in addition to mathematical modeling. Anchored in epistemology, the framework explores how to confirm new knowledge in a field where traditional scientific validation based on logical induction or deduction can be problematic.

This paper constructs a framework for modeling physical material and energy flows in industrial systems using input-output mathematics, independent of monetary implications. Based on previous research in ecological systems, the approach allows a modeler to fully consider both direct and indirect relationships among conserved flows.

This paper presents the validation square, a framework for verifying and validating design methods that rely on subjective statements as well as mathematical modeling. It addresses the problem that traditional, purely quantitative validation anchored in scientific inquiry is often problematic for this type of engineering research.

This paper describes the development of an assessment tool to rigorously measure students' engineering design process knowledge in a large college setting. The approach involves having students critique a proposed design process, with their responses assessed using an analytic scoring rubric to gauge their embodied design knowledge.

This article, a continuation of a companion piece, expounds on the use of ecological input-output techniques to analyze material flows in industrial systems. It introduces several material flow metrics, such as measures of material cycling, to characterize system behavior and link flow analysis to system synthesis and design.

This paper explores the student experience of tracking and reflecting on their design processes by creating visual timelines during team-based engineering projects. By analyzing survey responses, the study finds that self-tracking design activities provides authentic opportunities for reflection and helps students develop metacognitive awareness.

This paper describes a decision-driven methodology for designing business intelligence dashboards that effectively display important metrics for startups based on user and enterprise needs. The methodology involves understanding enterprise data, conducting stakeholder interviews to identify key business decisions, and then determining system objectives and metrics for each decision.

This study characterizes how students' views on cultural differences change after participating in a short-term, practicum-based international engineering and business consulting program in Argentina. Analysis of pre- and post-program responses shows a shift from ethnocentric, surface-level observations to more ethnorelative perspectives that consider deeper cultural context and values.

This paper proposes a systems methodology for navigating the complex decision-making process of commercial solar energy adoption, presented through a case study of a non-profit in Virginia. The methodology involves establishing objectives with stakeholders, identifying limitations, determining key decisions, and interpreting metrics to compare diverse proposals from solar companies.

This paper describes a model used for the past eight years to prepare secondary pre-service science teachers to integrate engineering design into their science instruction, as required by the Next Generation Science Standards. The authors provide the outcomes and suggestions for implementing this model, which they believe is transferable to other teacher education programs.

This study uses time domain thermoreflectance to measure the thermal conductivity and thermal boundary resistance of atomic layer deposited aluminum oxide, hafnium oxide, and titanium oxide thin films on silicon. The results are used to create a design map of effective thermal resistances, which is critical as the shrinking size of dielectric layers makes interfacial resistance a dominant factor.

This study experimentally investigates how point and extended defects impact phonon scattering by using ion irradiation to introduce controlled strain and defects into silicon crystals. By irradiating natural silicon with silicon isotopes, the results demonstrate that point defects decrease thermal conductivity more than extended defect structures for the same damage level.

This study investigates the effect of C3+, N3+, and O3+ ion implantation on the thermal conductivity of polycrystalline diamond. Using time-domain thermoreflectance, the results show that implantation can reduce the thermal conductivity by nearly two orders of magnitude while the material remains polycrystalline in the thermally probed regions.

This paper reports on the thermal resistances and heat capacities of 20 nm thin films of hafnium zirconium oxide (Hf1–xZrxO2) with varying compositions. Using time-domain thermoreflectance, the study found that effective thermal resistances decreased upon crystallization and determined the heat capacities for two specific compositions.

This work reports on the thermal conductivity of sputter-deposited Cu/W, Cu/Ta, and Cu/TaN nanomultilayers with varying thicknesses. The study uses different materials as thermal barriers to manipulate interfacial effects on thermal transport and discusses the resistive interfacial effects in relation to structural transformations upon annealing.

This paper reports that single-crystalline Ruddlesden-Popper chalcogenides (Ban+1ZrnS3n+1) exhibit both ultrahigh mechanical stiffness and intrinsic, glass-like ultralow thermal conductivity. This unusual combination is attributed to strong anharmonicity and intra-unit-cell rock-salt blocks that form intrinsic superlattices, impeding heat conduction through broadband phonon scattering.

This review focuses on the challenges and strategies associated with nano- and microscale optical thermal transport measurements across extreme properties, length scales, and temperatures. It discusses the limitations and error sources in thermoreflectance and pyrometry techniques, highlighting the need for rigorous uncertainty treatment to advance metrology for materials with high thermal conductivity or complex structures.

This study investigates the suitability of VTe2 and ZrTe2 for use in phase-change memory (PCM) superlattices by examining their thermal properties. The findings indicate that both materials are promising candidates due to their high crystalline quality, thermal stability, and consistently low thermal conductivity contrast between phases.

This paper reports on the development and thermal characterization of low-stress, suspended silicon nitride platform devices with membrane thicknesses ranging from 120 nm down to less than 10 nm. The study demonstrates thermal conductivities as low as 1.1 W m−1 K−1 near room temperature, highlighting the potential of these platforms for enhancing the performance of thermal sensors.

This study uses Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System data to examine factors affecting cost-related medication non-adherence (CRN) among US adults with diabetes. The results show that 16.5% of adults with diabetes report CRN, with financial factors like low income and lack of insurance being the most important predictors.

This study uses a Markov model and a cost-consequence analysis to understand the cost of nurse burnout-attributed turnover from a hospital payer perspective. The model compares a "status quo" scenario with a "burnout reduction program" scenario to evaluate the financial impact of burnout on nurse retention.

This scoping review summarizes the characteristics of 116 existing studies on racial and ethnic disparities in sleep to identify evidence gaps. The review found that most studies focus on disparities between Whites and Blacks, with disproportionately fewer studies examining sleep in Hispanic, Asian, and other racial/ethnic groups.

This study developed and validated a new population-based glycemic control Markov model to assess the benefits and harms of four common second-line antihyperglycemia treatment regimens for type 2 diabetes. The model, calibrated with US data, compared sulfonylurea, DPP-4 inhibitors, GLP-1 receptor agonists, and insulin against metformin monotherapy based on clinical effectiveness, quality of life, and cost.

This study developed and validated a single-lead sleep ECG-based AI model to predict the risk of incident atrial fibrillation (AF) using data from the Sleep Heart Health Study. The model demonstrated that ECG data from deeper sleep stages (N2 and N3) yielded better AF risk prediction compared to awake or REM sleep ECGs.

This single-center study investigated whether patients with positional obstructive sleep apnea (POSA), where apnea occurs predominantly in the supine position, have different future cardiovascular (CV) risk compared to non-positional OSA patients. A Cox proportional hazard model was used to assess the risk of new CV events in patients who underwent polysomnography.

This study analyzes trends in multiple sclerosis (MS) mortality by race and ethnicity in the United States using the CDC WONDER database. The research aims to identify disparities in MS-related deaths among different racial and ethnic groups.

This study used data from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) to examine whether "High-Risk" obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), characterized by high hypoxic burden or heart rate response, is linked to increased incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF). The analysis followed participants for a median of 6.8 years to ascertain new AF events.

This retrospective cohort study used Medicare data to assess racial and geographic disparities in antidiabetic medication discontinuation between non-Hispanic (NH) White and NH Black beneficiaries with type 2 diabetes. A multivariable Cox regression was used to examine the influence of race and location within or outside the Diabetes Belt on medication discontinuation.

This book presents methods for estimating the reliability of digital systems, with a focus on intermittent or transient faults. It provides techniques for analyzing the behavior of systems in the presence of such faults, for which generally applicable results were previously unavailable.

This work describes a method and system for securely enrolling personal identity credentials into electronic devices, involving a device manufacturer and a recognized enrollment authority. The manufacturer records a unique identifier and a self-generated public key for each device, while the authority validates the individual before enrollment.

This tutorial outlines the causes of faults in microprocessor-based systems and describes the basic techniques for achieving fault tolerance. It addresses how computers can fail and what can be done to deal with those failures.

This book describes a cooperative hardware/software codesign approach that utilizes a unified view of hardware and software to overcome limitations of traditional, separate development paths. It presents a unified representation, the decomposition graph, which can describe both hardware and software, enabling better exploration of tradeoffs.

This paper summarizes the D_RAMP safety analysis methodology and demonstrates its application for quantifying system safety in terms of Mean Time Between Hazardous Events (MTBHE). The D_RAMP toolkit is presented as a novel approach for concurrent verification and validation during the design of real-time computing systems.

This article presents a critical review of the literature on the reliability of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), covering both theoretical and practical research. It identifies failure causes and reliability challenges, and classifies methods for reliability modeling, analysis, and design of UAV systems.

This article defines gender allyship as the purposeful collaboration of men with women to promote gender equality through supportive relationships, sponsorship, and public advocacy. The authors' research suggests that men often perceive themselves as better allies than they actually are.

This chapter presents the application of object-oriented techniques to the modeling and design of hardware for embedded systems, illustrating a cross-fertilization of ideas from the software domain. It shows how data decomposition can be applied recursively to hardware components, supporting complexity management and refinement through a representation called the component-object graph.

This invention is directed towards methods, systems, and apparatuses for providing secure and private electronic interactions and transactions. The system provides identity verification of an initiating party and includes a self-destruct mechanism, limiting the transfer of personal data to only what is necessary for the transaction.

This review surveys both specialized and widely expressed mechanosensitive systems, suggesting that physical forces provide a general means of altering protein conformation to generate signals. It argues that essentially all organisms are mechanosensitive and that physical forces regulate a large array of physiological processes.

This study directly demonstrates the rapid deformation of the vimentin intermediate filament network in living endothelial cells subjected to hemodynamic shear stress. Using time-lapse optical sectioning and deconvolution microscopy, the research shows significant displacement of the filament network within the first three minutes after the onset of flow.

This study used gene targeting to generate SM22α-deficient mice to examine the function of this smooth muscle cell (SMC) lineage-restricted protein. The analysis revealed unanticipated insights into SMC differentiation and function, including the temporal and spatial pattern of SM22α transcriptional activation during development.

This paper discusses the crucial role of the endothelial cytoskeleton in mechanotransduction of hemodynamic shear stress, a key regulator of vascular physiology and pathology. It summarizes recent studies of four-dimensional cytoskeletal motion and strain distribution in living cells, supporting a decentralized model of endothelial mechanotransduction.

This study performed a spatiotemporal analysis of flow-induced intermediate filament (IF) displacement in living endothelial cells expressing green fluorescent protein-vimentin. By analyzing time-lapse microscopy images, the research quantified the magnitude and direction of IF network displacement, revealing a rapid, heterogeneous, and primarily downstream deformation in response to shear stress.

This paper, based on workshops from the 2024 Biomedical Engineering (BME) Education Summit, proposes an “Engineering for All” framework to integrate diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) into BME education. The framework outlines strategies for lowering systemic barriers and creating an equitable and inclusive educational environment to support student learning and professional development.

This work-in-progress paper reports on a novel, one-credit, peer-taught course titled “Starting an Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE)” designed to lower barriers to entry into undergraduate research for first-year engineering students. The course combines peer-led instruction and specifications grading to increase students' confidence, guidance, and sense of belonging in research environments.

This article is a correction to a previously published paper titled "Lowering Barriers to Entry in Undergraduate Research Through Student-Led Virtual Workshops." It clarifies that the conflict of interest statement was incomplete and should have noted that author Brian Helmke is the Deputy Editor-in-Chief of the journal.

This paper describes the design and implementation of Starting an Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE), a novel extracurricular workshop series aimed at lowering barriers for engineering students to gain research experiences. The student-led program, developed in fall 2020, provided guidance and small-group mentorship to over 150 students to address challenges like limited guidance and feelings of inadequacy.

This paper considers the optimization of point-to-point data transmission for an energy harvesting transmitter with a limited battery, aiming to maximize throughput by a deadline or minimize transmission completion time. The authors develop optimal offline policies using a directional water-filling algorithm and propose online policies based on stochastic dynamic programming.

This paper studies the optimal packet scheduling problem for a single-user wireless system where both data packets and harvested energy arrive randomly. The goal is to develop offline scheduling policies that adapt the transmission rate to minimize the time by which all packets are delivered, considering scenarios with and without packet arrivals during transmission.

This paper designs optimal online status update policies for an energy harvesting sensor to minimize the long-term average Age of Information (AoI) at a destination. The study considers three battery size scenarios (infinite, finite, and one unit), proposing a best-effort uniform policy for the infinite case and an energy-aware adaptive policy for the finite case.

This paper investigates the transmission completion time minimization problem for an energy harvesting transmitter in a two-user AWGN broadcast channel. The authors analyze the structural properties of the optimal transmission policy, proving that the optimal total transmit power sequence has a structure similar to the single-user case.

This paper introduces the concept of energy cooperation, where one energy harvesting user wirelessly transmits energy to another to shape energy arrivals and improve overall system performance. The authors determine optimal energy management policies that maximize throughput for relay, two-way, and multiple access channels with energy harvesting and transfer capabilities.

This paper studies the problem of robust offline reinforcement learning for non-Markovian decision processes where the nominal model has a low-rank structure. The authors propose a new algorithm featuring novel dataset distillation and a lower confidence bound design, and derive new dual forms for robust values to make the algorithm more practical.

This paper proposes DEcision Feedback IN-ContExt Detection (DEFINED), a new wireless receiver design that performs direct symbol detection using limited pilot data through in-context learning. The key innovation is a decision feedback mechanism where sequentially detected symbols are incorporated into the prompts to improve detections for subsequent symbols.

This paper presents a unified algorithm and analysis for a hybrid reinforcement learning framework where an agent leverages both an offline dataset and online interactions. The results show that augmenting confidence-based online RL algorithms with offline data achieves state-of-the-art results in both sub-optimality gap and online regret minimization.

This work theoretically analyzes the training dynamics of a one-layer transformer learning regular language recognition tasks, specifically 'even pairs' and 'parity check'. The analysis reveals that the joint training of attention and linear layers exhibits two distinct phases, with the attention layer first growing rapidly and the linear layer later converging towards a max-margin solution.

This paper presents a numerical investigation of Casson nanofluid flow, heat transfer, and entropy generation over a horizontal porous stretching surface. The study uses a finite difference scheme to solve the governing equations, which include effects of Lorentz forces and the Cattaneo-Christov heat flux model, for both Cu-H2O and TiO2-H2O nanofluids.

This paper presents a simplified mathematical model for solar thermal collectors, treating them as a non-uniform unsteady stretching surface with a non-Newtonian Maxwell fluid as the working fluid. The model incorporates a uniform magnetic field, slip boundary conditions, thermal radiation, and variable thermal conductivity to analyze the flow and heat transfer characteristics.

This study investigates the behavior of a spherical cavity in a soft biological tissue, modeled as a deformable porous material, during the injection of a non-Newtonian power law fluid. Numerical solutions indicate that shear thickening fluids exhibit less fluid pressure and induce smaller solid deformation compared to shear thinning fluids, while tissue absorption increases for all power law fluids.

This paper investigates the influence of Joule and viscous dissipation on the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) boundary layer flow over a stretching sheet with variable thickness and surface temperature. The governing equations are solved numerically using a shooting method to analyze the impact of physical parameters like the power index and magnetic parameter on velocity and temperature profiles.

This paper analyzes the capillary rise dynamics of a magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) fluid flowing through a deformable porous material, including gravity effects, using a mixture theory approach. Numerical solutions show that the capillary rise process for an MHD fluid slows down compared to a Newtonian fluid due to the Lorentz force.

This paper investigates the radial flow of a non-Newtonian power-law fluid through a poroelastic cylinder with moving boundaries, a problem relevant to applications like fluid flow through arteries and oil extraction. A general one-dimensional nonlinear diffusion equation for dilatation is derived and solved for both constrained and unconstrained cylinder cases.

This study presents an analytical investigation of the inertial flow of a viscous fluid near the corner of two intersecting walls with leakage, where one wall moves parallel to itself. An approximate solution is obtained by applying a recursive approach, yielding expressions for stream functions, velocity fields, and stresses up to the second approximation.

This study applies oxidation-sensitive nanoscale polymersomes for the co-delivery of antigen and adjuvant to dendritic cell (DC) endosomes to elicit cell-mediated immunity. The polymersomes, loaded with a Toll-like receptor agonist, successfully activated DCs and, when co-delivering antigen, induced antigen-specific T cell proliferation and cytokine production.

This study uses rational engineering to construct polymer nanocarriers that encapsulate a Toll-like receptor (TLR) 8 agonist for selective uptake and intracellular release by dendritic cells (DCs). These nanoparticles were shown to mimic the immunomodulating effects of the live BCG vaccine and enhance both innate and adaptive immune responses in newborns.

This study compares the T cell immune responses induced by ovalbumin (OVA) antigen delivered via two different nanocarrier morphologies: watery-core polymersomes (PSs) and solid-core nanoparticles (NPs). The results show that antigen-loaded PSs induced enhanced frequencies of both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, while antigen-conjugated NPs primarily induced CD8+ T cell responses.

This study reports that nanostructure morphology alone can be engineered for selective uptake by dendritic cells (DCs), which are critical mediators of atherosclerotic inflammation. Using a multimodal imaging approach, the research found that filamentous nanostructures (filomicelles) exhibited significantly enhanced targeting of DCs in atherosclerotic plaques compared to spherical nanoparticles.

This paper presents flash nanoprecipitation (FNP) as a single, customizable method for the rapid and scalable assembly of various soft nanoarchitectures, including polymersomes, from block copolymers. The study demonstrates that multiple impingements during the FNP process can decrease vesicle diameter and polydispersity, enabling gram-scale fabrication of monodisperse theranostic polymersomes.

This study investigates the role of autophagy in the activation and immunogenicity of microvascular endothelial cells (ECs) during cold storage and ischemia-reperfusion injury in heart transplantation. Using genetic and pharmacological modulation, the research found that inhibiting autophagy in ECs reduced their activation and subsequent T cell-mediated alloimmune responses.

This work describes flash nanoprecipitation methods for the facile assembly of soft nanoarchitectures and the co-loading of both hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules. The techniques enable the encapsulation of various target molecules, including bioactive protein therapeutics, within amphiphilic copolymer nanocarriers.

This paper presents a composite hydrogel (C-gel) embedded with filomicelles that enables localized in situ gelation and sustained nanocarrier release within the anterior chamber of the eye. The filamentous structure of the filomicelles confines crosslinking reactions, promoting efficient gel formation and retention, while their oxidation-induced transition facilitates gradual nanocarrier release for over a month.

This paper reports a hierarchical hydrogel depot vaccine that enables ratiometric loading of a protein antigen and four distinct adjuvants using simple poly(propylene sulfone) homopolymers. This 5-component nanogel vaccine, capable of noncovalent anchoring to subcutaneous tissues, demonstrated enhanced humoral and cell-mediated immune responses in mice compared to standard single-adjuvant formulations.

This study develops a novel nanocarrier system to deliver the active tamoxifen metabolite, 4-OH-tamoxifen, specifically to the Schlemm’s canal (SC) endothelium for genetic studies in glaucoma research. This system, using poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(propylene sulfide) nanocarriers with a VEGF-C derived peptide, provides highly efficient, SC-specific gene deletion and eliminates systemic phenotypes in nonspecific Cre mouse strains.

This paper describes the design and construction of a research infrastructure created to support controlled experimentation with software testing and regression testing techniques. The infrastructure aims to address the high cost and difficulty of obtaining necessary components for such experiments, thereby facilitating progress and the generation of empirical data in the field.

This paper presents a family of empirical studies comparing various test case prioritization techniques aimed at increasing a test suite's rate of fault detection. The studies address questions about targeting specific modified versions, trade-offs between fine and coarse granularity, and the potential benefits of incorporating fault-proneness measures.

This paper investigates test case prioritization techniques, which schedule test cases to increase their effectiveness in meeting performance goals like improving the rate of fault detection. The studies address whether prioritization can be effective for specific modified versions, the tradeoffs between different granularities, and if incorporating fault-proneness measures improves effectiveness.

This paper presents a new metric, APFDc, for assessing the rate of fault detection of prioritized test cases that incorporates varying test case costs and fault severities. A case study illustrating the application of the metric is presented, raising practical questions that may arise when applying such a metric.

This work presents algorithms to make regression testing in continuous integration development environments more cost-effective. The approach uses regression test selection techniques in a pre-submit phase to choose a subset of tests, and test case prioritization in a post-submit phase to provide faster feedback on test failures.

This paper proposes T4PC, a framework designed to increase the conformance of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) to specified properties during the training process, rather than after. T4PC achieves this by enriching the data preparation phase to account for property preconditions and the training phase to account for property satisfaction.

This paper introduces Defects4DeepNav, a growing catalog of over 100 failures from a deep learning-enabled commercial robotic navigation system operating in the real world. The catalog, which includes diverse failures and full sensor data, serves as a key instrument to drive the evolution and assessment of program analysis techniques for robotic systems.

This paper revisits a 2015 study on developers' code search practices by conducting three new surveys with over 1,900 responses to see how practices have evolved over the last decade. The study explores whether the original observations about why, how often, and in what situations developers search for code have stood the test of time amid changes like new languages and AI tools.

This work introduces Scene Flow Specifications to overcome the limitations of scene graphs in expressing temporal safety properties for autonomous driving systems. The new specification language and its associated monitoring framework enable the encoding and runtime monitoring of rich temporal properties, such as right-of-way at intersections.

This paper investigates the use of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to monitor safety properties for autonomous driving systems by extracting spatial relationships from real images, bridging the semantic gap between high-level properties and raw sensor data. To facilitate this, the authors created DriST, a dataset of road-scene images with extracted spatial triplets, and evaluated VLM performance on this new task.

This paper describes Recon 2, a community-driven consensus model that provides the most comprehensive reconstruction of human metabolism for computational analysis. The model was validated by accurately predicting biomarkers for inborn errors of metabolism and has been used to generate a compendium of cell type-specific models.

This review examines the major applications of genome-scale metabolic reconstructions, including contextualizing high-throughput data, guiding metabolic engineering, directing hypothesis-driven discovery, interrogating multi-species relationships, and discovering network properties. It also highlights trends and future directions in the field that will have a broad impact on biology.

This review discusses the reconstruction of large-scale cellular signalling networks, enabled by advances in high-throughput technologies over the past 20 years. It emphasizes the need to describe the properties of these carefully reconstructed networks within an integrative and quantitative modeling framework that accounts for their complexity.

This paper reviews the constraints-based approach for creating and analyzing genome-scale microbial in silico models, which are reconstructed from genome sequencing and annotation. It highlights that such models have successfully predicted substrate preference, gene deletion consequences, and optimal growth patterns with a high degree of accuracy.

This paper reports on MEMOTE, a community-developed, standardized test suite for assessing the quality of genome-scale metabolic models (GEMs). MEMOTE aims to address the lack of quality control and issues like incompatible formats and missing annotations that limit the reuse and interoperability of GEMs.

This commentary reframes the discussion around the "objective function" in metabolic network modeling to enhance its value and clarify common misunderstandings. It argues for placing the objective function in its proper context to better drive deeper understanding of cellular metabolism.

This study uses genome-scale metabolic network reconstructions (GENREs) to analyze metagenomic data from vaginal swabs and predict metabolic interactions associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV). In silico simulations and co-culture experiments revealed functional metabolic relationships between BV-associated species that are distinct from their genetic relatedness.

This work provides fecal biomarkers for diagnosing and assessing the risk of parenteral nutrition-associated cholestasis (PNAC) in subjects, particularly infants. The methods enable early identification of high-risk infants, allowing clinicians to optimize nutrition and proactively mitigate PNAC development.

This research compares parametric seasonal ARIMA models with nonparametric regression models for single point, short-term traffic flow forecasting. The study finds that refined nonparametric regression models can deliver statistically superior results compared to seasonal ARIMA models, motivating further investigation into data-driven approaches.

This research developed and tested four models—historical average, time-series, neural network, and nonparametric regression—for forecasting freeway traffic flow 15 minutes into the future. The nonparametric regression model significantly outperformed the other models, experiencing statistically lower errors in tests on two sites in Northern Virginia.

This paper explores the use of a neural network approach for short-term traffic flow prediction. The research aims to develop a model capable of accurately forecasting traffic conditions in the near future.

This paper presents the predictive microscopic simulation algorithm, a new, decentralized, fully adaptive traffic control algorithm that uses data from connected vehicles. The algorithm employs a rolling-horizon strategy to choose signal phasing that optimizes an objective function of delay, stops, and queue length over a 15-second future period.

This book explores the concept of divine war in the Old Testament and compares it to similar concepts in the broader ancient Near East. The work is part of a series covering all areas of Old Testament research, including the Hebrew Bible and its connections to neighboring cultures.

This study investigates the role of dermal fibroblast-derived thrombospondin 2 in extracellular matrix organization and wound healing, particularly in chronic diabetic and leprosy-related foot ulcers. The research compares Platelet-Rich Plasma (PRP) therapy with conventional treatment, assessing wound healing through various clinical and laboratory parameters.

This research presents a case study using virtual reality (VR) simulation to evaluate pedestrian behavior and safety with three different mid-block crossing treatments. The study demonstrates how immersive virtual environments can be used as a proactive, low-risk platform to compare design alternatives and ITS technologies before real-world implementation.

This invention describes an immersive digital experience for video conferencing that simulates the common presence of a remote participant in a local environment. The system may use a transparent media display to project the participant's image, place a camera behind the display at gaze level, and add virtual overlays to enhance the sense of depth.

This paper develops a prototype real-time monitoring system for a V2I-based connected and automated vehicle (CAV) system to detect cyberattacks and ensure resilient operation. The system uses a long-short term memory (LSTM) neural network to detect deviations from normal CAV operation and trigger countermeasures to revert the system to a safe state.

This invention describes a display construct that integrates media projection and wireless charging capabilities. The technology aims to combine visual display functionalities with the convenience of wirelessly powering devices.

This survey provides a comparative overview of research progress on memristors, from their use as synaptic devices to their application in new computing systems. It classifies different memristor synaptic devices, analyzes their working mechanisms, and discusses the advantages of crossbar-based memristors for vector-matrix multiplication and in-memory computing.

This paper proposes ReTransformer, a ReRAM-based Processing-in-Memory (PIM) architecture designed to accelerate Transformer models for NLP applications. The architecture addresses the performance bottleneck of the scaled dot-product attention mechanism and proposes a fine-grained pipeline design to handle matrix multiplication and intermediate results efficiently.

This paper demonstrates a photonic generative network, implemented as part of a generative adversarial network (GAN), that harnesses inherent optoelectronic noises for computation. The network, which uses a photonic core of programmable phase-change memory cells, can generate handwritten digits and demonstrates resilience to noise through noise-aware training.

This paper proposes a multi-objective optimization framework for designing robust, area- and energy-efficient ReRAM-based hardware accelerators for DNN inferencing. The framework includes a stochastic-noise-aware training method (ReSNA) and an information-theoretic algorithm (CF-MESMO) to identify Pareto-optimal solutions that trade off accuracy, area, time, and energy.
