This survey paper provides an overview of compute-in-memory (CIM) architectures for accelerating large language model (LLM) inference, addressing the challenges of growing computational and memory demands. It reviews transformer-based models and various CIM designs, highlighting challenges, trends, and insights for using CIM to overcome the memory wall in modern AI systems.

This paper proposes Norm-Q, a normalized linear quantization approach for compressing probabilistic symbolic models like Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) used in neuro-symbolic applications. The method introduces a normalized quantization-aware expectation-maximization process during training, achieving high compression rates with minimal impact on performance, thereby reducing memory and bandwidth stress.

This paper proposes Titanus, a software-hardware co-design that efficiently compresses the key-value (KV) cache on-the-fly to accelerate large language model (LLM) inference. Titanus uses a cascade pruning-quantization method and a customized two-stage design space exploration framework to significantly improve energy efficiency and throughput compared to GPU and other accelerator designs.

This paper proposes AutoRAC, a framework that automates the co-optimization of recommender models and Processing-In-Memory (PIM) accelerator designs. AutoRAC formulates the problem as a combinatorial search over mixed-precision operations and uses a one-shot supernet to efficiently explore the vast design space, achieving significant speedups over state-of-the-art PIM accelerators.

This survey explores the intersection of neuromorphic computing and large-scale deep learning models like BERT and GPT, focusing on how neuromorphic principles can address their significant computational and energy challenges. It reviews neuromorphic models, learning methods, and hardware, while also examining the scalability limitations of current neuromorphic systems and identifying future directions.

This work optimizes system performance for compact Processing-in-Memory (PIM) designs, which face challenges when neural network weights exceed on-chip memory capacity. The authors propose a novel pipeline method and scheduling algorithm that maximizes weight reuse and mitigates pipeline bubbles, achieving significant improvements in throughput and energy efficiency for compact PIM chips.

This paper presents a systematic empirical study of experience replay in deep reinforcement learning, rethinking its utility and focusing on the underestimated importance of the memory buffer size. The study showcases that a large replay buffer can significantly hurt performance and proposes a simple O(1) method to remedy this negative influence.

This paper presents GradientDICE, a method for estimating the density ratio between the target policy's state distribution and the sampling distribution in off-policy reinforcement learning, which fixes problems in the state-of-the-art GenDICE. By using a different objective based on the Perron-Frobenius theorem, GradientDICE avoids the need for nonlinear parameterization and is provably convergent under linear function approximation.

This paper proposes a novel and efficient exploration method for distributional deep reinforcement learning that utilizes the estimated value distribution to model both parametric and intrinsic uncertainties. The method combines a decaying schedule to suppress intrinsic uncertainty with an exploration bonus from the upper quantiles of the learned distribution, achieving significant performance gains in Atari games and a driving simulator.

This paper reformulates the option framework as two parallel augmented MDPs, which allows any policy optimization algorithm to learn intra-option policies, termination conditions, and a master policy. Applying an actor-critic algorithm to this formulation yields the Double Actor-Critic (DAC) architecture, which outperforms its hierarchy-free counterpart in challenging robot simulation tasks.

This paper introduces mlpack 3, a fast and flexible machine learning library written in C++ with bindings for other languages like Python. The library is designed for scalability and efficiency, enabling researchers and practitioners to quickly prototype and develop solutions for large-scale data problems.

This paper extends the Robbins-Siegmund theorem for almost supermartingales where the zero-order term is not summable but square summable, a condition often not met in reinforcement learning (RL) applications. By introducing a mild assumption on the increments, the new results establish almost sure convergence to a bounded set and provide convergence rates, with applications shown for stochastic approximation and Q-learning.

This paper establishes the first convergence rates for the linear Temporal Difference (TD) learning algorithm when operating with arbitrary, potentially linearly dependent, features. To address the non-uniqueness of solutions, the authors develop a novel stochastic approximation result that provides convergence rates to the solution set rather than a single point.

This article argues that resilience management must go beyond traditional risk management to address the complexities of large, integrated systems and the uncertainties of future threats. It emphasizes the need for a new paradigm to handle challenges like climate change.

This paper presents the theory and methodology of the inoperability input-output model (IIM), which is based on Leontief’s economic model and characterizes interdependencies among infrastructure sectors. The IIM analyzes initial disruptions and their ripple effects, and a dynamic extension analyzes recovery over time to help prioritize critical sectors.

This paper contributes an eight-phase methodological framework for identifying, prioritizing, assessing, and managing risk scenarios for a large-scale system. The framework uses qualitative screening and hierarchical holographic modeling initially, followed by quantitative evaluation and ranking to manage a large number of potential risk scenarios.

This paper discusses case studies applying the inoperability input-output model (IIM) to assess the impacts of willful attacks, specifically high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) scenarios, on interdependent sectors. The studies use parametric and uncertainty analyses to assess initial disruption intensity, recovery characteristics, and the efficacy of economic loss reduction policies.

This paper examines the concept of the return period for extreme events under nonstationary conditions, such as those potentially caused by climate change. It explores how the definition of return period as the expected waiting time before failure can be adapted to account for changing probabilities of events like floods and droughts.

This chapter describes principles and methods from operations research and systems engineering that support the enterprise risk management of electronics and computing device supply chains. It covers the risk management process, from identifying hazards like counterfeiting to quantifying risks and designing countermeasures, which is critical for ensuring component security and reliability.

This chapter discusses the complexity of managing semiconductor supply chains, which involve numerous steps, resources, and stakeholders from design to distribution. It advocates for a systems engineering perspective to manage the intricate processes and multiple interests inherent in the industry across different time horizons.

This chapter addresses the vulnerabilities of supply chains, particularly those for electronic hardware in cyber-physical systems, with a focus on resilience to counterfeiting and other disruptions. It discusses metrics for cyber resilience, reviews research on emerging topics, and emphasizes the need for strategies that go beyond traditional risk assessment to ensure robustness and adaptability.

This perspective reports on the evaluation of two experimental AI systems designed to assist authors and reviewers in the scientific peer-review process for risk science manuscripts. The study explores whether AI tools can provide useful feedback, improve manuscript quality, and avoid the biases of human reviewers, or if they might instead add noise and erode trust.

This paper uses a case study on biofuel distribution to Dulles International Airport to demonstrate a systems engineering-based supply chain analysis, covering stakeholder mapping, scenario evaluations, and resilience analysis. It introduces the Engagement, Financing, and Time Horizon Analysis (EFHA) matrix to support stakeholder negotiations for complex energy and fuel supply chains.

This study demonstrates that the cell injection process itself causes significant acute loss of cell viability due to mechanical membrane disruption at clinically relevant rates. As a protective strategy, the research shows that encapsulating various cell types within alginate hydrogels of specific mechanical properties significantly improves their viability during injection.

This study investigates how 3D hydrogel properties affect the maintenance of neural progenitor cell (NPC) stemness, finding that hydrogel degradation is necessary for this process. The requirement for degradation was independent of stiffness or adhesive ligand presentation and relied on matrix remodeling to facilitate cadherin-mediated cell-cell contact and β-catenin signaling.

This paper reports a new class of short, five-residue peptides that self-assemble into nanofiber hydrogels suitable for neural tissue engineering. The study characterizes how sequence variations, pH, and concentration alter the mechanical properties of these stimuli-responsive hydrogels, which exhibit shear-thinning and rapid self-healing.

This review aims to provide neuroscientists with basic information about hydrogels and their use as cell and drug delivery devices for neural tissue applications. It illustrates the many tunable properties of hydrogels and emphasizes their importance in obtaining reliable results for treating a broad range of neurological disorders.

This study uses engineered elastin-like protein (ELP) hydrogels with modular bioactive and structural regions to systematically investigate the effects of cell-adhesive ligand density and hydrogel stiffness on neurite growth in 3D. The results show that both increasing RGD ligand density and decreasing hydrogel stiffness independently promote neurite outgrowth from dorsal root ganglia.

This research focuses on developing in vitro tissue models to study neural cell development, with a specific emphasis on the processes of myelination and remyelination. The goal is to create better experimental systems for understanding the complex interactions that lead to the formation of myelin sheaths around axons.

This study aims to elucidate how oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) respond to the mechanical forces associated with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI). Using a 3D hydrogel model, the research investigates how high-rate mechano-stimulation alters the proliferation- and maturation-related signaling of OPCs, a promising therapeutic target for post-injury repair.

This study introduces a 3D hyaluronic acid (HA) hydrogel system containing encapsulated electrospun HA fibers to guide oligodendrocyte progenitor cell (OPC) maturation. The research investigates the effects of fiber presence and hydrogel stiffness on OPC proliferation, metabolic activity, and morphological changes to better model myelination.

This study combines simulations and experiments to investigate how the presentation of cell-adhesive ligands affects the supramolecular assembly and gelation of pentapeptide hydrogels. The research aims to decouple the effects of biomechanics and cell-matrix interactions in 3D environments to better understand their impact on neural lineages.

This book describes the origin, use, and limitations of electrochemical methods in corrosion science, including phase diagrams, testing schemes, and characterization of passivity. It offers practical guidelines for assessing active, passive, and localized corrosion, as well as methods for process alteration and materials selection.

This study conducted simultaneous electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, hydrogen gas collection, and mass-loss measurements during the corrosion of pure magnesium in NaCl solutions. The results show that the polarization resistance determined from impedance data, when accounting for a low-frequency inductive response, provides excellent correlation with corrosion rates measured by mass loss and hydrogen evolution.

This manual serves as a source book on corrosion tests and standards, providing guidelines for recognizing corrosion types and understanding testing fundamentals. The second edition has been revised and updated to include the most recent technologies, offering tools for making calculations, interpretations, and correlations in corrosion science.

This article reviews the influence of alloying on the corrosion of magnesium (Mg) alloys, with a particular focus on the underlying electrochemical kinetics that dictate the corrosion rate. It provides a holistic and in-depth analysis of the chemistry-corrosion link, which is crucial as the use of Mg alloys in transport and electronics continues to grow.

This book is a collection of twenty-seven papers on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, grouped into six categories covering corrosion process characterization, data validation, inhibition, and corrosion of specific materials like aluminum and steel. The topics include applications of Kramers-Kronig transformations and the evaluation of coatings on metal substrates.

This study evaluates the effects of cold-rolling and irradiation on the corrosion resistance of Ni-Cr alloys when exposed to molten FLiNaK salt. The research aims to understand how these processing methods impact the material's performance in high-temperature, corrosive environments relevant to advanced nuclear reactors.

This study investigates the effect of temperature on the dealloying behavior of a binary Ni-20Cr alloy immersed in molten FLiNaK salt. The research aims to understand how elevated temperatures influence the selective corrosion process in this high-temperature molten salt environment.

This research investigates the role of adding a third element to Fe-Co-Ni-Cr-Al compositionally complex alloys and conventional ternary alloys on their aqueous passivation behavior. The study aims to understand how these alloying additions influence the formation and stability of passive films in corrosive environments.

This study investigated the synergistic effects of Al on Cr passivation in a family of single-phase FeCoNi-Cr-Al compositionally complex alloys (CCAs) in chloride-containing sulfuric acid. Results showed that CCAs with both Cr and small amounts of Al achieved excellent passivation and resistance to pitting corrosion, outperforming alloys with only Cr and even 304L stainless steel.

This study revisits the influence of Sn alloying additions on the aqueous passivation of Cu-Al alloys, revealing a new third element effect that enables stainless steel-like corrosion behavior. Using electrochemical and spectroscopic techniques, the research shows that small Sn additions to Cu-Al alloys with sufficient Al content lead to the formation of a protective, Al-oxide-rich passive film.

This paper addresses the application of seasonal time series models, specifically seasonal ARIMA and Winters exponential smoothing, to the problem of single-interval traffic flow forecasting on urban freeways. The models were developed and tested on data from two sites on the Capital Beltway, with the results showing that seasonal models provided a better fit than those used in prior research.

This paper presents a preliminary investigation into predicting criminal incidents, specifically hit-and-runs, using events extracted from Twitter posts. The approach combines automatic semantic analysis of tweets with latent Dirichlet allocation and linear modeling, demonstrating that the model outperforms a uniform baseline.

This paper describes the SmartHouse project, which uses a system of basic sensors for remote, in-home monitoring of an elder's activities to support independent living. The study examined whether mixture models could be used to detect behavioral patterns from the sensor data, with results evaluated against a log of events kept by the occupant.

This study used a threat assessment with expert-elicited estimates to quantify the relative impact of various stage-specific threats on the population growth rate of the wood turtle. The results indicated that predators had the largest effect on hatchling and juvenile survival, while road mortality had the largest effect on adult survival.

This paper develops a multi-dimensional framework to systematically examine how characteristics of both the input image and the accompanying prompt affect the performance and biases of Vision Language Models (VLMs). Using open-source VLMs, the research explores how attention values fluctuate with varying input parameters to understand and characterize changes in VLM behavior.

This paper introduces MisstepMath, a novel semi-synthetic dataset of 12,000 categorized student mistakes in mathematics, paired with instructional teacher responses, designed to enhance AI-driven teacher training. Developed through expert brainstorming, AI-assisted generation, and expert refinement, the dataset provides diverse and contextually rich simulations of student errors from Kindergarten to Grade 8.

This paper describes the creation of a balanced COVID-positive cohort from the National COVID Cohort Collaborative (N3C) database to evaluate whether a documented Long COVID diagnosis is associated with decreased survival length. A Bayesian survival analysis was conducted on the cohort, which was balanced by the presence or absence of the ICD-10-CM code for Long COVID.

This study applied logistic regression, random forest, and XGBoost models to predict treatment outcomes for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) using data from cohorts in Tanzania, Bangladesh, and Siberia. The models were trained on data stratified by treatment regimen to identify individuals at higher risk of treatment failure in low- and middle-income contexts.

This work reports on the atomic structure, electronic properties, and vibrational modes of few-layered PdSe2, a pentagonal 2D layered noble transition metal dichalcogenide that is stable in air. Micro-absorption spectroscopy and first-principles calculations reveal a wide band gap variation from 0 eV in bulk to 1.3 eV in a monolayer, and field-effect transistors demonstrate its potential for electronic applications.

This paper reviews the progress and future prospects of spin-transfer torque random access memory (STT-RAM), a potentially universal memory technology. It discusses the performance requirements for the core magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) element and reports on progress in device design, material improvement, and CMOS integration for a demonstration test chip.

This paper describes a rigorous and computationally simple method for calculating the conductance of molecular conductors by combining quantum chemistry methods with a nonequilibrium Green’s function formalism. The approach uses self-energy matrices to partition the structure and is used to demonstrate the transition from metallic conduction in a gold nanowire to resonant conduction in a phenyl dithiol molecule.

This paper presents first-principles density functional calculations of the electronic structure, magnetism, and structural stability of 378 XYZ half-Heusler compounds. The study finds that a "Slater-Pauling gap" in the density of states is a common feature that contributes significantly to the stability of these compounds, many of which are predicted to be half-metallic ferromagnets.

This study uses transverse magnetic focusing to probe the propagation of charge carriers across an electrostatically defined p-n junction in ballistic graphene. The results show agreement with the predicted Snell’s law for electrons, including the observation of both positive and negative refraction, paving the way for electron optics based on graphene junctions.

This work designs an economic model predictive control (EMPC) formulation for battery energy storage system (BESS) dispatch to manage monthly demand charges in microgrids with variable renewable energy. To overcome the need for an unrealistic full-month reference trajectory, the EMPC is designed for 24 to 48-hour horizons with a corresponding reference trajectory computed online at each time step.

This paper proposes an Economic Model Predictive Control (EMPC) formulation for optimal microgrid dispatch that does not require a-priori knowledge of an optimal steady state or periodic trajectory. The framework is proven to have an asymptotic average economic cost no worse than any other non-fixed reference trajectory, and realistic simulations demonstrate its effectiveness.

This article proposes a battery energy storage system (BESS) integration approach for unbalanced active distribution networks that considers both cycle and calendar aging of the battery. A mixed-integer linear programming problem is formulated to minimize investment, operation, and degradation costs while supporting the network, as tested on an IEEE 37 bus system.

This paper presents a physics-based approach to calculate the alloy scattering rate in Sb-based quaternary alloys for avalanche photodiodes (APDs). The method, which considers screened Coulomb interactions and band non-parabolicity, advances Monte Carlo simulations for more precise modeling and improved design of APDs.

This paper proposes a gel-on-brush model for airway mucus clearance, where a periciliary layer occupied by membrane-spanning mucins and mucopolysaccharides acts as a brush to separate the mucus layer from the epithelia. This model explains the stability of mucus clearance in health and its failure in airway diseases based on the relative osmotic moduli of the mucus and periciliary brush layers.

This paper describes the design and fabrication of a tough, self-healing hybrid polymer network by crosslinking randomly branched polymers that carry motifs for both reversible hydrogen bonds and permanent covalent crosslinks. Forcing these two immiscible bond types to mix at the molecular level results in a "dry" elastomer with a very high fracture energy and excellent self-healing capability.

This paper uses scaling theory to derive the time dependence of the mean-square displacement of a nonsticky nanoparticle moving in polymer solutions and melts. The analysis shows that particle motion transitions from ordinary diffusion to subdiffusion and back to diffusion depending on the particle size relative to the polymer correlation length and tube diameter.

This paper uses scaling theory to study a simple model of autonomic self-healing in unentangled polymer networks with reversible bonds. The analysis of reaction kinetics reveals that the recovery of material strength across a fractured interface occurs faster after a shorter waiting time between fracture and healing.

This study investigates mucin concentrations in cystic fibrosis (CF) airway secretions, finding that while immunologically based techniques show low concentrations, physical measurement techniques reveal hyperconcentration compared to normal secretions. This hyperconcentration, along with increased osmotic pressure, is consistent with a model where mucus stasis in CF is driven by compression of the periciliary layer.

This work explores the hybrid 3D printing of anisotropic bottlebrush polymer nanocomposites. The research aims to create materials with controlled structural anisotropy by combining advanced polymer synthesis with additive manufacturing techniques.

This document describes a method and system for all-aqueous printing of viscoelastic droplets into a receiving material. The process involves controlling the deposition flow velocity and nozzle detachment acceleration to form and position a captive viscoelastic droplet.

This paper presents the deterministic relationships among molecular architecture, mesoscopic conformation, and macroscopic properties of foldable bottlebrush polymers with incompatible side chains and backbones. A combination of scaling theory and experiments reveals that as side chain length increases, the backbone collapses into a globule, leading to a transition from a stretchable to a brittle material.

This disclosure describes an air-liquid-interface culture apparatus featuring a porous support coated with a polyacrylamide hydrogel layer. The hydrogel's mechanical properties are designed to mimic the extracellular matrix of the human airway, providing a more physiologically relevant environment for culturing epithelial cells.

This study benchmarks immersive virtual environments against physical built environments to better understand user-environment interactions for building design and exploration. The research aims to leverage technologies like virtual and augmented reality to revolutionize the architecture, engineering, and construction industry by improving design, construction, and operations.

This paper presents a new computer vision algorithm for recognizing single actions of earthmoving equipment from site video streams using spatio-temporal features and support vector machine classifiers. The method addresses challenges such as partial occlusion and variations in equipment scale and pose to improve the efficiency of construction performance analysis.

This paper analyzes trends in the adoption of virtual and augmented reality in the AEC industry through surveys of industry experts conducted a year apart. The findings demonstrate significant growth in AR/VR utilization from 2017 to 2018 and show that older generations are more confident about the future of these technologies.

This paper presents a systematic approach to collect end-user lighting preferences using immersive virtual environments (IVEs) and integrate this data with building performance simulation (BPS) tools. The study demonstrates how user preference data can be used to evaluate design alternatives with the objective of meeting user needs while reducing energy consumption.

This paper provides a structured literature review of how behavioral theories from various disciplines can explain occupant interactions with building systems. The review aims to provide an in-depth understanding of the drivers behind occupant behavior to inform the development of innovative approaches for reducing building energy consumption without impacting comfort.

This study investigates the adoption trends, challenges, and potential of Augmented and Virtual Reality (AR/VR) in the AEC-FM industry using surveys and interviews with over 200 experts. The findings reveal a shift from initial optimism to more tempered expectations, with recent growth in the industrial sector and a trend towards outsourcing AR/VR tasks.

This paper introduces the World-centric Diffusion Transformer (WcDT), a novel framework for autonomous driving trajectory generation that combines diffusion models and transformers. The approach preprocesses historical data into an "Agent Move Statement," encodes it into a latent space using DDPM, and then fuses it with map and traffic information using transformer-based encoders to generate realistic trajectories.

This study introduces a novel real-time ground obstacle detection system for e-scooters that integrates an RGB camera, a depth camera, and an IMU to enhance road hazard detection. A deep learning model powered by YOLO detects six categories of obstacles, and depth data is used to estimate proximity, achieving a high mean average precision of 0.827 in naturalistic riding conditions.

This paper proposes TiFL, a Tier-based Federated Learning System that addresses client heterogeneity by dividing clients into tiers based on their training performance. TiFL selects clients from the same tier in each training round to mitigate the straggler problem and employs an adaptive model synchronization strategy to handle non-IID data.

This paper presents FedAT, a high-performance and communication-efficient federated learning system that uses asynchronous tiers to address both the straggler problem and the communication bottleneck. FedAT groups clients into tiers and performs intra-tier synchronous and inter-tier asynchronous model updates, achieving faster convergence and higher accuracy than existing synchronous or asynchronous methods.

This paper presents FaaSNet, a system designed for scalable and fast provisioning of custom serverless container runtimes at Alibaba Cloud Function Compute. FaaSNet addresses the challenges of costly container provisioning and highly dynamic FaaS workloads to enable better control over OSes, versioning, and tooling.

This paper describes Wukong, a scalable and locality-enhanced framework for serverless parallel computing that executes complex, burst-parallel DAG jobs. Wukong uses decentralized scheduling across Lambda executors to enhance data locality, reduce network I/O, and improve cost-effectiveness, achieving near-ideal scalability and significantly faster execution times.

This survey systematically reviews a broad spectrum of techniques designed to enhance the resource efficiency of Large Language Models (LLMs), addressing challenges in computational, memory, energy, and financial consumption. It categorizes methods by their optimization focus and applicability across the LLM lifecycle, and presents standardized evaluation metrics to facilitate fair comparisons.

This paper presents MorphServe, a dynamic, workload-aware LLM serving framework that uses morphological adaptation to handle fluctuating workloads without compromising accuracy. MorphServe introduces two runtime mechanisms—quantized layer swapping and pressure-aware KV cache resizing—which significantly reduce SLO violations and improve latency compared to static approaches.

This paper presents ZenFlow, a new offloading framework for fine-tuning large language models that avoids GPU stalls by prioritizing important parameters and decoupling updates between the GPU and CPU. ZenFlow performs in-place updates of important gradients on the GPU while asynchronously offloading less important ones to the CPU, achieving up to a 5x end-to-end speedup.

This paper presents zLLM, a model storage reduction pipeline that unifies tensor-level deduplication and a novel lossless delta compression algorithm called BitX to address the massive storage consumption of fine-tuned LLMs. By synergizing deduplication and compression around LLM family clustering, zLLM reduces model storage by 49.5%, over 20% more than state-of-the-art designs.

This paper analyzes over three years of IPFS internal traffic to provide an accurate view of its evolving centralization, revealing a low data replication level and high content concentration in a few hosting providers. The study highlights the challenges of this centralization for data availability and the opportunities for better data management and cost savings through deduplication.

This paper introduces NotebookOS, a GPU-efficient notebook platform tailored for interactive deep learning training (IDLT) that uses replicated, Raft-synchronized notebook kernels distributed across GPU servers. By oversubscribing resources and allocating GPUs only during active cell execution, NotebookOS enables interactive training with minimal delay while saving significant GPU hours.

This paper proposes a methodology for prioritizing regression test cases by analyzing empirical software change records using singular value decomposition. The technique generates clusters of files that historically change together, which are then combined with test case information to create a prioritized list of tests for a new system modification.

This paper proposes a methodology for analyzing the impact of a new system modification by using singular value decomposition on historical software change records. The technique, which generates clusters of files that tend to change together, was shown to be effective in identifying impacted files in a post hoc case study of five open-source systems.

This paper presents the design and execution of a year-long Service Learning Practicum (SLP) capstone course for computer science seniors. In the course, student teams develop software for local nonprofit organizations, and the paper describes the course structure, challenges, and student perceptions.

This paper examines the state of empiricism in recent proceedings of the SIGCSE Technical Symposium to categorize the research and identify areas for increased rigor. The study found an increase in empirical work compared to prior investigations, but many papers still lack the detail needed for replication.

This panel discussion addresses the challenges of evaluating teaching-track faculty for promotion, as departments and universities often struggle to apply appropriate standards. The panelists, including both teaching-track and tenured faculty, will share experiences and discuss how to best evaluate these positions without resorting to watered-down tenure-track standards.

This birds-of-a-feather session is designed for teaching-track faculty in computer science to share their experiences, especially regarding challenges and lessons learned from pandemic teaching. It also provides an opportunity for schools considering such positions to gather information and for participants to celebrate their successes.

This paper presents an eight-year curriculum redesign effort in a computer science department that impacted almost every course. The systematic process involved collecting requirements from stakeholders, developing a compromise plan for seven new courses, and iterating on piloted courses based on feedback.

This paper reports on six years of experience running a year-long professional development and mentoring program for computing educators to train them in empirical research methods. The goal is to help instructors transition their educational innovations from anecdotal experience reports to empirical results that can be replicated by others.

This systematic literature review characterizes the reporting of empiricism in Computing Education Research (CER) literature to determine if published work contains the necessary content for replication, meta-analysis, and theory building. The study analyzes 1,351 papers from four top CER venues to assess the state of reporting norms in the community.

This article reviews electrochemical methods for detecting neurological drugs and neurotransmitters, with a focus on how nanomaterial-modified detection systems enhance sensitivity, selectivity, and versatility. It discusses how specific nano-sized modifiers influence electron transfer events and surveys electrodes based on carbon materials, metal nanoparticles, and conductive polymers.

This paper reports a competitive, wash-free electrochemical detection system for real-time monitoring of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) over a five-log concentration range. The system uses an aptamer-based recognition surface and a graphene-gold nanoparticle-modified signaling electrode to achieve a low detection limit in the picomolar range.

This paper reports on the photoelectrochemical stability of p-type cuprous oxide (Cu2O) films electrodeposited from an alkaline lactate solution onto Au substrates. The study found that while the initial photocurrent decayed, the film morphology changed from a dense structure to a more stable network of elongated crystals, attributed to the higher stability of {111} facets.

This work demonstrates the electrochemical detection of neuropeptides NPY and OXA at picomolar levels from subnanoliter samples by using electrokinetic preconcentration onto patterned graphene-modified electrodes in a nanochannel. The high sensitivity of the method, which avoids interferences from dopamine and ascorbic acid, makes it suitable for analyzing noninvasively collected biological samples like sweat.

This tutorial review presents a comparative survey of approaches for elucidating cellular and subcellular features from microfluidic impedance cytometry data. It covers device design, data analytics (including signal processing and dielectric modeling), and population clustering to enable multiparametric cell characterization and subpopulation distinction.

This work describes a microfluidic system that uses impedance cytometry to quantify apoptotic bodies (ABs) with single-cell sensitivity, providing real-time information on cellular disassembly. By measuring electrical impedance magnitude and phase parameters, the system can distinguish subpopulations of ABs to assess the drug sensitivity of cancer cells.

This study utilizes single-cell biophysical cytometry under tunable viscoelastic extensional flows to correlate the nuclear phenotypes of T-cell lymphoma cells with their deformability characteristics. By coupling impedance, deformability, and recovery dynamics, the research provides insights into how nuclear size, shape, and protein expression affect cell mechanics and migration potential.

This article describes a modular microfluidic platform for controlled nanoconfinement over a large area, using an elastomeric diaphragm with integrated strain sensors and microfabricated posts. The device enhances biomolecular binding by alternating between confinement and bulk transport, demonstrating rapid DNA immobilization and screening of aptamers.

This work describes a method for inline classification of biological specimens, such as mammalian cells, using impedance cytometry. A model specimen class is used to determine an impedance parameter value indicative of a specified biophysical characteristic, which can then be used for classification.

This paper demonstrates the on-chip integration of impedance cytometry for the inline optimization of dielectrophoretic cell separations based on multiple biophysical metrics. The integrated system overcomes the limitations of traditional endpoint assays by providing label-free, real-time quantification of separated cell fractions, enabling their use in downstream studies.

This article suggests using selected science fiction stories in the engineering ethics classroom to teach students about the societal and ethical implications of nanotechnology. This approach provides students with the ethical skills and cultural knowledge needed to engage in public debates and make responsible decisions about futuristic technologies.

This book, "Nanotalk," presents a series of conversations and explorations with thirty-five nano-research scientists and engineers. In these discussions, the researchers share their ideas about the ethics, meaning, and beliefs surrounding the development of nanotechnology.

This article discusses the ethical challenges and social changes associated with nanotechnology, an emerging capability that has captured the attention of government, scientists, and the public. It argues for the conscientious development of this technology, which holds the potential for dramatic and unpredictable impacts on human existence.

This panel discussion explores the use of science fiction (SF) to engage students in computer science education, making connections between technical content and human experience. Panelists from a range of schools will present overviews of how they have used SF to engage students in technical topics as well as ethical and societal issues.

This article explores the use of intergenerational dialogue between undergraduate engineering students and senior citizens as a learning tool in a required engineering ethics course. The dialogue helps students appreciate and understand the practical and ethical meaning of technological change by learning from the lifetime experiences of seniors.

The book "Animals, Ethics, and Engineering: Intersections and Implications" is a seminal work exploring the intricate relationship between technology, ethics, and the welfare of nonhuman animals. Edited by Rosalyn W. Berne, the volume brings together leading scholars and practitioners to examine the ethical responsibilities inherent in technological progress and its impact on animal well-being.

This paper argues that engineering education has a critical role in addressing the sixth mass extinction by preparing engineers with a new ethical framework that dismantles the distinction between nature and technology. It submits that this new ethics must first challenge the rationalist worldview that separates humans from other animals and treats them as technologies for human use.

This lecture uses the pulse oximeter as a case study to discuss how race can become a matter of ethics in the design of biomedical devices. It highlights that despite early studies showing the device overestimates oxygen saturation in dark-skinned individuals, it remains unaltered, a disregard with significant implications during the COVID-19 pandemic.

This webinar, part of the ASEM DE/I series, features a talk by Professor Rosalyn W. Berne titled "Race Matters in Engineering and Technology." The discussion covers the role of values in technology development and how those values can be used to create more ethically designed technology.

This guide introduces hydrogels to researchers who may be unfamiliar with them, providing procedures for culturing and studying cells within these systems. With a focus on commercially available hydrogels, it aims to lower the knowledge barrier for scientists interested in using these materials to better recapitulate native cellular environments.

This study uses a hyaluronic acid hydrogel system to show that N-cadherin adhesive interactions modulate mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) mechanosensing and fate commitment. Decoupled presentation of N-cadherin and RGD motifs revealed that N-cadherin ligation reduces the cellular contractile state and nuclear YAP/TAZ localization, altering the interpretation of ECM stiffness.

This study investigates how culture dimensionality and microenvironmental factors like stiffness and degradability regulate the mechanosensitive signaling mediators YAP/TAZ in mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs). Using tunable hyaluronic acid hydrogels, the research found that MSCs showed increased YAP/TAZ nuclear localization on stiffer 2D hydrogels but the opposite trend when encapsulated in 3D.

This study uses analytical methods and Monte Carlo simulations to examine the dynamics of motor clutches between a cell and a viscoelastic substrate. The model predicts that for soft substrates, maximum cell spreading is achieved at an optimal viscosity where the substrate relaxation time is between the clutch binding timescale and its binding lifetime.

This study describes the development of an anisotropic collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffold with aligned ellipsoidal pores to mimic native tendon physiology for tissue engineering. The results show that equine tendon cells cultured in these scaffolds exhibited greater attachment, metabolic activity, and alignment compared to those in isotropic scaffolds.

This study investigates the influence of hydrogel stiffness and viscoelasticity on fibroblast senescence, both independently and in combination with genotoxic stress. The results reveal a unique role for soft viscoelastic substrates in promoting the onset and amplification of senescence, even without genotoxic stress, suggesting a role for nuclear organization in this phenotype.

This study investigates unintended norbornene homopolymerization in thiol-norbornene photoclick hydrogels, which can limit 3D cell spreading. The results show that norbornene conversion exceeds 1:1 thiol-ene expectations, and reducing the number of norbornenes per hyaluronic acid chain mitigates this homopolymerization, leading to hydrogels with greater stress relaxation.

This study uses tunable hyaluronic acid hydrogels to investigate how tissue mechanics and macrophage signaling combine to influence fibroblast activation, a driver of fibrotic disease. While fibroblast activation increased on stiff hydrogels, co-culture with M2 macrophages overrode these mechanical cues and increased activation even on soft hydrogels, an effect dependent on IL-6 signaling.

This study assessed the ability of aligned collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffolds to facilitate functional muscle recovery in a rat model of volumetric muscle loss (VML). After 12 weeks, muscles treated with either nonconductive or conductive scaffolds produced significantly greater maximum isometric torque than nontreated tissues, supporting the platform's potential for VML repair.

This study develops aligned collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffolds and systematically varies the GAG content by incorporating hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, or heparin to regulate myogenesis. Results show that heparin-modified collagen scaffolds significantly enhance myoblast metabolic activity, myogenic differentiation, and sequestration of insulin-like growth factor-1, highlighting their promise for skeletal muscle tissue engineering.

This review provides an update on the field of thermoelectrics, focusing on progress in understanding charge and heat carrier transport, strategies to improve the thermoelectric figure of merit, and new discussions on device physics. It assesses recent advances and remaining challenges, highlighting the significant role of first-principles calculations and the development of new experimental tools.

This paper reports the enhancement of the thermoelectric figure-of-merit (ZT) in silicon germanium alloy nanocomposites by using an alternative modulation-doping design. By using alloy Si70Ge30 as the nanoparticles and Si95Ge5 as the matrix, the design increases the power factor without increasing thermal conductivity, leading to a ZT of 1.3 at 900 °C.

This paper introduces and experimentally demonstrates the concept of modulation doping in three-dimensional nanostructured bulk materials to increase the thermoelectric power factor. By creating a two-phase composite of doped silicon nanograins and intrinsic silicon germanium grains, charge carriers are separated from their parent grains, resulting in enhanced mobility and higher electrical conductivity.

This review focuses on the thermoelectric power factor, a key parameter for determining the performance of thermoelectric materials. It discusses the fundamental mechanisms and various strategies that have been developed to enhance the power factor for achieving higher performance.

This paper presents a versatile bottom-up strategy to produce high-performance thermoelectric nanocomposites by assembling colloidal nanocrystals. In a PbS-Ag system, Ag nanodomains are shown to block phonon propagation and also provide electrons to the PbS host, resulting in reduced thermal conductivity and enhanced charge transport.

This issue of MRS Bulletin highlights key innovations in thermoelectricity, driven by a deeper understanding of physics, inventive material design, and progress in computational and experimental techniques. It covers topics from spin caloritronics to waste heat recovery, emphasizing the need for efficient, stable, and sustainable materials for a futuristic economy.

This paper presents a comprehensive investigation of the thermoelectric properties of 1T-TiSe2, focusing on the Thomson and Nernst effects around its charge density wave transition. The study reveals an exceptional peak in the Thomson coefficient and an unusual Nernst coefficient, highlighting the material's potential for developing practical Thomson coolers with extended operational ranges.

This study uses Raman scattering, infrared absorption, and X-ray techniques to investigate the complex chalcogenide CoPS3, which lies at the nexus of different structural and magnetic behaviors in its material family. The findings reveal a structural component to its magnetic ordering transition and a remarkable set of lower-temperature magnon-phonon pairs, pointing to strong spin-phonon entanglement.

This work identifies Ni-Fe as a promising metallic alloy for active cooling applications by using machine learning to screen a database of binary alloys for large Seebeck coefficients. Fabricated Ni-Fe ingots demonstrated high thermoelectric power factor values, making them attractive candidates composed of cost-effective and abundant elements.

This study investigates the temperature-dependent transport properties of FeRh thin films, observing a nonzero anomalous Hall effect (AHE) signal in the antiferromagnetic (AFM) phase that reverses its sign upon transitioning to the ferromagnetic phase. This observation, which contrasts with theoretical predictions, is attributed to an additional Hall conductivity contribution from the topological Hall effect.

This paper proposes a new finite-volume based approach for solving Saint Venant’s torsion problems for homogeneous and composite prismatic bars. The method uses a semi-inverse approach to construct an approximate displacement field within discretized subvolumes, enabling the analysis of bars with heterogeneous microstructures and orthotropic materials.

This paper extends a finite-volume method for Saint Venant’s torsion problems to enable the analysis of arbitrarily shaped cross sections with curved boundaries. This is achieved by incorporating parametric mapping based on transfinite grid generation, which allows the cross section to be discretized by quadrilateral subvolumes.

This work presents an integrated Application Programming Interface (API) based on finite-volume homogenization to analyze the mechanical response of composites with complex microstructures. The tool aims to provide an efficient method for predicting the effective properties of heterogeneous materials.

This paper presents an integrated homogenization engine that uses microgravity-driven microstructure generation to predict the properties of random unidirectional composites. The tool combines microstructure modeling with a homogenization technique to analyze the effective mechanical behavior of these materials.

This paper reports the development of a disposable, polyester-toner centrifugal microdevice for the semi-automated, dynamic solid-phase extraction (dSPE) of DNA from whole blood samples. The low-cost device integrates novel valving to allow sequential reagent addition, achieving a DNA extraction efficiency of ~45% and enabling successful multiplexed PCR amplification.

This paper describes the design and implementation of an autonomous quadcopter that uses commercial off-the-shelf technologies to independently explore and map an unknown area. The system integrates an Android smartphone, an Arduino microcontroller, and ultrasonic sensors to achieve autonomous navigation and mapping for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) applications.

This study thermally characterized thin-film silica aerogel films using the 3ω technique to determine their thermal conductivity. The results indicate that thin-film aerogel, deposited on SiO2 substrates, can maintain the ultra-low thermal conductivity commonly observed in bulk aerogel, making it a promising thermal insulator for microelectronic systems.

This paper presents the HCT Disc, an inexpensive centrifugal microdevice fabricated from polyester and toner, for measuring hematocrit from a single drop of blood. The device uses centrifugal force for blood metering and cell sedimentation, with analysis performed using a cell phone, showing good correlation with clinical laboratory values.

This study presents a rapid, low-cost method for detecting Clostridium difficile using a magnetic bead aggregation assay within an inexpensive polyester microfluidic device. The system uses centrifugal force for fluid control and a rotating magnetic field to manipulate beads, with detection and analysis performed in under an hour using a cell phone.

This work details the implementation of a fully enclosed bioreactor environment (FEBE) system that interfaces with automated bioprinting methods for manufacturing tissue-engineered muscle repair (TEMR) constructs. Implantation of these constructs, which consist of a porcine bladder matrix seeded with muscle progenitor cells, resulted in significant functional recovery in a rat model of volumetric muscle loss.

This disclosure relates to a bioreactor system that can be hermetically or aseptically sealed to protect against external contaminants during the artificial manufacturing of cells and tissues. The system uses cyclic motion to stimulate cell growth and maturation within the enclosed environment.

This invention provides an inexpensive, microcontroller-based bioreactor controller with a linear motor and a simple user interface. The controller offers greater temporal accuracy and allows a user to select and run protocol and setup modes for stimulating cell growth.

This work describes the development and evaluation of a Fully Enclosed Bioreactor Environment (FEBE) for the automated biofabrication of implantable Tissue Engineered Muscle Repair constructs. The system aims to improve the manufacturing process for these therapeutic tissues.
This invention describes a system for monitoring and maintaining separation between individuals or objects. The system is designed to help enforce social distancing or other spatial requirements.

This study developed a data-driven approach using mass cytometry and a new algorithm, PhenoGraph, to define phenotypes in high-dimensional single-cell data from acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients. This method revealed that leukemic blast surface phenotypes do not always reflect their intracellular state and identified a progenitor-like cell population that correlates with prognosis.

This paper describes a pharmacological approach to interrogate the PI3-K family by synthesizing and profiling a diverse panel of inhibitors, revealing cryptic homologies and a uniquely exploited mobile region in p110γ. Using this chemical array, the study defines p110α as the primary insulin-responsive PI3-K in cultured cells and in vivo.

This paper describes mass-tag cellular barcoding (MCB), a method that uses n metal ion tags to multiplex up to 2n samples for high-throughput mass cytometry analysis. The authors applied this technique to characterize human PBMC signaling dynamics, inhibitor effects, and donor-to-donor variability in a single multiplexed experiment.

This paper presents an optimized mass-tag cell barcoding (MCB) protocol that uses palladium-based labeling reagents to expand the number of available measurement channels in mass cytometry. The method includes an error-detecting barcoding scheme to identify and remove cell doublets and a single-cell-based deconvolution algorithm to improve accuracy.

This paper introduces PLAYR (proximity ligation assay for RNA), a method for highly multiplexed quantification of transcripts by flow and mass cytometry that is compatible with standard antibody staining. When used with mass cytometry, PLAYR allowed for the simultaneous quantification of more than 40 different mRNAs and proteins in single primary cells.

This study performed deep phenotyping of circulating B-cells in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and healthy controls using mass cytometry. The research identified an expansion of atypical CD11c+ B-cells in IPF, which was associated with elevated levels of IgA antibodies against oxidized cholesterol.

This study utilized time-resolved single-cell mass cytometry (CyTOF) to measure distinct signaling pathways activated in microglia upon exposure to bacterial and viral mimetics. The research also evaluated the immunomodulatory role of astrocytes on microglial signaling in mixed cultures to better understand neuroinflammatory responses.

This study uses single-cell mass cytometry (CyTOF) to characterize the cellular landscape of the developing mouse telencephalon in wild-type and knockout mice, revealing the roles of extrinsic apoptosis and necroptosis. The results show that combined deletion of RIPK3 and Caspase-8 leads to an increase in total cell count, challenging the notion that intrinsic apoptosis exclusively governs developmental cell elimination.

This study presents a single-cell mass cytometry-based atlas of the developing mouse brain, analyzing over 24 million cells with a 40-antibody panel from embryonic day 11.5 to postnatal day 4. The analysis identifies 85 molecularly distinct cell clusters, confirms canonical neurogenesis and gliogenesis pathways, and predicts two distinct trajectories for cortical oligodendrogenesis.

This article analyzes Mark Zuckerberg’s 2017 open letter, “Building Global Community,” as a political manifesto that outlines a future of ubiquitous social media and government in an era of surveillance capitalism. Using a critical framework, the article argues that the letter constitutes a coherent statement on the future of governance, evoking a social media-age version of Rousseau's "General Will."

This case study explores how the ambiguous status of San Diego taxi drivers as independent contractors shaped their work conditions and opportunities for resistance. While objectively disempowered, drivers leveraged their dual identity as both workers and entrepreneurs to build alliances and successfully campaign for reform.

This paper analyzes US congressional debates on encryption controls from 1993 to 1999 to investigate how privacy claims were used to legitimate government surveillance. The analysis reveals that a market liberalization discourse, which framed loosened encryption controls as a way to protect privacy in market transactions, dominated the debates.

This study, based on participant observation and interviews with civic technologists in the San Francisco Bay Area, argues that "Tech for Good" initiatives are structured by technologists' affective attachments to their careers. Participants engage in "repair work," repurposing civic technology organizations into idealized versions of their workplaces to work through feelings of disillusionment with the high-tech sector.

This study investigates how civic technology organizations, comprised of volunteers from the high-tech industry, work to design digital technologies for the common good in the San Francisco Bay Area. Drawing on participant observation and interviews, the research explores how these groups attempt to address local social problems through technology.

This chapter analyzes how race has shaped the development and regulation of encryption technologies by examining US congressional hearings from 1990 to 2016, known as the “Crypto Wars.” The analysis demonstrates how state and private actors mobilized racialized mythological constructions of criminals while negotiating how to regulate encryption, highlighting the need to center race in countersurveillance advocacy.

This article proposes and analyzes a topology-transparent broadcast protocol for vehicular networks that reliably delivers safety messages with better performance in terms of success probability and delay compared to existing protocols.

This paper presents two families of error-correcting codes designed to correct tandem duplication errors in data stored within the DNA of living organisms, with one family correcting any number of errors and the other correcting a bounded number.

This paper introduces translocation rank codes for flash memories to handle arbitrary charge-drop errors, deriving their asymptotic capacity and providing construction techniques for asymptotically good codes with simple decoding methods.

This paper investigates the capacity and expressiveness of generating a large number of sequences from a small initial seed using tandem duplications of bounded length, a process common in the human genome.

This paper investigates the capacity of four fundamental string-duplication systems, including those resembling genomic duplication, to determine their expressive power in constructing an exponentially large number of sequences from a short initial sequence.

This study designs constrained codes using de Bruijn graphs to mitigate the high error rate of nanopore-based DNA sequencing for data storage, finding that the novel codes significantly improve overall performance compared to unconstrained coding.
This paper constructs asymptotically optimal codes that can correct one substring edit error, where a substring is replaced by another of bounded length, achieving a redundancy of 2k log n.
This paper constructs linear list decodable codes that can correct k edits with a rate approaching 1-H(2k/n) and a reasonable list size, using an encoder and decoder that run in polynomial time.

This paper constructs almost optimal codes that correct one substring edit error with a redundancy of 2k log n + O(1) and also proposes a hash with an expected length of approximately 2k log n for the average-case document-exchange problem.

This paper introduces and constructs binary codes of length n that can correct a single k-substring edit error with a redundancy of O(k log n), showing that such codes are more efficient for synchronizing related documents than general indel/substitution-correcting codes.

This article argues for an alternative presentation slide design characterized by a succinct sentence headline supported by visual evidence, which is more effective for technical communication than the traditional bulleted list format.

This book retells the story of Mary Somerville, a leading 19th-century woman scientist, focusing on the cultural factors that enabled her to become an eminent figure and arguing for a rethinking of the history of women's participation in science.

This book presents various institutional and individual responses to the ABET/EC2000 accreditation criteria, showing paths forward for faculty to integrate liberal education topics like communication, ethics, and humanities into 21st-century engineering curricula.

This article argues that women writers on science and technology in the 18th and 19th centuries, often acting as mediators or "mediatrixes," performed essential tasks that clarified scientific knowledge and were crucial for the functioning of the scientific enterprise.

This paper proposes an alternative presentation slide design that uses a succinct sentence headline supported by visual evidence, arguing it is more effective for communicating engineering content than the traditional phrase headline/bullet list format, despite resistance from users accustomed to PowerPoint's defaults.

This paper draws on the scholarship of Fred Newton Scott to articulate a humanistic and functional view of engineering communication, arguing that it should be seen as an interdisciplinary area of specialization grounded in fundamental notions of human interaction.

This paper explores how the language used to discuss diversity, equity, inclusion, and social justice can inadvertently deter audiences outside the diversity community, and argues for using a conversational rhetorical mode and thematic framing to expand the audience.

This paper describes a systems approach to engineering ethics that integrates sociotechnical systems thinking, communication ability, and traditional ethics to situate ethical action within the organizational, cultural, and technical contexts of engineering practice.

This paper examines the life and work of Charles Riborg Mann, author of the influential 1918 report on engineering education, highlighting his integrative, systems-based approach and noting that many of his observations and recommendations remain relevant today.

This study demonstrates that the weak van der Waals potential of graphene does not completely screen the stronger potential field of an underlying substrate, enabling a phenomenon termed "remote epitaxy" that allows for epitaxial growth and facile layer release.

This paper demonstrates a novel solar cell design using kirigami to create an array of tilted surface elements from thin-film gallium arsenide, enabling integrated solar tracking with high mechanical robustness and optical efficiency comparable to conventional trackers.

This paper demonstrates a layer-resolved 2D material splitting technique that enables high-throughput production of multiple wafer-scale monolayers by splitting a single stack of thick 2D materials grown on one wafer.

This paper demonstrates a universal mechanical exfoliation method for producing freestanding, single-crystalline membranes from a wide range of complex-oxide materials, enabling their heterogeneous integration with semiconductor technologies and overcoming the limitations of substrate clamping.

This disclosure presents methods and growth structures for epitaxial lift-off of thin-film devices that use at least one superlattice layer as a wafer protection scheme to preserve wafer surface integrity and increase the number of times it can be reused for regrowth.

This paper presents a high-precision, single-shot technique using Fourier imaging microscopy to simultaneously quantify the refractive index and transition dipole moment orientation in morphologically non-uniform nanoscale emissive films.

This Perspective explores the key requirements for microdisplays in augmented and virtual reality headsets, considers the advantages of different light-engine technologies like LCoS, OLEDoS, and LEDoS, and discusses how their performance can be accurately characterized.

This study utilizes solution shearing to fabricate composite thin films of the metal-organic framework UiO-66 and the piezoelectric polymer P(VDF-TrFE), investigating how polymer concentration influences the film's crystallinity, surface coverage, and piezoelectric performance.

This paper presents EAS-CiM 2.0, an event-driven, asynchronous, stream-based Compute-in-Memory architecture that leverages Asynchronous Stream Computing to dynamically adapt computational precision and speed in response to workload demands and available energy resources.

This paper reviews the state-of-the-art applications of Artificial Intelligence in manufacturing, provides a systematic view for analyzing data and process dependencies, and identifies challenges and opportunities for leveraging AI to transform the manufacturing domain.

This research proposes a new data-driven method for detecting throughput bottlenecks in both the short and long term by utilizing production line blockage and starvation probabilities and buffer content records, without needing an analytical model.

This paper presents a deep learning method based on a recurrent neural network to parse visual observations of human actions and forecast the operator's future motion trajectory for online robot action planning in a human-robot collaborative assembly setting.

This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning-based approach to obtain an optimal preventive maintenance policy for serial production lines to improve cost efficiency. The algorithm, based on the Double Deep Q-Network, is proven effective in delivering a policy that increases throughput and reduces cost through simulation studies.

This paper develops a data-driven simulation methodology to automatically model a complex automobile general assembly plant and rapidly modify the model to respond to dynamic requirements and real-time information, enabling quick analysis and remodeling in response to demand fluctuations.

This paper presents a novel Hybrid Graph-Diffusion Based Planning Framework that integrates generative AI with system-theoretic modeling to autonomously generate optimal Flexible Smart Manufacturing System configurations based on different market demands.

This review paper provides a comprehensive synthesis of system-level modeling, analysis, and control methodologies in manufacturing, covering classical, simulation-based, and cutting-edge AI/ML approaches to guide future research toward improving modern manufacturing environments.

This paper presents a demand-driven hierarchical framework that integrates planning and scheduling for a mobile, multi-skilled, robot-operated Flexible Smart Manufacturing System to address the challenges of adapting to frequent demand fluctuations and managing system complexity.

This study explores whether pre-trained Large Language Models, specifically GPT-4, can function as out-of-the-box bottleneck detectors in manufacturing without domain-specific fine-tuning by evaluating three prompting techniques with increasing levels of domain knowledge.

This paper presents a scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning control framework for multi-stage manufacturing lines that enables training a small, characteristic 3-workstation model which can then generalize to production lines of any size.

This paper presents a novel response generation system using a neural network architecture trained end-to-end on unstructured Twitter conversations, which shows consistent gains over machine translation and information retrieval baselines by effectively incorporating contextual dialogue history.

This paper describes DyNet, an open-source toolkit for implementing neural network models that uses dynamic declaration of network structure, allowing for efficient and flexible implementation of complex architectures with speeds comparable to or faster than static declaration toolkits.

This paper presents two case studies on machine-in-the-loop creative writing for slogans and stories, finding that while participants found the process fun and helpful, the machine-suggested content did not necessarily lead to better written artifacts.

This paper presents a representation learning approach for text-level discourse parsing that jointly learns to parse discourse and a discourse-driven projection of surface features, resulting in a shift-reduce parser that achieves substantial improvements on the RST Treebank.

This paper shows that discourse analyses from Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST) parsers can improve document-level sentiment analysis by reweighting discourse units in a dependency representation or by using a recursive neural network over the RST structure.

This paper identifies "syntactic blind spots" in Large Language Models, a systematic failure mode where models misapply familiar reasoning to semantically straightforward but syntactically unfamiliar mathematical problems, and shows that rephrasing these problems often leads to correct answers.

This work introduces a theoretically grounded framework for optimizing latent dimension allocation in hierarchical variational autoencoders (HVAEs) for out-of-distribution detection, demonstrating that tuning the allocation ratio consistently improves performance across datasets and architectures.

This paper proposes CASE, a contrastive saliency estimation method that isolates features uniquely discriminative for a predicted class, addressing the finding that many widely used saliency methods are class-insensitive and produce nearly identical explanations regardless of the class label.

This study demonstrates the formation of a strain-driven morphotropic phase boundary in lead-free piezoelectric bismuth ferrite films, where a tetragonal-like phase can be reversibly converted into a rhombohedral-like phase with an electric field, yielding large electromechanical responses.

This paper reports a significant photovoltaic effect in ferroelectric BiFeO3 thin-film heterostructures, characterized by high open-circuit voltages of ~0.8-0.9 V and external quantum efficiencies up to ~10%, an order of magnitude larger than previously reported for ferroelectric-based devices.

This paper demonstrates the first all-dielectric metamaterial composite in the midinfrared, based on micron-sized, high-index tellurium dielectric resonators, which exhibits optical magnetism and is desirable for its low loss and angular invariance.

This study reports the growth of phase-pure, epitaxial BiFeO3 thin films on SrTiO3 substrates using molecular-beam epitaxy, and determines through spectroscopic ellipsometry that the material has a direct optical band gap of 2.74 eV.

This study reports the room temperature refractive index and absorption of ferroelectric antiferromagnet bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) using spectroscopic ellipsometry, finding a direct band gap at 2.81 eV, and determines its nonlinear optical coefficients using second harmonic generation.

This report presents a methodology for nanoscale phase and orientation identification in polymorphic materials by leveraging vector pair correlation functions extracted from atomically resolved scanning transmission electron microscopy images, demonstrating its accuracy on HfO2-based films.

This review discusses the use of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to characterize fluorite-structured ferroelectrics like hafnium oxide, highlighting recent advances in TEM techniques that have provided critical insights into their switching mechanisms and phase evolution, while also outlining persistent experimental challenges.

This study developed and characterized a reproducible rat model of cyclic ischemia-reperfusion injury in the skin to investigate its role in chronic pressure ulcer formation, finding that tissue injury increased with the number and duration of cycles.

This review examines the role of macrophages as key regulators in both angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, particularly in environments of tissue injury or pathology where their numbers are increased and their dynamic behaviors can influence vessel growth and remodeling.

This review highlights recently published multiscale computational models of biological systems, proposing best practices for future model development that involve coupling continuous and discrete systems to capture biological information across spatial, temporal, and functional scales.

This study demonstrates that circulating non-classical monocytes are directly recruited to polymer films within skin injuries and are biased progenitors of wound healing macrophages, highlighting their critical role in guiding the design of immunoregenerative materials.

This study shows that human adipose-derived stromal cells (ASCs) accelerate diabetic wound healing in mice, with cells delivered as multicellular aggregates showing a significantly greater therapeutic effect than those delivered in suspension due to enhanced secretion of pro-angiogenic factors.

This study uses single-nucleus RNA sequencing to identify sex- and brain region-specific alterations in pericyte-centered signaling programs in Alzheimer's Disease, revealing changes in TGFβ and estrogen pathways in female donors and a conserved inflammatory program in both sexes.
This study investigates pericyte-mediated capillary constriction in the hyperglycemic brain, finding similarities to the vascular dysfunction observed in Alzheimer's Disease.

This study developed a bioactive PEGDA hydrogel model with tunable stiffness to show that while healthy lung explants had decreased capillary sprouting on stiffer gels, fibrotic lung explants were not impacted by stiffness, a difference associated with higher angiogenic marker expression.

This paper provides a comprehensive protocol for using two-photon microscopy for serial imaging of neurovascular unit cell types like pericytes, astrocytes, and microglia to evaluate their changes throughout the progression of brain diseases.

This work leverages denoising diffusion probabilistic models to train a generative AI surrogate of a computationally expensive Cellular-Potts Model used to investigate in vitro vasculogenesis, enabling accelerated evaluation of the complex biological system.

This paper presents fast computational methods for Preisach-based magnetization models and their inverses, using a differential equation approach that is substantially faster than standard models and enables effective open-loop control of magnetic hysteresis.

This paper describes a method to integrate the fast, Preisach-based DOK magnetic hysteresis model into the ANSYS finite element program, showing that it provides an accurate representation of magnetization without affecting the convergence of the FE solution.

This paper presents a fast, Preisach-based magnetization model for highly magnetostrictive materials like Terfenol-D that accounts for prestress-induced anisotropy using a bimodal structure and discusses the necessity of strain feedback.

This paper addresses and suggests a correction for an orientation error in the simplified vector Preisach model, which incorrectly predicts a ratcheting motion for the magnetization of an isotropic medium under a smoothly rotating field.

This study measures the magnetic aftereffect in Co/Pt multilayer films using a MOKE magnetometer and calculates it with a newly developed Preisach-Arrhenius model, which accurately describes the magnetization decay over time.

This paper reformulates the simplified vector Preisach model to speed up its computations for vector magnetization by extending the use of a "cobweb" grid to define the Preisach function for this multi-dimensional model.
This paper details a new algorithm for the simplified vector Preisach model (SVPM) that extends it from a two-dimensional to a three-dimensional model and provides an efficient implementation.

This study employs experimental and theoretical techniques to show that the dominant stabilization of sugar isomerization transition states within hydrophobic zeolite pores arises from entropic effects, rather than enthalpic effects, due to the disordered nature of confined water.

This study disentangles the effects of clustered and networked water structures on ethanol dehydration catalysis within microporous Brønsted acids by measuring turnover rates as water pressure is increased to the point of intrapore condensation.

This review discusses the use of heterogeneous metal-nitrogen-carbon (MNC) catalysts for aerobic oxidation reactions, drawing lessons from their application as oxygen reduction electrocatalysts to guide the design of more effective oxidation catalysts.

This study identifies two types of Sn sites in Sn-zeolites with catalytic reactivity for ethanol dehydration differing by more than an order of magnitude, with the more reactive sites attributed to Sn atoms located at grain boundaries or defect sites.

This study combines density functional theory calculations with kinetic measurements of ethanol dehydration to identify the relative catalytic contributions of structurally distinct Sn site speciations in Beta zeolite frameworks, constructing a microkinetic model that agrees well with measured data.

This Perspective provides a methodological framework for accurately assessing the uniformity of active sites in atomically dispersed heterogeneous catalysts and for linking their synthesis, structure, and function, supplemented with recent case studies.

This review discusses experimental research methodologies for performing quantitative kinetic studies of heterogeneous catalysis, with a focus on site-isolated materials, and emphasizes the importance of accurately modeling transport processes to obtain intrinsic kinetic data.

This work provides an overview of active site characterization techniques in heterogeneous catalysis, outlining common experimental challenges and best practices to avoid data misinterpretation and improve rigor and reproducibility.
