This study develops a kinetic probe reaction method using the aerobic oxidation of a model hydroquinone substrate to quantify the density of FeNx active centers in Fe-N-C catalysts, showing good agreement with other site-counting methods.

This study investigates the dynamical properties of tension development in leech longitudinal muscle during swimming by using a novel 'dual-sinusoid' experimental method that subjects the muscle to both periodic activation and rhythmic length changes.

This study investigated the passive mechanical properties of the leech body wall, finding nonlinear and hysteretic length-tension relationships, and developed a mathematical model that accurately describes the tension dynamics for step-stretch experiments.

This paper presents an analysis of motoneuron input-output relationships in the medicinal leech, revealing that a simple model with a static threshold and a single time constant accurately predicts impulse frequency adaptation to various current injections.

This paper describes an Introduction to Engineering course taught with a design-centric approach, where first-year students completed collaborative projects like building a solar-powered phone charger and a persistence of vision wand to learn the engineering design process.

This work developed a complete systems model for the leech neuromuscular system that predicts tensions generated during swimming by modeling active muscle tension as a product of length-dependent and frequency-dependent factors, capturing the complex transformation from motoneuron activity to muscle contraction.

This paper discusses the challenges first-year engineering students face with literature reviews and explores how the integration of traditional library instruction and new Generative AI tools like ChatGPT can reshape their research process.

This GIFTS paper presents two approaches for employing Generative AI in the engineering design process for first-year students, aiming to build their understanding and analytical skills in using tools like Copilot and ChatGPT for knowledge acquisition and ideation.

This Work in Progress paper investigates how first-year engineering students' design process knowledge evolves during a two-semester course sequence and evaluates the influence of prior high school engineering experiences on their learning.

This workshop explores how various modes and methods of feedback can support holistic student development, aiming to help instructors, administrators, and advisors shape how they collect, process, and apply student feedback for enhanced learning and growth.

This paper proposes a crack detection method for nuclear power plant inspection videos that fine-tunes a deep neural network to detect local crack patches, which are then grouped in spatio-temporal space for more robust group-level classification.

This paper traces the origins of computational thinking to the educational computing research led by Seymour Papert at MIT, arguing that the five decades of work developing environments like Logo provide an important context for contemporary integration efforts.

This paper proposes an automatic pollen classification method that improves accuracy with less training effort by developing a new feature to capture pollen spikes, applying classification rules from existing types to new ones, and using a new selection criterion to obtain valuable unlabeled samples.

This study determined that hydrogen sulfide (H2S) contributes to hepatic microcirculatory dysfunction during endotoxemia by modulating sinusoidal constriction, as shown by in vivo portal pressure measurements and intravital microscopy in a rat model.

This paper presents a method to automatically track multiple colliding leukocytes in intravital microscopy videos by modeling the appearance and motion for each collision state and testing hypotheses of possible transitions between states.

This article introduces the National Technology Leadership Society (NTLS) microscope prototyping system, highlighting the coalition's goal of advancing the effective use of technology for teaching and learning.

This paper devises a novel multi-stream sensor data verification and anomaly detection method for IoT-based flood forecasting systems that uses sensor fusion between nearby devices to improve F1-Score by 10.8% over previous methods.

This paper traces the evolution of educational technology through the waves of microcomputers, the Internet, and generative AI, demonstrating how educational computing and AI have been intertwined since the development of Logo at MIT.

This paper showcases the pipeline for the Flood-Watch project, which aims to advance flood monitoring and prediction by collecting weather data through the LoRa protocol to be used in flood risk forecasting and visualization.

This study implemented and compared four deep learning models for predicting age and sex from 12-lead electrocardiograms on a freely available dataset, finding the best models achieved a mean absolute error of 8.06 years for age and an AUC of 0.92 for sex.

This paper presents DeepFLASH, a novel and efficient network for learning-based medical image registration that operates entirely in a low-dimensional bandlimited space, dramatically reducing computational cost while maintaining high accuracy.

This paper presents a probabilistic latent variable model for principal geodesic analysis (PGA), providing a probabilistic framework for factor analysis on manifolds and using a Monte Carlo Expectation Maximization algorithm to compute maximum likelihood estimates.

This paper presents a generative Bayesian model for diffeomorphic image registration and atlas building that simultaneously estimates the atlas and the parameters controlling transformation smoothness using a Monte Carlo Expectation Maximization algorithm.

This paper presents a fast geodesic shooting algorithm for diffeomorphic image registration by introducing a finite-dimensional Lie algebra structure on bandlimited velocity fields, which allows computations to be performed in a much lower-dimensional space.

This paper introduces FLASH, a fast geodesic shooting algorithm for diffeomorphic image registration that approximates the infinite-dimensional Lie algebra of vector fields with a low-dimensional, bandlimited space, resulting in dramatic savings in time and memory.

This paper proposes a method to compute fitted frames on the boundary and interior of objects to produce alignment-free, locally corresponding geometric features for powerful statistical analysis of object populations, such as hippocampi shapes.
This paper proposes an unsupervised method for cardiac video translation using a motion feature-guided diffusion model to generate realistic cardiac motion sequences.

This paper presents IGG, a novel framework for Image Generation informed by Geodesic dynamics that combines an efficient autoencoder learning geodesic paths with a latent geodesic diffusion model to ensure smooth, topology-preserving, and interpretable image deformations.

This paper proposes a robust alignment-assisted multi-contrast convolutional dictionary (A2-CDic) model for MRI super-resolution that explicitly models correlations, handles spatial misalignment, and effectively constrains complementary information between modalities.

This study on 2 Ah Li4Ti5O12/LiMn2O4 cells reveals that at elevated temperatures, significant capacity and power loss occurred due to the formation of a manganese, phosphorous, and fluorine-containing coating on the anode, accompanied by substantial hydrogen gas generation.

This paper describes the electrochemical and safety characterization of Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) and graphite anodes paired with LiMn2O4 cathodes, finding that LTO outperforms graphite in cycle life, pulsing impedance, and thermal stability, making it an attractive alternative for high-power automotive applications.

This highlight summarizes advancements in producing crystalline precursor particles for lithium-ion battery cathodes via coprecipitation, focusing on the synthesis of tunable, complex morphologies and the fundamental knowledge gained from studying the reaction process.

This study investigates the nucleation and growth of Ni0.3Mn0.7CO3 precursor particles for Li-ion battery cathodes during a continuous stirred tank reactor process, finding that a lead time of about 5 hours was necessary to achieve uniformity in particle shape and chemical composition.

This paper reports the tailored synthesis of precursor particles with internal gradients in transition metal composition using a coprecipitation reaction, which were then used to create a novel Li1.2(Mn0.62Ni0.38)0.8O2 cathode material for lithium-ion batteries.
This work focuses on the development and characterization of a sulfonated cation exchange membrane designed for selective ion transport in non-aqueous redox flow battery applications.
This study investigates the use of poly(phenylene oxide) backbone membranes as separators for lithium-metal batteries, aiming to improve battery safety and performance.

This study explores an alternative approach for lithium capture from simulated geothermal brine using a packed bed reactor where the capture is driven by the chemical reduction of iron phosphate intercalation host particles by a Fe2+-citrate complex.

This paper discusses the development of selective cation exchange membranes for nonaqueous redox flow batteries, which offer the potential for higher cell voltages and energy densities compared to traditional aqueous systems.

This study evaluates the performance of thick, all-active-material lithium-ion battery electrodes, which lack binder or conductive additives, to understand the trade-offs between increased volumetric energy density and potential increases in cell overpotential.

This article presents an adaptive method of sensitivity encoding called TSENSE, which incorporates both spatial and temporal filtering by acquiring phase encodes in an interleaved manner to improve image reconstruction from undersampled k-space data.

This article provides a comprehensive review of the current state-of-the-art in cardiovascular magnetic resonance phase contrast imaging, covering methodology, clinical applications, and emerging research that utilizes the latest technology.

This paper describes the development and initial evaluation of a breath-hold, two-dimensional cine displacement-encoded (DENSE) MR pulse sequence for quantitative myocardial motion tracking, which demonstrated good agreement with conventional MR tagging for measuring circumferential strain.

This paper describes the development of a collagen-targeted MRI contrast agent for the noninvasive detection, assessment, and monitoring of fibrosis, a common outcome in many chronic diseases of the heart, kidney, liver, and lungs.

This study investigates the role of macrophages in mediating the favorable effects of mesenchymal stromal cell (MSC) therapy in myocardial infarction, finding that MSCs increase the percentage of reparative M2 macrophages, which are essential for infarct repair.

This study used multiparametric cardiac magnetic resonance to investigate whether preventive SGLT2 inhibitor administration attenuates metabolic heart disease in mice, finding that the benefits are mediated by macrophage NOS2.

This prospective cohort study characterizes the incidence and risk factors for BRAF and MEK inhibitor-associated hypertension and cardiac dysfunction in melanoma patients, finding a high incidence of cardiovascular adverse effects despite low baseline cardiotoxicity risk.

This study presents an accelerated cardiac magnetic resonance method for simultaneous mapping of epicardial adipose tissue fatty acid composition and T1, and evaluates their relationships with histological and cytokine markers of inflammation in a mouse model of obesity.

This paper introduces a novel DENSE-guided deep learning network that explicitly accounts for large rotational motion to improve myocardial strain analysis from standard cine bSSFP images, demonstrating improved accuracy in predicting myocardial displacements and strains.

This overview article provides a foundational starting point for researchers and practitioners interested in learning about and applying tensor decomposition in signal processing, statistics, data mining, and machine learning.

This paper proves that transmit beamforming for physical-layer multicasting is NP-hard but shows that semidefinite relaxation techniques can be successfully applied to find approximate solutions with performance guarantees for both minimum power and max-min SNR problem formulations.

This work proposes a joint dimensionality reduction and K-means clustering approach that learns a deep neural network to recover clustering-friendly latent representations from data generated by an unknown nonlinear function, showcasing improved performance on real datasets.

This paper proposes a new learning-based perspective for interference management in wireless communications by using a deep neural network to approximate the input-output mapping of a traditional optimization algorithm, significantly reducing computational complexity while maintaining high performance.

This paper establishes a link between multiple invariance sensor array processing and parallel factor (PARAFAC) analysis, which facilitates the derivation of powerful identifiability results and shows that the uniqueness of ESPRIT stems from the uniqueness of low-rank tensor decomposition.

This paper introduces Subspace Clustering of Subspaces (SCoS), a novel framework for clustering a collection of tall matrices based on their column spaces by using a Block Term Decomposition of a third-order tensor, achieving superior performance in hyperspectral imaging datasets.

This paper introduces the Vertex-Attribute-Constrained Densest k-Subgraph (VAC-DS) problem, a new variant of the densest subgraph problem that incorporates vertex attributes, and proposes an efficient Frank-Wolfe algorithm to solve its tight continuous relaxation.

This paper introduces a repetitionless signal alignment strategy that uses linear precoding to guarantee interference excision in wireless communication with a controllable and practically negligible rate loss.

This paper reformulates the Densest k-Subgraph problem via diagonal loading and shows that its non-convex continuous relaxation is tight under certain conditions, leading to an efficient Frank-Wolfe-based algorithm that outperforms existing baselines.

This paper proposes an interference-resilient hybrid multi-antenna ARQ protocol that synergistically combines packet retransmissions with canonical correlation analysis at the receiver to eliminate strong interference, offering a robust cross-layer design for wireless communication.

This article discusses how the internet has exponentially increased access to public records like campaign finance disclosures, raising complex questions about the balance between government accountability, transparency, and individual privacy.

This paper argues that framing both surveillance and transparency regimes as sociotechnical systems of accountability allows for a comparative analysis of how each system constructs individuals, utilizes information technology, and arranges power relationships in democratic societies.

This paper proposes a "wrap-around" approach to international engineering experiences, involving pre-departure preparation, in-country assignments, and a post-return course to help students process their experience and develop global competency by learning from reverse culture shock.

This paper presents a co-curricular service-learning and community engagement approach, framed as an intellectual apprenticeship, designed to break down institutional silos and foster a continuum of engagement and learning for science and engineering students, faculty, and communities.

This paper explores how a gender metaphor is used by enthusiasts to make sense of their relationship with old warplanes in North America, framing the aircraft not just as machines but as cherished, personified entities.

This paper discusses the importance of immersing student researchers in the field to study coupled human-natural systems, highlighting the value of direct experience for understanding complex environmental interactions.

This paper reviews XPS studies on carbon nitride (CN) and reports on CN thin films prepared by ion-beam deposition, showing that nitrogen is incorporated in two bonding configurations and that elevated temperatures or ion irradiation induce ordering towards a crystalline graphitelike structure.

This study investigates the influence of ion energy on the growth and structure of noncrystalline hydrocarbon films deposited from methane plasmas, finding an abrupt change in the sp3/sp2 ratio in the energy interval from 80 to 120 eV.

This study investigates the bonding characteristics of amorphous B-C-N thin films deposited by reactive DC magnetron sputtering, finding that true ternary compounds form only at low concentrations of one element, otherwise the material tends to phase-separate into binary compounds.

This study analyzes the surface electronic structure of ex situ prepared boron-nitride films using various electron spectroscopy methods, finding that while hexagonal films reflect bulk properties, cubic films exhibit a hexagonal-like top layer about 0.9 nm thick.

This work investigates the influence of low-energy argon ion irradiation on the surface structure of polycrystalline diamond and amorphous carbon films, using photoelectron spectroscopy to monitor a gradual change from diamond features to amorphous carbon with increasing ion dose.

This study investigates the early-stage oxidation of Ni-22Cr-6Mo alloy using in-situ synchrotron-based XPEEM and XPS, revealing that unlike binary Ni-Cr, the ternary alloy exhibits a layer-by-layer growth of a Cr2O3 oxide with small admixtures of Mo-oxides.

This study uses in-situ and in-operando synchrotron-based XPEEM and XPS to investigate the early-stage oxidation of Ni-22wt%Cr, revealing preferential Cr oxidation and demonstrating data analysis techniques to extract the evolution of oxide island distribution and growth kinetics.

This study investigates the impact of the high-power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) pulse width on the crystallization, microstructure, and ferroelectric properties of undoped HfO2 films, finding that an intermediate pulse width stabilizes the ferroelectric phase over the widest temperature range.

This study compares the passive film composition and corrosion resistance of Ni-22Cr and Ni-22Cr-6Mo alloys in acidic chloride solutions, revealing that Mo alloying enhances passivation by promoting a more protective, stratified film enriched with Cr and Mo oxides.

This book provides an overview of Distributed Constraint Optimization Problems (DCOPs), a framework for modeling and solving multi-agent coordination problems, and discusses their various applications.
This work explores End-to-End Constrained Optimization Learning, a paradigm that integrates machine learning models directly with optimization problems to improve decision-making under uncertainty.

This paper presents a deep learning approach to predict AC optimal power flows by combining a neural network with a Lagrangian dual method to satisfy physical and engineering constraints, achieving highly accurate predictions with average errors as low as 0.2%.

This paper presents a comprehensive review of decision-focused learning (DFL), a paradigm that integrates machine learning and constrained optimization, providing an in-depth analysis of gradient-based and gradient-free techniques and an extensive empirical evaluation across seven problems.

This paper explores the use of Lagrangian duality for deep learning applications with complex constraints, demonstrating its benefits in predicting optimal power flows and compressor settings in energy systems, as well as enforcing fairness and robustness in learning models.

This paper presents Constrained Discrete Diffusion (CDD), a novel method for enforcing constraints on natural language generation by integrating discrete diffusion models with differentiable optimization, demonstrating its effectiveness in toxicity mitigation and property adherence for molecule generation.

This paper proposes a novel, training-free integration of stable diffusion models with constrained optimization frameworks to enable the generation of outputs that satisfy stringent physical and functional requirements, demonstrated through material design and copyright-constrained content generation tasks.

This paper analyzes the disparate speed-up rates of speculative decoding across different tasks, showing that the performance gain consistently diminishes for under-fit and underrepresented tasks, and proposes a mitigation strategy that improves fairness.

This paper introduces a learning-based framework that integrates a time-discrete Neural Operator with an optimization surrogate to solve computationally demanding PDE-constrained optimization problems, achieving solution quality comparable to classical methods but with up to four orders of magnitude improvement in speed.

This paper proposes Chance-constrained Flow Matching (CCFM), a novel training-free method that integrates stochastic optimization into the sampling process of generative models to enforce hard constraints while maintaining high-fidelity sample generation, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on complex physical and molecular problems.

This book details the central role of modular forms and q-series in number theory, covering their applications to quadratic forms, Fermat's Last Theorem, hypergeometric functions, elliptic curves, and more, serving as a resource for advanced students and researchers.
This paper proves that for every non-negative integer n, the number of partitions of n, p(n), is equidistributed modulo m for any integer m with at least one prime factor greater than or equal to 5.

This book presents the essential features of the theory of harmonic Maass forms and mock modular forms, which extend the theory of modular forms to non-holomorphic functions and have wide-ranging applications in number theory, combinatorics, and mathematical physics.

By constructing a weak Maass-Poincaré series, this paper proves the Andrews-Dragonette conjecture for the coefficients of the mock theta function f(q), thereby obtaining exact formulas for the number of partitions of n with even and odd rank.

This paper outlines the general theory of harmonic Maass forms and provides several applications to number theory, including partitions, modular forms, singular moduli, and L-functions, showing how these non-holomorphic modular forms solve a great mathematical mystery originating with Ramanujan.

This paper shows that a sequence of weight n quasimodular forms arising from derivatives of Jacobi's theta function corresponds to special symmetric polynomials that arise in the study of syzygies of numerical semigroups, thereby settling two conjectures about these polynomials.
This comment considers how artificial intelligence tools are reshaping mathematical research and discusses how future developments of this technology will transform mathematical practice.

This paper proves that the number of hooks of length t among size n self-conjugate partitions is asymptotically normally distributed, confirming the speculation that the distribution of t-hooks in unrestricted partitions essentially descends to self-conjugate partitions.

This note solves a general problem posed by G. E. Andrews by establishing a necessary and sufficient condition for when holomorphic q-series on a congruence subgroup form a vector-valued modular function, providing a clear path to modularity for "strange" q-series.

This note confirms a conjecture by Larson regarding the supersingular order of a specific weight form, providing the precise modular input needed to calibrate relevant differentials in Behrens' program on detecting periodic classes in the stable homotopy groups of spheres.

This paper describes the Protein Data Bank (PDB), the single worldwide archive of structural data of biological macromolecules, outlining its goals, data deposition and access systems, and future development plans.

This paper formally publishes the FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship, which are designed to enhance the ability of machines to automatically find and use data, in addition to supporting its reuse by individuals.

This paper reports a new and fast algorithm for protein structure alignment that uses a combinatorial extension of an alignment path defined by aligned fragment pairs, making it suitable for database scanning and analysis of large protein families.

This paper presents ElliPro, a new structure-based web-tool that implements Thornton's method for predicting antibody epitopes by identifying residues protruding from a protein's surface and has been successfully tested on a benchmark of discontinuous epitopes.

This article reviews literature demonstrating that open research practices like open access and open data are associated with increases in citations, media attention, collaborations, and funding opportunities, providing evidence of significant career benefits for researchers.

This article proposes a new paradigm of human physiologically-based drug discovery using AI-powered programmable virtual humans, dynamic multiscale models that can evaluate and optimize compound efficacy and safety earlier in the drug discovery process.

This perspective introduces the concept of programmable virtual humans—dynamic, multiscale models that simulate drug actions from molecular to phenotypic levels—as a transformative path to optimize therapeutic efficacy and safety earlier in the drug discovery process.

This paper describes a CACHE challenge to predict ligands for the SARS-CoV-2 Nsp13 helicase RNA binding site, where 23 computational teams predicted 1957 compounds, of which 0.7% were confirmed to bind in a surface plasmon resonance assay.

This review systematically summarizes advances in reversible covalent kinase inhibitors (RCKIs), covering their electrophilic groups, chemical scaffolds, and binding modes to provide insights and design strategies for their development.

This paper provides an overview of key issues regarding data errors and their propagation within and across biological databases, making recommendations to reduce these problems, especially in the age of generative AI, with a focus on improved data engineering education for biologists.

This study investigated whether a finite-element model of human ribs composed entirely of hexahedral elements would provide more accurate simulations of fracture than a hex-shell model, finding that the all-hex model better predicted fracture force and displacement in dynamic loading experiments.

This study performed lateral bending and shear tests on human tibias, femurs, and knee joints, reporting a significantly lower lateral failure bending moment for the knee joint (134 Nm) compared to previous literature and the failure moments for the tibia and femur.

This study developed kinematic corridors for the response of post-mortem human surrogates (PMHS) in full-scale pedestrian impact tests with a small sedan at 40 km/h to assess the biofidelity of pedestrian dummies.

This study performed dynamic latero-medial bending experiments on human leg and thigh specimens and combined the data with previous studies to develop injury risk functions for femur and tibia fractures at different loading locations.

This study evaluated the effectiveness of anthropometry-based scaling techniques to predict female responses in reclined frontal impact sled tests by scaling data from mid-size male post-mortem human subjects, finding that scaling was most effective for predicting upper body kinematics.

This study establishes best practices for ethical research using Postmortem Human Subjects (PMHS) in injury prevention and reviews literature to underscore the pivotal role of PMHS testing in evaluating safety systems like airbags.
This book presents general techniques and methods for solving regular problems on concurrent processors, providing a foundation for parallel computing.

This paper presents a set of rotationally invariant observables that characterize the "shapes" of events in processes like e+e- annihilation, which are calculable in quantum-chromodynamics perturbation theory and can be compared to experimental data.

This book provides an overview of Grid computing by bringing together many of the major projects and perspectives of pioneering developers and researchers, defining the Grid as a system that supports the integration of resources like computers, networks, and data archives.

This paper presents Twister, an enhanced MapReduce runtime with an extended programming model and architecture that efficiently supports iterative MapReduce computations for large-scale data parallel applications.

This article, based on a National Science Foundation workshop, examines the requirements of future scientific applications and the challenges they present to current scientific workflow technologies, which are used to manage complex distributed computations.

This paper describes a simple do-it-yourself method to compute the probability of a large earthquake in a local region by using the Gutenberg-Richter relation and the Receiver Operating Characteristic formalism to analyze the number of small earthquakes occurring in natural time.

This paper proposes using adaptable workflow templates and simple experiment management tools, termed benchmark carpentry, to address the challenge of demonstrating HPC resource capability with limited benchmarks, validated by two independent tools across various scientific applications.

To address the immense computational cost of LHC event simulation, this paper proposes a conditioned quantum-assisted generative model that integrates a variational autoencoder and a restricted Boltzmann machine tailored for D-Wave's quantum annealer to simulate calorimeter interactions.
This editorial celebrates the successes of the Journal of Geophysical Research: Machine Learning and Computation during its first 18 months of publication.

This study developed and evaluated C-OLiVE, an interactive virtual environment for museums, finding some evidence that synchronous, co-located, tripartite group collaboration can afford greater learning compared to conventional approaches.

This paper describes the design of RabBit EscApe, a tangible board game for children ages 6-10 that promotes computational thinking by challenging them to complete or create paths using magnetized manipulatives.

This paper proposes a framework for socially engaging large groups of young museum visitors by combining serious games and virtual environments to facilitate orchestrated learning activities that enhance motivation and social interaction.

This poster presents an experiment evaluating the Leap Motion Controller against the mouse for performing integral and separable 3D manipulation tasks, finding that the mouse performed significantly better in terms of completion time and error.

This paper presents findings from a study in a Greek museum where triads of students learned about olive oil production using a game, revealing that expert facilitation led to greater learning gains compared to students playing alone.

This study tested a conceptual framework on the impact of personal relevance on group work in a project-based learning course, finding that students' investment in their project and contribution to the idea were significantly related to better team dynamics and higher perceived effort.

This poster presents a plan for the second phase of an evaluation of e2Logos, a new grading and annotation tool for online technical reports, to assess the educational impact of its feedback on student learning in complex, real-world problem-solving activities.
This paper introduces e2Logos, a novel software tool designed for the evaluation of online student project reports, aiming to improve the grading and feedback process for complex assignments.

This work reports findings from testing Marcus, a depression screening chatbot based on the PHQ-9 assessment, which was found to be comparable to the online PHQ-9 in detecting depression but was not the most effective method based on user preference.

This workshop seeks to advance the design of digital interfaces that promote meaningful interactions and digital wellbeing by inviting interdisciplinary researchers and practitioners to discuss how to counter attention-capture dark patterns on digital platforms.

This study experimentally and numerically investigates the effects of dilution, pressure, and flow-field on the extinction of methane-air diffusion flames, showing that the maximum velocity gradient at extinction is relatively insensitive to burner design and boundary conditions.

This paper investigates the effect of fine water droplets on extinguishing steady, laminar counterflow methane-air flames using a new two-phase numerical model, revealing a nonmonotonic dependence of the extinction strain rate on droplet size.

This study experimentally and numerically investigates the effectiveness of eleven gaseous agents as substitutes for CF3Br in quenching diffusion flames of liquid hydrocarbon fuels, finding that CF3Br was the most effective on a mass and mole basis.

This paper presents numerical simulation results on the mass burning rate and flame structure of a heated graphite rod in a stagnation-point flow field, using detailed homogeneous and semiglobal heterogeneous chemical kinetics with extensive comparisons to experimental data.

This study experimentally and numerically investigates the interaction of fine droplets of water and water/NaOH solutions with a steady, laminar counterflow methane/air nonpremixed flame, supporting earlier modeling conclusions about the non-monotonic effect of droplet size on extinction.

This paper derives skeletal reaction models for a four-component gasoline surrogate via an instantaneous local sensitivity analysis technique, developing two new models that accurately reproduce the vital flame results of a detailed 1389-species model with significantly fewer species.

This paper employs a local-sensitivity-analysis technique using the forced-optimally time dependent (f-OTD) methodology to generate new, accurate skeletal reaction models for methane combustion from the foundational fuel chemistry model (FFCM-1).

This work expands the Reaction Mechanism Generator (RMG) program to include a comprehensive set of boron species and reactions, then uses the newly generated kinetic models to predict reagent decomposition and deposition pathways for boron nitride and boron carbide coatings.

This study presents initial life cycle data on the interaction of Chemical Vapor Deposited Silicon Carbide with a high-temperature, high-pressure steam jet in a newly developed laboratory reactor designed to mimic gas turbine engine conditions.

This paper generates skeletal reaction mechanisms for methane combustion at atmospheric and high pressures from the foundational fuel chemistry model (FFCM-1) using the forced-optimally time dependent (f-OTD) methodology to compute and analyze sensitivities.

This paper proposes exploiting opportunistic communications in Mobile Social Networks to offload mobile data traffic, and studies the target-set selection problem to minimize cellular data usage by proposing and evaluating three algorithms.

This paper presents simple and provably good heuristics for several NP-hard optimization problems on unit disk graphs, including maximum independent set and minimum coloring, without needing a geometric representation of the graphs.

This paper presents a general polynomial algorithm for minimizing maximum power in ad hoc network topology control for a class of monotone properties and discusses a general approximation approach for minimizing total power.

This paper presents NC-approximation schemes for a number of NP- and PSPACE-hard problems on geometric graphs, including unit disk graphs, which exhibit the same time versus performance trade-off as the best known schemes for planar graphs.

This decision analytical model projects US COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths from April 2024 to April 2025 under six scenarios of immune escape and vaccine recommendations, assessing the potential benefit of vaccination in reducing disease burden.

This paper develops a unified mathematical framework for the computationally intractable problem of welfare maximization in resource allocation scenarios with peer effects, and provides a polynomial-time algorithm for a restricted version with one-sided preferences.

This study uses a behavioral-epidemiological model to show that individual behavioral adaptations based on localized risk perception lead to premature population-level responses relative to the actual dynamics of an epidemic on a network.

This paper develops IGraSS, a novel iterative framework that combines semantic segmentation with a graph-based ground-truth refinement module to significantly improve the accuracy of mapping infrastructure networks like canals and roads from satellite imagery.

This paper develops a novel and generic algorithm for the adversarial multi-armed bandit problem that achieves various new data-dependent regret bounds by applying optimism and adaptivity techniques to the Online Mirror Descent framework.

This work significantly expands the understanding of last-iterate convergence for Optimistic Gradient Descent Ascent (OGDA) and Optimistic Multiplicative Weights Update (OMWU) in constrained saddle-point optimization, showing linear convergence for OMWU in bilinear games and introducing a sufficient condition for OGDA's exponential convergence in more general settings.

This paper proposes the first parameter-free, efficient, and optimal contextual bandit algorithm for non-stationary environments, which achieves a dynamic regret of O(sqrt(ST)) by introducing novel "replay phases" to detect non-stationarity.

This work develops several efficient contextual bandit algorithms for non-stationary environments by equipping existing methods with statistical tests to adapt to distribution changes, achieving near-optimal dynamic regret without prior knowledge of the non-stationarity.

This paper proposes an optimal black-box reduction that transforms a reinforcement learning algorithm with optimal regret in a stationary environment into one with optimal dynamic regret in a non-stationary environment, without prior knowledge of the non-stationarity.

This paper introduces Dig-DEC, an improved model-free decision-estimation coefficient that drives exploration purely by information gain, resolving an open problem by providing the first model-free regret bounds for hybrid MDPs with bandit feedback under general transition structures.

This paper presents an efficient algorithm for linear contextual bandits with adversarial losses and stochastic action sets that achieves O(sqrt(dT)) regret in polynomial time by reducing the problem to a misspecification-robust adversarial linear bandit with fixed action sets.

This paper presents a simple black-box reduction that transforms the average iterates of an uncoupled learning dynamics into the last iterates of a new one, leading to new state-of-the-art last-iterate convergence rates for two-player zero-sum games under both gradient and bandit feedback.

This work proposes a general extension of the decision estimation coefficient (DEC) to more precisely characterize the complexity of online decision making in hybrid environments where dynamics are fixed but rewards are adversarial, covering both model-based and model-free learning.

This work introduces HANQ, a deep Q-learning algorithm with an asymmetric predictor, specific normalization layers, and hypergradient descent, which avoids the need for a target network and matches or exceeds DQN's performance in offline RL experiments.

This paper reformulates the image colorization problem to be directly solvable by deep learning techniques and proposes a joint bilateral filtering-based post-processing step to ensure artifact-free quality, outperforming state-of-the-art algorithms in both quality and speed.

This paper shows that the deep image prior is asymptotically equivalent to a stationary Gaussian process prior and uses this insight to develop a Bayesian inference approach with stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics that avoids early stopping and improves results for image reconstruction tasks.

This study investigates machine unlearning for pre-trained large language models as a solution to the 'right to be forgotten', establishing a robust benchmark for seven unlearning methods and demonstrating their computational efficiency over retraining.

This paper evaluates semi-supervised learning (SSL) for fine-grained classification on a realistic benchmark with class imbalance and novel classes, finding that while recent SSL methods provide benefits, they are outperformed by a simple transfer learning baseline.

This paper proposes a mixture learning model for image colorization that ensembles multiple neural networks to better capture distinct color styles within a dataset, outperforming single-network approaches.
This study explores the use of representation learning techniques to predict the shape selectivity of nanoporous zeolites, a critical factor in their catalytic performance.

This paper introduces Frame In-N-Out, an efficient identity-preserving and motion-controllable video Diffusion Transformer architecture for unbounded, controllable image-to-video generation, supported by a new dataset and evaluation protocol.

This study introduces a suite of benchmark protocols to systematically assess the mid-level vision capabilities of 22 prominent self-supervised learning models, revealing a weak correlation between mid-level and high-level task performance.

This paper proposes learning 3D representations from procedural 3D programs that automatically generate shapes, finding that these representations perform on par with those learned from semantically recognizable 3D models across various downstream tasks.

This work pioneers the study of open-vocabulary monocular 3D object detection, introducing a class-agnostic approach that lifts open-vocabulary 2D detections into 3D space and establishes a new target-aware evaluation protocol.

This paper argues for transforming consumer health informatics by adopting a patient work framework, which connects patients to their context by simultaneously attending to their activities, family members, and the embeddedness of their health management in larger processes.

This article argues that the widespread use of telehealth due to the COVID-19 pandemic has the potential to exacerbate health inequities for people with disabilities if inadequate attention is paid to the design, implementation, and policy dimensions of these technologies.

This study performs a secondary content analysis of three studies on the work of chronically ill patients to develop a consolidated macroergonomic patient work system model, identifying 17 contextual factors across physical, social, and organizational domains that shape health-related work.

This 10-year mapping review of 212 publications defines patient ergonomics as the application of human factors to improve patients' health-related work, revealing a robust body of literature and identifying gaps for future research with understudied populations and topics.

This study developed and assessed two recruitment strategies using direct communication with existing Facebook groups and pages to recruit Filipino-Americans and individuals with type 2 diabetes for health information technology research, demonstrating a feasible and effective method for accessing diverse populations.

This study elicited the social and organizational factors important to the design and implementation of exoskeletons for nurses with acute and chronic pain in long-term care facilities, highlighting potential impacts on patients, training considerations, and anticipated pressures to increase productivity.

This perspective piece offers guidance on engaging the disability community in the design, implementation, and policymaking of exoskeletons by using inclusive design principles and partnering with disabled users as experts in their own experiences.

This chapter brings together a transdisciplinary team to articulate achievable imaginaries for disability data justice, arguing that despite a history of exclusion in data and AI, intersectional and disability-led visions can chart new paths toward inclusive futures.

This paper describes a randomized controlled trial testing whether a videoconference-based intervention with American Sign Language-fluent community health navigators can improve cancer screening adherence and communication for adults who are deaf, deafblind, and hard of hearing.

This paper calls for integrated approaches in digital technology design for aging and disability, arguing that joint efforts are essential to address the limitations of current standards and the structural power of ageism and ableism.

This study created a viable caveolin-1 null mouse model which lacks caveolae and shows evidence of hyperproliferative and vascular abnormalities, demonstrating the protein's role in caveolae biogenesis, endocytosis, and cell proliferation control.

This review scrutinizes the physiology of penile erection and the pathophysiology of erectile dysfunction, detailing the hemodynamic changes, neural pathways, and various molecular modulators involved in the process.

This study demonstrates that electrospun, unidirectionally aligned poly(epsilon-caprolactone)/collagen nanofiber meshes can guide the morphogenesis of human skeletal muscle cells, significantly inducing cell alignment and myotube formation for potential use in tissue engineering.

This paper summarizes evidence-based and expert-opinion consensus guidelines developed by an international committee for the clinical management of men's sexual dysfunctions, including erectile dysfunction, orgasm/ejaculation disorders, priapism, and Peyronie's disease.

This study shows that genetically engineered caveolin-2-deficient mice, despite having intact caveolae, exhibit severe pulmonary dysfunction characterized by hypercellularity and thickened alveolar septa.

This patent describes an integrated bioreactor and reseeding chamber system, featuring a bioreactor with a removable crossbar-bar construct and a complementary reseeding chamber, designed for use in cell culture and tissue engineering.

This study demonstrates that microporous annealed particle (MAP) hydrogel scaffolds improve muscle regeneration after volumetric muscle loss in a rodent model by minimizing the foreign body reaction and promoting the formation of innervated myofibers within the implant.
يناقش هذا المقال فقدان العضلات الحجمي كإصابة منهكة تتجاوز قدرة الجسم على التجدد، ويسلط الضوء على أهمية تقييم التعافي الوظيفي، خاصة من خلال اختبار تقلص العضلات في الجسم الحي، لإثبات الفعالية العلاجية.

This paper reviews the communication, driver characteristics, and control aspects of Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) systems to identify key challenges for real-world deployment, such as suitable data communication protocols and maintaining driver engagement.

This paper presents a manifesto outlining key research directions for the next decade of cloud computing, driven by recent technological developments such as serverless computing, IoT, and edge processing.

This paper proposes a deep learning-based method to improve the accuracy of task failure prediction in large-scale cloud data centers by analyzing system message logs to identify relationships between the data and failures.

This paper compares the performance of state-of-the-art machine learning methods for predicting Virtual Machine workloads in cloud computing to improve prediction accuracy and enable more efficient resource management.
This article surveys existing mobile crowdsensing techniques with an emphasis on strategies that reduce resource costs and achieve high Quality-of-Service by judiciously reducing redundant data.

This paper proposes HACK (Homomorphic Acceleration via Compression of the KV cache), a method for disaggregated LLM inference that eliminates dequantization overhead by performing computations directly on the compressed KV cache to reduce latency and memory bottlenecks.

This paper demonstrates through experimental measurements that straggler problems, primarily caused by communication hurdles, persist in homogeneous GPU-based distributed deep learning training and proposes a novel mitigation method to address these limitations.

This paper introduces STRN, a novel deep learning training job scheduler that proactively reduces stragglers during the scheduling phase by considering that different jobs have distinct sensitivities to straggling and resource overload.

This paper proposes MobiRescue, a human mobility-based rescue team dispatching system that predicts rescue request distribution using a Support Vector Machine and then uses an Euler path-based algorithm to create an optimal dispatch plan for flooding disasters.

This paper presents DeepCompile, a compiler-driven framework that optimizes distributed deep learning training by compiling models into computation graphs and applying profiling-guided optimization passes to improve communication-computation overlap and reduce memory pressure.

This study investigated the anisotropic shear deformation and fracture of human cortical bone, finding that fracture patterns depend on osteon orientation and that cracks primarily propagate along the cement lines between osteons.

This study found a strong correlation between the calcination temperature, structure, and photocatalytic properties of Bi2WO6 nanostructures, revealing that while higher temperatures increase crystallinity, they decrease surface area and photocatalytic activity, with quantum dots playing a key role in enhancement.

Using high-resolution 3D imaging, this study reveals a complex lacuno-canalicular network in mineralizing avian tendon, suggesting a cell-mediated process where tenocytes extend canaliculi that connect to channels within the collagen fibril gap zones to control mineralization.

This review summarizes the current understanding of recently discovered mesoscale mineral ellipsoids in bone, discussing their morphology, distribution, and potential roles in mechanical function and remodeling, while highlighting unanswered questions about their formation and significance.

This study demonstrates that factors secreted by primary breast cancer tumors induce the formation of new, lower-quality bone in mice, perturbing the bone microenvironment in regions prone to metastasis even before the arrival of tumor cells.

This study uses FIB-SEM nanotomography to reveal that mesoscale mineral clusters in osteonal bone are arranged in a twisted plywood structure that follows the orientation of the underlying collagen fibrils, providing new insight into bone's hierarchical organization.

This review highlights recent advances in Focused Ion Beam-Scanning Electron Microscopy (FIB-SEM) methodologies that enable 3D analysis of biomineralizing tissues across multiple length scales, bridging the gap between ultrastructural detail and large-volume characterization.

This study reveals distinct gradients in lacunar morphology, mineralization, and matrix organization within the mouse femoral head epiphysis, reflecting its structural adaptation to balance mechanical stability and nutrient transport in the absence of a secondary ossification center.

This paper reviews the potential role of the endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi complex and various intracellular vesicles in mediating vertebrate tissue mineralization by accumulating and transporting the necessary calcium and phosphate ions.

This review by Grandfield and co-workers highlights how in situ liquid transmission electron microscopy provides new insights into the dynamic processes of physiological and pathological biomineralization in a wide range of organisms.

This work demonstrates a hybrid femtosecond/picosecond coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering technique for simultaneous, single-shot measurement of pure-rotational and rovibrational energy distributions in highly nonequilibrium plasma environments.

This study employs hybrid femtosecond/picosecond rotational coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering to achieve interference-free, accurate gas-phase thermometry at elevated pressures by minimizing the influence of collisions and nonresonant background.

This manuscript provides a comprehensive overview of various non-intrusive optical measurement techniques for characterizing flow in hypersonic wind tunnels, comparing their capabilities and limitations across different operating conditions.

This paper presents a dual-pump hybrid femtosecond/picosecond coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering method for simultaneous temperature and multi-species concentration measurements with improved sensitivity across a wide temperature range from 298 to 2400 K.

This work enhances the low-temperature sensitivity of vibrational femtosecond/picosecond coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering thermometry by spectrally resolving rovibrational coherence revivals, enabling accurate measurements from 300 to 2400 K.

This paper uses numerical simulations to investigate the potential of using ultraviolet radiation from a hypersonic vehicle's bow shock as a feedback sensor by analyzing how its spectral features change with freestream velocity and angle of attack.

This paper demonstrates a novel counter-propagating hybrid femtosecond/picosecond CARS configuration that achieves ultra-high spatial resolution in the tens of micrometers for gas-phase thermometry, enabling measurements of steep temperature gradients.

This study uses one-dimensional femtosecond/picosecond coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering to perform spatially resolved post-shock temperature measurements along a line in CO2-predominant environments relevant to atmospheric entry.

This paper presents spatially-resolved temperature and qualitative species concentration measurements within a dual-mode scramjet combustor using hybrid femtosecond/picosecond CARS to characterize the impact of fuel injection on local thermodynamics and flame structure.

This work demonstrates the use of coherent control via adaptive femtosecond pulse shaping to achieve selective excitation of different combustion-relevant species in a flame using hybrid fs/ps coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering.

This paper presents NoDoze, a system that combats threat alert fatigue by using causal dependency graphs and a novel network diffusion algorithm to triage alerts based on historical context, reducing false alarms by 86%.

This paper introduces Tactical Provenance Graphs, which reason about high-level security tactics rather than low-level system events, to help commercial Endpoint Detection and Response tools overcome challenges like high false alarm rates and overwhelming log volumes.

This paper presents PROVDETECTOR, a provenance-based approach that effectively detects stealthy malware by using a novel selection algorithm and machine learning pipeline to identify significant behavioral deviations in OS-level process data.

This work presents ProvThings, a platform-centric auditing system for the Internet of Things that uses automated instrumentation to generate data provenance, enabling the reconstruction of complex causal event chains to diagnose incorrect or malicious behavior with low overhead.

This paper presents ωLOG, a provenance tracking mechanism that creates high-fidelity "universal provenance" graphs for attack investigation by transparently bridging the semantic gap between system-level and application-level logs.

This paper proposes HADES, the first provenance-based intrusion detection system capable of accurate cross-machine causality tracing, which it achieves by leveraging logon session-based execution partitioning to detect and investigate stealthy Active Directory attacks.

This paper presents Nitro, a high-performance, tamper-evident auditing system that co-designs cryptographic and system-level components and uses eBPF to provide fine-grained tamper detection with significant performance gains and near-zero data loss.

This paper introduces PROVSYN, an automated framework that synthesizes high-fidelity provenance graphs for data augmentation to address class imbalance and improve the performance of intrusion detection systems against Advanced Persistent Threats.

This paper introduces Netguardian, a novel Network Intrusion Detection System that detects Advanced Persistent Threats by using multi-stage causal analytics to correlate traffic anomalies and reconstruct attack paths.

This study provides a systematic evaluation of state-of-the-art Graph-based Network Intrusion Detection Systems, revealing significant challenges in reproducibility and robustness that hinder the development of reliable and generalizable solutions.

This paper demonstrates a simple and inexpensive photolithographic method for patterning polyethylene glycol hydrogels by using a transparency mask to selectively conjugate peptides to the hydrogel surface via UV exposure.

This review describes the use of decellularized extracellular matrix (dECM) as a promising tool in regenerative medicine, covering its unique biomimetic properties, methods of use, and the challenges associated with its clinical translation.

This study developed a nitric oxide-releasing polyurethane-PEG copolymer containing the YIGSR peptide that promotes endothelialization and decreases platelet adhesion, showing promise for improving the long-term patency of small-diameter vascular grafts.

This paper describes a nitric oxide-producing polyurethane that improves thromboresistance by inhibiting platelet adhesion and smooth muscle cell proliferation while encouraging endothelial cell growth, making it a promising material for vascular grafts.
This patent describes temperature- and pH-responsive polymer compositions, assigned to the University of Washington, with potential applications in controlled delivery systems.
This work presents a poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate hydrogel platform designed to model and study angiogenesis in the context of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

This study uses an integrated multiscale computational model to predict how combinations of biomechanical and biochemical cues in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis affect microvascular remodeling and the efficacy of drug treatments.

This work presents a multi-scale computational model that integrates intracellular signaling networks with an agent-based model to investigate how combined biomechanical and biochemical cues regulate microvascular remodeling in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

This paper presents a vision and roadmap for Integrated Environmental Modeling, a transdisciplinary, science-based structure for organizing knowledge to explain and predict the behavior of environmental systems in response to human and natural stressors.

This study uses three decades of water-column chlorophyll a data to examine the relative importance of local versus advected sources of reduced carbon to benthic communities on the Chukchi Sea shelf, finding a strong correlation between biomass and chlorophyll indicative of strong benthic-pelagic coupling driven by advection from the Bering Sea.

This work presents a design for a modeling service that builds from the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) Web Processing Service (WPS) protocol, enabling environmental models to operate and interact with others as web services to overcome platform and language incompatibilities.

This article proposes best practices for the Geoscience Paper of the Future, an approach for geoscientists to fully document, share, and cite all research products including data, software, and computational provenance to accelerate scientific discovery.

This paper describes the creation of web services for the National Water Information System (NWIS), providing a machine-accessible interface that offers a middle-layer of abstraction between the USGS database and client applications to facilitate easier data access and integration.

To understand long-term stormwater Best Management Practice maintenance challenges, this study surveyed professionals from the Virginia Department of Transportation and reviewed inspection records, revealing how resource constraints shape maintenance priorities and identifying strategies for improvement.

To address the high computational cost of physics-based models for real-time flood forecasting, this study develops and validates a seq2seq LSTM surrogate model that provides accurate, multi-step-ahead, street-scale nuisance flood forecasts for urban-coastal cities.

Utilizing a hydrodynamic model, this study presents a methodology for simulating nuisance flooding from tidal and compound events in Norfolk, Virginia, quantifying its impact under present conditions and projecting a significant increase in flood extent with a 1-meter sea-level rise by 2100.

This paper describes the soil moisture retrieval approach and implementation for the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer (AMSR-E) on the EOS Aqua satellite, which offers improved sensing capability, and outlines a postlaunch validation program to evaluate its performance.

This paper introduces the IAHS Decade on Predictions in Ungauged Basins (PUB), a scientific initiative aimed at coordinating the global research community to achieve major advances in the ability to make reliable hydrological predictions in ungauged or poorly gauged basins.

This report presents a decadal strategy for the US civil space Earth observation program, outlining prioritized science, applications, and observations to advance knowledge of our planet and support societal benefits like resource management and disaster response.

This paper presents a vision for advancing process-based watershed hydrological research by synergistically using electrical and magnetic geophysical methods to measure geological structure and identify flow paths, thereby improving the integration of measurement and modeling.

This paper provides an updated review of the state-of-the-science in soil moisture remote sensing, covering global mapping from satellites like SMAP and SMOS, methods for extending surface data to the root zone, and current validation and research efforts.

This study presents a new 1 km summer brightness temperature dataset and a two-step soil moisture evaluation method that incorporates this dataset to address the challenges of evaluating global soil moisture products due to limited in-situ observations and spatial heterogeneity.
This entry announces the Witherspoon Lecture at an AGU conference, presented by Lixin Wang.
This study evaluates the accuracy of the SMAP 400 m soil moisture product across diverse micro-watersheds in South India using data from the REWARD program.
This entry is the title for an oral presentation session at an AGU conference on advances in remote sensing, AI, and modeling for hydrology.
This entry announces the Walter B. Langbein Lecture at an AGU conference, presented by Chris Soulsby.

This study reports the synthesis of Fe-Cr-Mo-(Y,Ln)-C-B bulk metallic glasses with diameters up to 12 mm, achieved by destabilizing the competing crystalline phase with large atoms like Y/Ln, resulting in a non-ferromagnetic material with high elastic moduli and hardness.

This paper reports the synthesis and properties of a new class of metallic glasses containing up to 90 atomic percent aluminum, which exhibit unusual glass formability and high tensile strength, making them promising for high-strength, low-density materials.

This article reviews various classes of bulk thermoelectric materials, such as skutterudites and half-Heusler alloys, to understand how manipulating their structure, for example by using "rattlers" or mixed-lattice atoms, can optimize their properties for thermoelectric applications.

This paper reports the direct observation of deformation-induced crystallization within the shear bands of aluminum-based amorphous alloys, where 7-10 nm diameter aluminum nanocrystals form as a result of localized heating during plastic deformation.

This study employs a Support Vector Machine model to efficiently classify the phases of thermoelectric alloys, achieving prediction accuracies from 77% to 92% and demonstrating a time-efficient computational approach to aid in the design of high-performance materials.

This work examines the effects of adding various physical concepts, such as short-range order and dopant properties, to machine learning models to improve their ability to predict thermoelectric properties and capture the underlying physics in designing TE materials.

This study compares several machine learning models for predicting the yield strength and plasticity of high-entropy alloys, demonstrating high accuracy with low error by integrating advanced feature engineering that reflects electronic factors, atomic ordering, and stacking fault energy.

This research pioneers an integrated approach using high-throughput machine learning and simulations to effectively navigate the design space of refractory high-entropy alloys, leading to the development of single-phase ordered B2 aluminum-enriched alloys with a remarkable synergy of high strength and ductility.

This study characterized the passive film on a dual-phase Al0.3Cr0.5Fe2Mn0.25Mo0.15Ni1.5Ti0.3 alloy, finding that each phase formed a unique film with compositions reflecting the underlying microstructure, which remained continuous across phase boundaries and provided uniform corrosion resistance.

This paper discusses the dual-mode scramjet, a promising propulsion system that integrates ramjet and scramjet capabilities into a single fixed-geometry combustor, enabling operation from Mach 3 to near Mach 20.

An experimental study was performed to characterize the effects of combustion-air preheating vitiation on dual-mode scramjet performance, finding that adding water vapor and carbon dioxide to the freestream decreased combustor pressures and shifted the transition between supersonic and subsonic combustion to higher equivalence ratios.

This paper describes the use of sequentially imaged, fluorescence-based molecular tagging velocimetry to perform quantitative velocity measurements in hypersonic flows at NASA Langley Research Center, providing data needed to validate computational models.

This paper discusses the dual-mode scramjet, a hypersonic airbreathing propulsion system where a precombustion shock train forms in the isolator during ram mode to achieve subsonic combustion, and the transition between modes is controlled by fuel flow rate.

This paper discusses the dual-mode scramjet concept, which allows a single-engine flowpath to operate as a scramjet at high Mach numbers and as a ramjet at lower speeds by managing heat release to produce a thermal choke.

This work investigates the use of an optical emission spectroscopy sensor for improving closed-loop shock train control in a dual-mode scramjet flowpath, demonstrating that feedback from the sensor provides a smoother and more effective control response compared to traditional wall pressure measurements.

This paper applies wavelet-based optical flow velocimetry to 100 kHz OH-PLIF measurements to determine two-dimensional velocity fields in a supersonic combustion environment without introducing seed particles, offering insights into instantaneous and time-averaged flow behavior.

This work examines new propagation uncertainty strategies for estimating fluid film bearing coefficients, presenting the Monte Carlo method as a more accurate approach than the Taylor Series Method and proposing a novel method for estimating uncertainty in bearing eccentricity.

This study demonstrates shock train leading edge location control in a dual-mode scramjet flow path using an optical emission spectroscopy sensor for feedback, which proved to be a more effective and smoother method than traditional wall-based pressure measurements.

This article discusses the projected link between climate change-induced environmental stresses, such as resource scarcity and glacier melt, and the amplification of conflict, particularly in vulnerable regions of the developing world like Peru.
This guide provides information and procedures for the development of renewable energy projects in Costa Rica.

This document provides information to support discussion and advocacy for improving policies and funding for energy access in Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, and Nicaragua by describing the energy situation and poverty conditions in the region.

This thesis empirically examines how the Costa Rican Movement Against Genetically Modified Organisms engages with a wide range of public deliberation spaces, proposing a multifaceted approach to bridge the study of social movements and deliberative democracy.

This paper outlines the strengths and barriers to the growth of Peace Engineering in Costa Rica, arguing that building the field requires greater reflection and deliberative democratization of disciplinary boundaries in civil service and academia.

This article reviews the state of the art of membrane technology for water purification, identifying the need for improved polymer-based membranes with higher flux, selectivity, and resistance to fouling and chemical degradation to address global water challenges.

This paper reviews the performance of polymer membranes for desalination, noting an inverse correlation between water permeance and salt rejection, and argues for using intrinsic material properties like water permeability and water/salt permeability selectivity for more meaningful comparisons.

This review covers key developments in water and salt transport through polymer membranes, surveying polymers used in applications like reverse osmosis and highlighting the influence of polymer structure, such as charged groups and cross-linking, on transport properties.

This paper reports on the synthesis and transport properties of polyamide thin-film composite membranes prepared via interfacial polymerization, achieving high NaCl rejection and permeate flux, and also explores membranes made with a new disulfonated diamine.

This paper discloses a strategy that directs the hierarchical self-assembly of sodium thioctate, a small molecule of biological origin, into a highly ordered supramolecular layered network by combining dynamic covalent ring-opening polymerization with an evaporation-induced interfacial confinement effect.

By applying single-cell RNA sequencing to 4645 cells from 19 melanoma patients, this study dissected the tumor ecosystem, revealing transcriptional heterogeneity in malignant cells, distinct tumor microenvironmental patterns, and T cell exhaustion programs.

This paper reports a public-domain method for highly multiplexed single-cell imaging called cyclic immunofluorescence (CycIF), a simple procedure where four-color staining alternates with chemical inactivation of fluorophores to progressively build a high-dimensional image.

This paper describes the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS) program, an NIH initiative that catalogs how human cells globally respond to various perturbations to better understand human disease and advance new therapies.

This study took a multiparametric approach to analyze cellular response to anticancer drugs, finding that parameters beyond potency, such as the slope and maximum effect of the dose-response curve, vary systematically with cell line and drug class and can reveal mechanisms like cell-to-cell variability in target inhibition.

Using single-cell analysis and live-cell imaging, this study shows that melanoma cells adapt to RAF/MEK inhibitors by reversibly entering a slowly dividing, de-differentiated state characterized by the up-regulation of neural crest markers like NGFR.

Using multivariate modeling approaches on hundreds of cancer cell lines, this study systematically identifies recurrent metabolic states, their association with tumor lineage, and uncovers synthetically lethal associations between metabolic vulnerabilities and driver mutations or drug sensitivities.

This paper presents a streamlined protocol for iterative indirect immunofluorescence imaging (4i) to generate highly multiplexed spatial data at cellular and subcellular resolutions across fixed cultured cells, tissue sections, and metaphase chromosome spreads.

This study analyzed the MSK-IMPACT database to identify driver oncogenic mutations specific to in-transit melanoma, a distinctive form of metastasis, to understand the mechanisms of lymphatic trapping and find potential therapeutic targets.

This study identifies a tool compound, MTX-216, that is highly effective in blocking NF1-loss-of-function melanoma cells by co-suppressing PI3K and SYK, providing a path to exploit SYK dependency to selectively target this melanoma subtype.

This study identifies that loss of NF1 in melanoma confers sensitivity to SYK kinase inhibition, demonstrating that a tool compound, MTX-216, effectively blocks tumor growth by inhibiting both PI3K and SYK, leading to the suppression of mitochondrial electron transport chain genes.

This article explores how electroconvection can be induced using a patterned membrane and strong unipolar charge injection under both DC and AC voltages, using a specialized flow simulation to find the optimal pattern ratio for achieving the highest time-averaged current density.

This dissertation explores the induction of electroconvection under AC and DC voltages using patterned surfaces with unipolar charge injection, developing a specialized adaptive time-stepping algorithm to simulate the system and identify optimal pattern designs for enhancing ion transport.

This work uses numerical simulation with an iterative algorithm to investigate and optimize patterned accelerated electroconvection, showing how alternating permeable and impermeable regions can increase ion transport and current density at polarized surfaces.

This study investigates the impact of surface patterning on electroconvection with unipolar charge injection under both AC and DC voltages, aiming to understand how different patterns affect ion transport and current density.

This study uses Raman scattering with various laser excitation wavelengths to observe and identify numerous vibrational modes in single-wall carbon nanotubes, finding good agreement with lattice dynamics calculations and a nonresonant bond polarizability model.

This paper demonstrates a method to unite the unique electronic properties of single-walled carbon nanotubes with the specific molecular-recognition features of DNA by coupling them to peptide nucleic acid and hybridizing them with complementary DNA for recognition-based assembly.

This paper discusses a microfiltration-based purification procedure for single-wall carbon nanotubes that separates them from coexisting carbon nanospheres and metal nanoparticles without requiring oxidative treatment, achieving a purity in excess of 90%.

This paper reports the results of Monte Carlo simulations of H2 physisorption in finite-diameter carbon nanotube ropes, showing a strong dependence of adsorption on rope diameter and identifying high binding-energy sites in the external grooves.

This study demonstrates the use of individual metallic and semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes as nanoelectrodes for electrochemistry, observing similar steady-state voltammetric curves for both types and resolving very fast interfacial electron transfer rates.

This work-in-progress paper presents the design and implementation of a new two-semester first-year engineering course sequence that integrates engineering design, sociotechnical skills, career development, and academic advising, with faculty serving as both professor and advisor.

This paper reports the preparation, isolation, and characterization of the dimetallic endohedral heterofullerene Gd2@C79N, an exceptionally stable paramagnetic molecule with a high magnetic spin state of S = 15/2.

This study uses Raman spectroscopy and density functional theory to investigate the vibrational spectrum of the endohedral fullerene C2@C84, reporting evidence for quantum tunneling of the diatomic C2 unit through its rotation plane.

This study uses Raman spectroscopy with a wide range of excitation wavelengths to investigate the Fano interference effect on the zone center optical phonon in heavily p-type doped silicon, identifying a transition in the electronic excitation spectrum.

Using current noise measurements, this study investigates the effects of electron beam exposure on carbon nanotube field-effect transistors, finding that high doses induce a potential barrier in p-type semiconducting nanotubes, likely due to trapped charges in the underlying SiO2.

This paper demonstrates how an adaptive design strategy, tightly coupled with experiments, can accelerate the discovery of new materials by sequentially identifying the next most informative experiments, successfully applying it to find NiTi-based shape memory alloys with very low thermal hysteresis.

This review discusses how active learning, particularly using uncertainties and utility functions to guide adaptive sampling, can accelerate the search and discovery of new materials by efficiently navigating the vast experimental and computational search space.

This study demonstrates how machine learning coupled with optimization methods can accelerate the discovery of new Pb-free BaTiO3-based piezoelectrics, leading to the synthesis of (Ba0.84Ca0.16)(Ti0.90Zr0.07Sn0.03)O3 with the largest electrostrain of 0.23% in the BTO family.

This paper demonstrates a two-step machine learning approach, combining classification to screen for perovskite structures and active learning to guide synthesis, to accelerate the experimental search for high-temperature ferroelectric perovskites in a vast chemical space.

This study demonstrates that a statistical learning approach using three material descriptors related to chemical bonding and atomic radii can accurately predict the martensitic transformation temperatures of NiTi-based shape memory alloys.

This paper develops the theory for a new class of type-1.5 superconducting nanowire single photon detectors based on two-bandgap superconductors like MgB2, showing that unique vortex-vortex interactions can lead to multiple vortex seeding from a single photon and suppressed dark counts.

This paper presents results from a comprehensive interlaboratory study on laser powder bed fusion involving 32 institutions, which used advanced statistical methods and machine learning on a dataset of over 1.2 million correlations to identify critical variability drivers across the entire production chain for metals and polymers.

This study experimentally and computationally investigates thermal transport in a series of rare earth sesquioxides and zirconates, finding that a reduction in thermal conductivity in multi-cation oxides is directly correlated to broadband optical phonon scattering caused by local bonding distortions.
