This work combines high-performance computing, machine learning, and molecular dynamics within an adaptive Bayesian optimization framework to enable asynchronous ensemble sampling of the synthesis space for van der Waals epitaxy, demonstrating its potential for on-demand materials discovery.

In response to the COVID-19 public health emergency, this paper describes the development of an online interactive dashboard at Johns Hopkins University to visualize and track reported cases, deaths, and recoveries in real time.

This mathematical modeling study used anonymized cell phone data to generate a social distancing metric for each US county, finding a strong correlation between the reduction in mobility and the reduction in COVID-19 transmission rates during the early phase of the pandemic.

This Personal View details the data collection, curation, and management system underlying the Johns Hopkins University COVID-19 Dashboard, covering the technical processes, challenges faced, and lessons learned during its operation as a global real-time surveillance system.
This entry refers to the COVID-19 Dashboard created by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering (CSSE) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU).
This is a correction to a previously published article about the interactive web-based dashboard to track COVID-19 in real time.

This paper introduces SafeTraffic Copilot, a system that adapts Large Language Models to perform expected traffic crash prediction as a text-reasoning task and then uses a novel attribution method to identify critical features for targeted safety interventions.

This paper introduces a feedback-informed epidemiological model that integrates a dynamic economic decision-making model with a compartmental disease model to show how accounting for disease-behavior feedback significantly impacts the predicted health and economic outcomes of public health policies.

This dissertation embodies engineering approaches to advance infectious disease modeling by developing multimodal machine learning frameworks for short-term forecasting and by creating a Feedback-Informed Epidemiological Model to simulate human health-wealth trade-offs in complex systems.

This paper introduces PandemicLLM, a framework that uses multi-modal large language models to reformulate real-time infectious disease forecasting as a text-reasoning problem, enabling the incorporation of complex, non-numerical information like public health policies and genomic data.

This work investigates the feasibility of using a society of generative agents powered by Large Language Models to simulate human health-related decision-making, using vaccine hesitancy as a case study to evaluate public health interventions in a simulated environment.

By analyzing 14 years of adverse event data from the FDA's MAUDE database, this retrospective study found 144 deaths and 1,391 injuries related to robotic surgery, with device malfunctions like falling broken instrument pieces and electrical arcing being common causes.

This paper demonstrates targeted cyber-physical attacks on teleoperated surgical robots that can cause catastrophic consequences and presents a dynamic model-based analysis framework that can detect and mitigate these malicious commands with 90% accuracy.

This article formalizes the definition of machine learning safety in terms of risk, epistemic uncertainty, and harm, and uses this framework to examine safety strategies across cyber-physical systems, decision sciences, and data products.

This article investigates the causes of safety-critical computer failures in medical devices by analyzing FDA recall and adverse event data, characterizing failure modes and their impact on patients to identify key safety issues.

This survey provides a comprehensive review of Healthcare Cognitive Assistants (HCAs), bridging a knowledge gap by identifying emerging trends, key challenges, design guidelines, and state-of-the-art technologies for researchers across multiple domains.

This paper proposes KnowSafe, a combined knowledge and data-driven approach for designing safety engines that can predict and mitigate hazards in cyber-physical systems like artificial pancreas systems by integrating domain-specific safety constraints with machine learning techniques.

This paper underscores the urgency of addressing cybersecurity in ML-enabled medical devices during the pre-market phase by analyzing public data on recalls and vulnerabilities, and introduces a suite of tools to assist security analysts in conducting comprehensive risk assessments.

This paper evaluates the resilience of a widely used advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) against safety-critical perception attacks, simulating various safety mechanisms to assess their impact on mitigating attacks and enhancing system resilience.

This paper evaluates the security of DNN-based Adaptive Cruise Control systems against runtime stealthy perception attacks, presenting a context-aware strategy for triggering attacks and an optimization-based method for generating image perturbations to cause forward collisions.

This paper introduces SAM, a technique that enables security analysts to perform System Theoretic Process Analysis for Security on ML-enabled medical devices during the design phase to foresee and mitigate risks from false data injection attacks at inference time.

This paper reviews the fundamental reaction processes and degradation mechanisms of NOx storage/reduction catalysts, covering NO oxidation, NOx sorption, reductant evolution, NOx release, and the impact of aging and sulfur poisoning on catalyst performance.

This study examines the interaction of molecular oxygen with the TiO2(110) surface, showing that O2 adsorption and dissociation only occur in the presence of surface oxygen vacancy defects, which can be quantified using water temperature-programmed desorption.

This paper reviews the process of methane catalytic cracking for producing carbon monoxide-free hydrogen, discussing its economic challenges compared to other methods and highlighting extensive research aimed at improving its efficiency and catalyst stability.

This review describes the history, configuration, and fundamental reactions of the diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC), covering its primary functions of oxidizing CO, hydrocarbons, and NO, as well as its deactivation mechanisms.

This study shows that molecular oxygen reacts with bridging OH groups formed at oxygen vacancy defects on the TiO2(110) surface, providing insights into photoexcited electron scavenging processes on TiO2 photocatalysts.

This disclosure describes a process for acrylonitrile manufacture using forced dynamic operation over transition metal promoted bismuth molybdate-based catalysts, which leverages catalyst lattice oxygen to improve acrylonitrile productivity and yield.
This study investigates the impact of sulfur and hydrothermal aging on the performance of Cu-CHA catalysts for NOx reduction in selective catalytic reduction systems.

This work utilizes an integrated experimental and kinetic modeling approach to examine the effect of combined hydrothermal aging and sulfur poisoning on the standard SCR reaction rate over Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts by modeling the transformation of Cu sites.
This study investigates how the speciation of copper within Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts influences their performance in various oxidation reactions relevant to selective catalytic reduction systems.
This study examines the effects of sulfur exposure on the speciation of copper and the ammonia storage capacity in SSZ-13 catalysts used for selective catalytic reduction.

This paper proposes TracKnee, a sensing knee sleeve with a stretchable conductive fabric sensor, and presents three models to calculate knee angles from voltage readings, which were evaluated in a user study with six participants.

This paper introduces a supervised-learning method to detect Parkinson's Disease action tremors from regular activities using data from wrist-worn accelerometers and gyroscopes, comparing hand-crafted features with CNN data-driven features.

This paper proposes MobiGesture, a mobility-aware hand gesture recognition system for healthcare that uses a novel segmentation algorithm and a Convolutional Neural Network to accurately classify hand gestures even when the user is moving.

This paper proposes TremorSense, a Parkinson's Disease hand tremor detection system that uses a Convolutional Neural Network and data from wrist-worn accelerometers and gyroscopes to classify rest, postural, and action tremors.

This paper designs a system that detects and predicts microsleep episodes using data from an EKG-capable heart rate monitor, achieving 96% detection accuracy and 83% prediction accuracy within 15 seconds to 5 minutes before the event.

This paper introduces DermaGlow, a novel wearable optical spectroscopy framework designed for low-cost, non-invasive, and continuous monitoring of melanin, erythema, and skin tone using an off-the-shelf spectrometer and a custom-designed 3D-printed enclosure.

This paper introduces a novel multi-wavelength optical sensing framework for calibration-free wearable blood pressure monitoring that utilizes a broad spectrum of wavelengths and interpretable features combined with machine learning to accurately estimate blood pressure.

This cohort study developed an ACL reinjury risk prediction model for adolescent athletes that accurately classifies an individual's risk, identifies modifiable risk factors, and ranks them to guide personalized rehabilitation.

This paper presents three meta-analyses integrating empirical data on the effects of interrupting task modality (auditory, tactile, visual) on the performance of an ongoing visual-manual task to support interruption management and multimodal interface design.

This study explores the applicability of Fitts' law to 3D pointing tasks in virtual reality using the Oculus Rift system, proposing a new formulation that accounts for the influence of target location specified in a spherical coordinate system.

To inform the design of multimodal cockpit interfaces, this paper presents a meta-analysis of 23 studies comparing the effectiveness of auditory versus tactile interruption signals, finding that while tactile interruptions yield faster responses, auditory signals are better for complex and urgent information.

Using performance and eye tracking metrics in a dual-task UAV simulation, this study investigated how constant versus variable workload levels affect operator attention, finding that sudden workload transitions led to better secondary task performance and more attention switching.

This paper highlights the critical but neglected step of crossmodal matching in multimodal research, demonstrating through an experiment that even minor variations in matching procedures can lead to significant differences in perceived stimulus intensities across senses.

This randomized, controlled, four-way crossover study assesses the effectiveness of four different deep learning-assisted reading modes for cervical cytopathology, finding that all DL-assisted modes improved diagnostic accuracy and efficiency compared to unassisted reading.

This paper surveys the research literature on tactile change blindness, summarizing findings on how parameters like the number of tactors, stimulus intensity, and distractors impact the human ability to detect changes in tactile signals, with the goal of improving haptic display design.

Using a two-alternative forced choice paradigm and EEG, this study compared tactile change detection for stimuli defined by intensity versus location, finding that while detection sensitivity was similar, behavioral responses to intensity-based changes were nearly 100 ms faster.

This study explores the feasibility of using gaze-based machine learning models to classify the mental demand of teammates in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle command-and-control teams, finding that a k-Nearest Neighbors classifier achieved the highest accuracy (81%) in predicting workload levels.

This review examines the development of smart textiles for personalized healthcare, covering different platform technologies, fabrication strategies, and clinical applications, while also exploring the commercial, regulatory, and data management landscapes.

This review comprehensively summarizes research advances in electronic textiles for wearable point-of-care systems, covering textile sensors for diagnosis, therapeutic devices for treatment, and protective devices for prevention, highlighting their working mechanisms and materials.

This review provides a comprehensive overview of the applications of nanogenerators as sustainable power sources and self-powered active sensors for smart cities in the era of 5G and IoT, covering areas like renewable energy, intelligent transportation, and digital healthcare.

This paper reports a giant magnetoelastic effect in a soft composite system of micromagnets dispersed in a silicone matrix, which, when combined with liquid-metal coils, can be used for stretchable and water-resistant magnetoelastic sensors and energy harvesters.

This paper describes the development of a muscle-fiber-inspired nonwoven piezoelectric textile made from polydopamine-enhanced barium titanate/polyvinylidene fluoride nanofibers, which exhibits tunable mechanical properties and high performance for wearable physiological monitoring.

This paper reports a soft, self-powered, on-eyelid magnetoelastic sensor that can capture eye-blink parameters in real time to quantitatively decode fatigue levels by converting eye movements into high-fidelity electrical signals.

This paper describes a diagnostic pen with a soft magnetoelastic tip and ferrofluid ink that, assisted by a convolutional neural network, can quantitatively analyze both on-surface and in-air handwriting motions to distinguish Parkinson's disease patients from healthy individuals with 96.22% accuracy.

This review provides a comprehensive overview of wearable biosensors based on two-dimensional materials, highlighting their unique properties, synthesis methods, and integration into flexible electronic systems for advancements in health monitoring and personalized medicine.

This paper describes a soft acoustic energy harvester based on the giant magnetoelastic effect that efficiently captures energy from low-density environmental sounds by converting multi-directional acoustic waves into electrical energy across a wide frequency range.

This paper describes a soft, portable intelligent keyboard that leverages magnetoelasticity to detect subtle pressure variations in keystroke dynamics, enabling the quantitative analysis of Parkinson's disease motor symptoms with machine learning.

In "Fighting Traffic," Peter Norton argues that the American city street was socially and physically reconstructed between 1915 and 1930 to accommodate automobiles, a violent revolution that redefined streets as motor thoroughfares and marginalized pedestrians.

This article argues that automotive interest groups in the 1910s and 1920s socially reconstructed the American street as a place for cars by promoting the term "jaywalker" to ridicule and delegitimize pedestrians' traditional use of street space.

To correct for ahistorical interpretations of traffic safety history, this paper proposes four approximately sequential paradigms for the twentieth-century United States: Safety First, Control, Crashworthiness, and Responsibility.

In "Autonorama," technology historian Peter Norton argues that the promise of high-tech driving and driverless cars is an illusion distracting us from investing in better, more humane mobility solutions that are available now.
This book, "Fighting Traffic," details the social and physical transformation of the American city street during the dawn of the motor age to accommodate the automobile.

This article argues that the typical American city street was radically transformed in the twentieth century by novel standards that prioritized vehicular functions, leading to the privatization of public space and the marginalization of other valuable urban uses.

This paper argues that a radical revision in public policy between 1920 and 1940 redefined American streets from public spaces for all to motor thoroughfares, shifting the burden of safety from the minority of motorists to the majority of pedestrians.

This book review of "Justice and the Interstates" critiques the anthology for presenting the racist history of urban highways in the United States as a new revelation, when in fact this truth has been recognized for over 50 years.

This book review of "No Bicycle, No Bus, No Job" praises Patrick Bek's work for addressing the under-examined history of power struggles over the responsibility for workers' daily journeys to and from their jobs in the Netherlands.
This is a book review of Thomas Zeller's "Consuming Landscapes," which examines driving as a constructed visual experience where road designers contrive scenic views for motorists.

This book chapter discusses the design of ultra-low-power systems, particularly focusing on register files and memories in sub-threshold circuits, which are critical for energy-constrained applications but dissipate significant leakage energy.

This article discusses the challenges and opportunities for body area sensor networks, highlighting that research must address obstacles like size, cost, and compatibility before such networks can become widespread in healthcare and beyond.

This paper provides an analytical solution for the optimum supply and threshold voltages to minimize energy in subthreshold circuits for a given frequency, and shows that minimum-sized devices are theoretically optimal for reducing energy consumption.

This paper explores the limits of low-voltage operation for SRAM, proposing an alternative bitcell that allows a 256-kb 65-nm test chip to operate in the sub-threshold region below 400 mV, offering substantial power savings for energy-constrained applications.

This paper presents an ultra-low power, batteryless, 19 μW body sensor node SoC that harvests energy to acquire, process, and transmit ECG, EMG, and EEG data, demonstrating heart rate extraction and atrial fibrillation detection while running solely on harvested power.
This paper describes the Everactive self-powered System-on-Chip, which integrates energy harvesting, a wakeup receiver, and an energy-aware subsystem for use in batteryless IoT applications.

This paper presents a compact, power-efficient I2C-to-SPI converter chip for distributed e-textile systems that uses an on-the-fly conversion scheme to eliminate the need for data buffers and internal clock generation, thereby reducing area and power consumption.

This paper presents a 0.36-mm2 I2C-to-SPI converter chip for E-textile applications that uses on-the-fly conversion to eliminate data buffers and clock generation, making it significantly smaller and more power-efficient than commercial alternatives.

This paper presents a comparison of various on-chip photovoltaic cell configurations implemented in a 65nm CMOS technology to characterize their performance and enable designers to select an optimal configuration for specific energy harvesting applications.

This study manufactured and tested colloidal-silver-impregnated ceramic filters for household water treatment, quantifying their flow rate, pore-size distribution, and effectiveness in removing Escherichia coli bacteria.

This study quantitatively evaluates the coagulant properties of Opuntia spp. cactus for water treatment, finding it reduces turbidity by 98% in synthetic water samples and likely operates through an interparticle bridging mechanism.

This study investigated tetrachloromethane sorption from water to bentonite clay modified with ten different quaternary ammonium cations, finding that sorption behavior is characterized by either nonlinear adsorption or linear partitioning depending on the structure of the organic cation.

This study investigated the sorption of nonionic organic contaminants to bentonite clay modified with single and dual organic cations, finding that long-chain alkyl groups interfere with adsorption while creating a partition medium for the solutes.

This article discusses the unequal global distribution of water quality and quantity, noting that developing countries often have less capacity to improve water quality and depend on lower-quality water for various uses, including drinking.

This study reports on a randomized controlled trial in rural South Africa that found no significant association between the use of two point-of-use water treatment technologies and the cognitive scores of children under five years old after two years of follow-up.

This study evaluates the larvicidal effects of silver, copper, and hypochlorite ions, finding that their combined application yields greater efficacy in suppressing the emergence of Aedes aegypti from household water storage containers compared to individual disinfectants alone.

This study optimized and evaluated laboratory methods for detecting viable Campylobacter and Shigella bacteria in water and raw cow milk using viability polymerase chain reaction (PCR), identifying the most effective concentration and DNA extraction protocols for each sample type.
This is a correction to a previously published article about the effectiveness of a silver-ceramic technology for disinfecting drinking water in school tanks in rural India.

This study assessed the larvicidal effects of silver, copper, and chlorine disinfectants on Aedes aegypti larvae at concentrations below drinking water limits, finding that sodium hypochlorite was most effective against early instars while silver nitrate was most effective against late instars.

This perspective article summarizes the recent development of lanthanum-based perovskite oxides as advanced, tunable catalysts for energy conversion applications and traditional heterogeneous reactions, highlighting their potential to replace noble metals.

This study synthesized sub-10 nm nanoparticles of M(II)-substituted magnetite (MxFe3-xO4) and found that MnFe2O4 nanoparticles supported on carbon are as efficient as commercial Pt in catalyzing the oxygen reduction reaction in alkaline solution.

This paper reports that FePt and CoPt nanowires supported on carbon exhibit enhanced catalytic activity and stability for the oxygen reduction reaction in acidic media compared to commercial Pt/C catalysts.

This paper describes a new approach to synthesize fully ordered face-centered tetragonal FePt nanoparticles that serve as a robust and highly active electrocatalyst for both the oxygen reduction reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction in acidic media.

This study synthesized ~9 nm hard-magnet L10-CoPt/Pt core/shell nanoparticles that exhibit enhanced activity and durability for the oxygen reduction reaction in fuel cells, exceeding DOE 2020 targets due to the ligand effect of Co and biaxial strain on the Pt shell.

This study demonstrates a sustainable route to polymer-grade ethylene by using 45 nm Cu nanocubes for the electrocatalytic semihydrogenation of acetylene in a flow reactor, achieving high ethylene selectivity and Faradaic efficiency while removing acetylene to parts-per-million levels.

This work synthesized core/shell Cu/CuAu nanocubes with precisely controlled ordered intermetallic layers, demonstrating that strain relaxation in the shell enhances the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction to produce ammonia with high efficiency and yield.

This review highlights recent advances in catalyst design, quantification methods, and intermediate identification for the electrocatalytic synthesis of urea via C-N coupling, and explores future prospects for alternative C-N coupling products.

This study reports that single-atom molybdenum doping in NiO significantly enhances its alkaline hydrogen evolution reaction activity by promoting the in situ transformation of NiO to active Ni(OH)2 sites, which accelerates the rate-limiting water dissociation step.

This work investigates the structural evolution of CuNi nanoparticle electrocatalysts during CO2 reduction, finding that cathodic corrosion leads to Ni loss and the formation of defect-rich Cu nanoparticles, which enhances the Faradaic efficiency of multi-carbon products.

A longitudinal qualitative study of 47 students in three countries reveals that while most have instrumental reasons for studying, they are personally committed to the knowledge in their field and see it playing a key role in their future lives, challenging the simple dichotomy of students-as-consumers versus personal transformation.

This qualitative study of first-year STEM students at a large research university found a pattern of low engagement with their discipline's professional community, with most impactful socialization occurring prior to their enrollment in their chosen major.

This dissertation uses a longitudinal embedded case study to explore how the socialization experiences of eight STEM students over four years influence their sense of belonging to both their discipline and their university.

This paper describes the process and challenges of creating an interdisciplinary senior capstone course at a large research university to better prepare engineering students for the collaborative, cross-disciplinary work environment they will face after graduation.

This GIFT paper describes a creative reflection assignment for first-year engineering students at the end of a semester, designed to help them synthesize their learning and connect their personal values and hobbies with their engineering work.

This Work-In-Progress paper describes an intervention using Challenge Essential Questions to help first-year engineering students make meaningful connections between technical and sociotechnical content in a foundational engineering program.
This book systematically studies the analysis and design of control systems with actuator saturation, a ubiquitous and theoretically challenging nonlinearity in engineering systems.

This paper revisits the problem of multi-agent flocking, showing that even when only a fraction of agents are informed about a virtual leader's velocity, a previously proposed algorithm can still enable all agents to achieve the desired group movement.

This survey paper offers a detailed overview of discrete-time and continuous-time distributed optimization algorithms for multi-agent systems, discussing their extensions and applications, particularly in power systems.

This paper presents a method for estimating the domain of attraction for a linear system under a saturated feedback, deriving a simple condition in terms of an auxiliary feedback matrix that can be expressed as linear matrix inequalities for controller synthesis.
This book chapter discusses the use of low-gain feedback for a class of multi-input multi-output nonlinear systems that are input-output linearizable and of minimum-phase.

This article develops a novel distributed control architecture for multi-robot systems that integrates adaptive neural networks with projection-based pseudogradient dynamics to enable each robot to seek its Nash equilibrium strategy without global information or prior knowledge of disturbances.

This paper proposes a distributed secondary control scheme for energy storage units in a droop-controlled DC microgrid that simultaneously achieves global voltage regulation, proportional power sharing, and state-of-energy balancing using two auxiliary control inputs.

This paper investigates the state-of-charge balancing control problem for a battery energy storage system, introducing the concept of "powered SoC" and designing a new power allocating controller that achieves accelerated balancing speed.

This paper presents a novel privacy-preserving distributed control algorithm for state-of-charge balancing in a networked Battery Energy Storage System, which uses two distributed estimators to ensure asymptotic balancing and accurate power delivery while safeguarding agent privacy.

This work presents a compact and physically realizable Langevin model, called an Oscillator Potts Machine, that serves as a sampler for finding the low-energy spin configurations of the standard Potts model.

This paper describes HotSpot, an accurate and fast thermal model for microprocessors, and introduces several effective dynamic thermal management techniques such as temperature-tracking frequency scaling and migrating computation to regulate operating temperature.
This paper proposes the bus-invert method of coding I/O, which lowers bus activity to decrease peak power dissipation by 50% and average power dissipation by up to 25% for CMOS circuits.

This paper presents HotSpot, a computationally efficient compact thermal modeling methodology for early-stage VLSI design that provides detailed static and transient temperature information across the die and package, including an on-chip interconnect self-heating model.

This paper describes HotSpot, an accurate and fast thermal model for microarchitectural studies, and introduces several effective dynamic thermal management methods, including temperature-tracking frequency scaling and migrating computation to spare hardware units.

This paper proposes using formal feedback control theory, specifically a PID controller, for adaptive dynamic thermal management in processors and develops an efficient thermal-RC model to accurately test the proposed fetch "toggling" mechanism.

This paper explores the potential of adiabatic logic circuits in modern FinFET technologies, demonstrating through simulation that they can achieve significant power savings at higher clock rates than previously possible, making them a viable solution for ultra-low power ICs.

This paper presents a Virtualized Computational RFID solution for Industry 4.0 applications that keeps tags minimalistic by offloading computational tasks to the reader, enabling a 97% reduction in energy consumption for battery-less, fine-grain monitoring.

This paper presents Cool-3D, an end-to-end, thermal-aware framework for early-phase design space exploration of microfluidic-cooled 3D integrated circuits that integrates architectural simulators with advanced cooling models to enable flexible and accurate modeling.

This work proposes a highly sensitive UHF RF energy harvesting circuit in a 22-nm FDSOI technology by optimizing a combined RF-DC rectifier with a DC-DC converter, using techniques like flipped well transistors and dynamic leakage suppression to improve performance.

This book, "Modern Electroplating, Fifth Edition," serves as a comprehensive, one-stop reference to the latest methods and applications of electroplating metals, alloys, and semiconductors, with special emphasis on nanotechnologies, data storage, and medical applications.

This book provides new insights into the theoretical and applied aspects of metal electrodeposition, covering the electrochemistry of metals, the technology of deposition, and the properties and structure of coatings for advanced students and researchers.

This paper reviews fundamental and technological issues in alkaline and PEM water electrolysis, arguing that advancements in non-PGM catalysts are poised to benefit alkaline electrolyzers, and presents data showing an advanced alkaline electrolyzer with performance rivaling PEM devices.

This study investigated the corrosion behavior of autocatalytically deposited Ni-P based alloy films in sulfuric acid, finding that while they do not passivate like pure Ni, their corrosion resistance improves with increasing P content and can be further enhanced by adding W.

This paper describes the fabrication and magnetic properties of Fe and Co nanowires deposited in the hexagonally ordered nanopores of anodized alumina, achieving excellent hexagonal ordering and high out-of-plane coercivity.

This work explores the electrodeposition of smooth, near-equiatomic CoCuFeNi multi-principal element alloys from glycine-citrate electrolytes, investigating the influence of deposition parameters on film composition and morphology.

This presentation discusses industrial applications of combined electrodeposition and physical vapor deposition techniques for creating metal and alloy coatings on fashion accessories with high resistance to corrosion and wear.

This work successfully synthesized near-equiatomic CoCuFeNi multi-principal element alloy films via electrodeposition from an acidic glycine-citrate-Triton X-100 electrolyte, demonstrating control over composition and morphology to produce a single crystalline phase.

By profiling over 700 longitudinal specimens from large B cell lymphoma patients treated with CAR19 T cells, this study identifies multiple classes of gene alterations associated with resistance, including those in B cell identity, immune checkpoints, and the tumor microenvironment.

This review discusses the application of focused ultrasound in conjunction with microbubbles to transiently and non-invasively disrupt the blood-brain barrier, enabling localized delivery of therapeutics and demonstrating potential for neuromodulation and other physiological responses.

This review highlights the intracellular and extracellular barriers to T cell infiltration into tumors, such as deficient homing receptor ligands on tumor vasculature, and discusses multiple therapeutic approaches that show promise in enhancing immune-mediated cancer control.

This paper contends that MR image-guided focused ultrasound represents a noninvasive approach for favorable therapeutic immunomodulation in the central nervous system, particularly by overcoming the blood-brain barrier to enable effective drug delivery.

This paper provides an updated perspective on the progress of focused ultrasound immunotherapy over the last two years, highlighting its potential as a non-invasive technique for eliciting immune mechanisms in cancer and other pathologies.

This work presents the design and evaluation of a preclinical PET insert for simultaneous operation with MRI and FUS systems, a step towards creating a trimodal PET-MRI-FUS system for monitoring therapeutic effects during focused ultrasound applications.

This study aims to improve the efficacy of B7-H3-directed CAR T-cell therapy for aggressive Group 3 medulloblastoma by using the TLR7/8 agonist Resiquimod to reprogram immunosuppressive macrophages and low-intensity focused ultrasound to enhance drug and CAR T-cell infiltration across the blood-brain barrier.

This review addresses the two predominant barriers to CAR-T cell therapy efficacy in brain malignancies—cellular trafficking and persistence—by discussing the underlying limiting mechanisms and evaluating current and novel strategies to overcome these challenges.

This review spotlights recent advancements in therapeutic focused ultrasound for breast cancer care, outlining its physical principles and multifaceted roles in tumor ablation, drug delivery, radiosensitization, and enhancement of tumor-specific immune responses.

This study investigated whether the timing of melanoma brain metastasis seeding in a two-site mouse model impacts the intracranial efficacy of systemic anti-CD40 agonist therapy, a treatment aimed at improving the anti-tumoral immune response.

This paper derives and validates speckle reducing anisotropic diffusion (SRAD), a partial differential equation-based filtering method tailored to ultrasonic and radar imaging that acts as an edge-sensitive diffusion for speckled images.

This study shows that meningeal lymphatic vessels drain macromolecules from the central nervous system into cervical lymph nodes, and that impairment of this function in aged mice slows waste clearance and induces cognitive impairment, which can be reversed by treatment with vascular endothelial growth factor C.

This paper proposes a new external force for active contours called vector field convolution (VFC), which addresses problems like limited capture range and poor convergence to concavities by convolving the image edge map with a user-defined vector field kernel.

This paper presents a computationally efficient image enhancement algorithm for JPEG-compressed images that operates in the decompression stage, based on a contrast measure defined within the discrete cosine transform domain.

This study demonstrates that chronic, partial microglia depletion is sufficient for peripherally derived macrophages to engraft the brain without irradiation, where they maintain a unique functional and transcriptional identity distinct from microglia without altering behavior.

This paper introduces a dynamic predictive transformer network for skeleton-based action detection that incorporates future frame data during training and an adaptive temporal attention system to improve temporal analysis and boundary frame detection.

This paper proposes PSF-SRDN, a novel point spread function-aware speckle reducing diffusion network that encodes the spectrum of lateral and axial distortions to enable adaptive denoising of ultrasound images corrupted with signal-dependent speckle.

This article argues that while AI can now classify classroom activity structures, it is the instructional activities within those structures that matter for student learning, and teacher dashboards powered by AI could support advancements in instruction.

This paper shows that the dynamic average consensus algorithm can be applied to improve object detection classifier accuracy in a multi-camera network by averaging the latent features extracted from each camera's detection network.

This paper introduces a novel technique for evaluating student attentiveness in classrooms by analyzing their 3D eye gaze direction, derived from a new 3D head pose estimation algorithm that does not require frontal face information.

This study quantified structural changes in the aging bony thorax using CT scans and a finite element model, finding that ribs become more perpendicular to the spine with age, a change that significantly increases the risk of rib fracture in simulated frontal impacts.

This study used elastic-viscoelastic correspondence to derive solutions for spherical indentation load-relaxation tests on soft biological tissues, demonstrating the method's utility in obtaining material properties like shear modulus and time constants for rubber, kidney tissue, and costal cartilage.

By analyzing the National Trauma Databank, this study found that the presence of rib fractures (AIS 3+) significantly increases fatality risk in motor vehicle crash patients, with the effect being more pronounced in younger adults (18-45) than in older adults (over 64).

This study evaluated the skeletal deformation of restrained post-mortem human subjects in 40 km/h frontal sled tests, finding that anterior and superior displacement of the lower ribcage may have contributed to early sternal fractures at lower-than-expected displacement levels.

This paper describes methods for determining the specific causation of spinal injuries in motor vehicle collisions by analyzing injury rates from national databases and reviewing the biomechanical literature to distinguish acute injuries from chronic degenerative disease.
This document lists the editorial review board for Volume 64 of the Stapp Car Crash Journal, a leading publication in the field of impact biomechanics and automotive safety.

This paper describes the development of mandatory testing and maintenance practices for synthetic turf fields in the National Football League, based on a literature review and expert opinion, to improve the consistency and safety of playing surfaces.

This patent describes a mobile, automated apparatus for measuring controlled and applied forces and moments on sport surfaces like artificial turf to assess the performance and safety of athletic apparel and surfaces.

This review navigates the four stages of wound healing to explore the interplay between fibroblasts, the extracellular matrix, and inflammation in scar formation, arguing that a systems-level understanding is necessary to replicate fetal scarless healing.

This article summarizes the known effects of lactate and associated H+ ions on immune cells, highlighting their generally immunosuppressive but context-specific roles in augmenting certain immune functions, with implications for cancer, sepsis, and autoimmunity.

This study shows that lactic acid suppresses IL-33-mediated mast cell inflammatory responses in a pH-dependent manner by enhancing hypoxia-inducible factor-1α, which in turn suppresses miR-155, a key regulator of IL-33 signaling.

This study demonstrates that lactic acid inhibits lipopolysaccharide-induced mast cell function by limiting glycolysis and ATP availability, a mechanism that is dependent on monocarboxylate transporter-1 and may contribute to the immunosuppressive phase of sepsis.

This review explores the crosstalk between T cells and fibroblasts in the context of biomaterial-induced fibrosis, highlighting how different T cell subsets can modulate fibroblast activity and contribute to the foreign body response that leads to implant failure.

This study identifies a distinct Thy-1-negative immunofibroblast population that emerges in response to inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and TNFα as a key determinant of fibrotic encapsulation around biomaterials.

This study reveals that the inflammatory cytokine IL-33 induces the expression of miR-146a in mast cells, which then acts as a feedback inhibitor to negatively regulate IL-33-mediated mast cell function.

Using single-cell analysis, this study found that decreased circulating monocytes are associated with persistent pulmonary fibrosis and reduced lung function in post-COVID patients, an immune signature that resembles idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

This paper describes the HPN-DREAM community challenge, which demonstrated through the assessment of over 2,000 submitted networks that inferring causal molecular relationships from complex biological data is feasible, especially when incorporating prior biological knowledge.

This paper theoretically proves that linear transformers, when trained on random linear regression tasks, can learn to implement iterations of preconditioned gradient descent in their forward pass, with the preconditioning matrix adapting to both the input distribution and data variance.

This paper shows that the inherent variance of stochastic gradients in certain non-convex models has a strong component along negative curvature directions, enabling plain SGD to escape saddle points without explicit noise injection and achieving a dimension-independent convergence rate.

This paper provides a theoretical explanation for Batch Normalization's success, proving it accelerates optimization by decoupling the length and direction of parameters, which allows gradient-based methods to leverage a favorable global loss landscape and achieve exponential convergence rates in certain non-convex settings.

This paper provides a theoretical framework and an efficient soft-thresholding algorithm for inferring hidden network structures from diffusion cascades, establishing that the correct structure can be recovered with high probability given a sufficient number of observations.

This study shows that a linear transformer trained on matrix completion tasks implicitly discovers a single, unified, resource-adaptive iterative solver that spans prediction, estimation, and Nyström extrapolation without being explicitly programmed to do so.

This paper proposes a novel, estimation-free generative method that uses deterministic gradient descent on a set of interacting particles to transport a uniform distribution to an arbitrary data distribution, avoiding the need for function estimation, neural networks, or noise injection.

This paper demonstrates both empirically and theoretically that a transformer, when trained on policy evaluation tasks, can discover and learn to implement temporal difference learning in its forward pass, providing a mechanism for in-context reinforcement learning.

This paper proves that a transformer with fixed parameters can effectively solve the optimal transport problem by implementing an adaptive gradient descent algorithm on the dual problem, demonstrating that prompt engineering and network depth are essential for its algorithmic expressivity and performance.

Through a mixed-methods study of 527 users in China, this paper explores live streaming practices, revealing how content, reward systems, and fan groups engage users, and highlighting a desire for deeper interaction mechanisms.

This paper introduces Thor's Hammer, a novel handheld haptic device that uses six propellers to generate up to 4 Newtons of ungrounded, 3-DOF force feedback, enhancing realism and immersion in virtual reality applications.

This paper explores a pre-touch sensing modality on mobile devices that detects fingers hovering above the screen, enabling novel interactions such as anticipatory user interfaces and hybrid touch-hover gestures.

This paper introduces SplitBoard, a simple split soft keyboard for smartwatches that allows users to flick between halves of a QWERTY layout, which outperformed other text entry methods in user studies for initial performance and learnability.

This paper introduces ThingMoji, a novel form of user-captured visual cut-outs that allows live stream viewers to create and share unique icons from the stream content, enhancing expressive communication between streamers and their audience.

This paper presents SpaceShare, a video meeting system that integrates real-time 3D space reconstruction and leverages multimodal context to enable fluid spatial sharing, independent exploration, and conversational retrieval of spatial features.

This paper presents CustomSight, an LLM-powered assistive technology that helps blind and visually impaired users query their visual environment by using goal-directed dynamic filters to provide real-time camera framing guidance and automated image capture.

This paper proposes Thing2Reality, an Extended Reality meeting platform that uses generative AI to enable users to spontaneously create and share 3D objects from 2D content, facilitating collaborative discussions in immersive environments.

This paper introduces DialogLab, a prototyping toolkit that provides a unified interface for authoring, simulating, and testing complex, dynamic multi-party conversations involving both humans and AI agents.

This paper proposes and applies a parallel adaptive mesh refinement algorithm using a fully coupled finite-volume formulation to efficiently predict steady, three-dimensional, turbulent, non-premixed, compressible combusting flows.

This paper proposes a parallel adaptive mesh refinement algorithm that uses a fully coupled finite-volume formulation and a flexible block-based data structure to efficiently predict turbulent non-premixed combusting flows.

Using two-dimensional simulations, this study examines lean turbulent methane-air flames with hydrogen addition, finding that hydrogen significantly modulates methane chemistry, leading to a strong positive correlation between local burning speed and flame curvature.

This paper presents a parallel adaptive mesh refinement algorithm using a fully coupled finite-volume formulation to predict two-dimensional laminar and turbulent non-premixed combusting flows, demonstrating its validity through comparisons with experimental data.

This study uses numerical simulations to show that localized hotspots created by thermodiffusive instabilities in lean premixed turbulent hydrogen flames lead to significant production of nitrogen oxides, even at temperatures well below 1800K.

This work proposes a new framework for a quantum algorithm to solve the incompressible nonlinear Navier-Stokes equations, using matrix product states and operators combined with Krylov subspace methods to represent and evolve the system efficiently on quantum computers.

This paper evaluates the parallel performance of HashBrick, a novel brick-based hash-table CFD library, demonstrating its performance portability and efficiency for distributed computing on heterogeneous CPU-GPU architectures through a weak-scaling study.

This paper analyzes two-level additive overlapping domain decomposition methods for finite volume discretizations of elliptic problems, proving that the condition number of the preconditioned system does not depend on the number of subdomains.

This paper applies a novel fourth-order accurate finite-volume method with adaptive mesh refinement in space and time to a multifluid plasma model, demonstrating improved solution stability and a significant reduction in compute time for complex test cases involving shocks.

This study found that during human walking at different speeds, the angular momentum of the body about its center of mass is small and highly regulated, with the arms and trunk making the largest contributions.

This study used the uncontrolled manifold hypothesis to demonstrate that synergies among segmental angular momenta exist during the swing phase of walking to stabilize the whole-body angular momentum.

This double-blinded randomized controlled trial evaluated the effects of a 4-week rehabilitation program combined with patterned electrical neuromuscular stimulation on lower-extremity biomechanics and muscle activity in females with patellofemoral pain.
This study found that wearing ankle foot orthoses increased stride length and energy recovery during walking in children with cerebral palsy, without changing the total mechanical work performed.

This cross-sectional study compared lower-extremity and lumbar spine stiffness during a landing task between individuals with and without a history of low back pain to identify potential biomechanical adaptations.

This study developed and validated an augmented full-body musculoskeletal model that adds joints to the spine and shoulders, significantly improving the accuracy of upper body kinematic tracking and reducing dynamic inconsistency during complex sports motions.

This prospective study demonstrates that a new "Coin Test" is a highly specific and sensitive tool for assessing upper extremity function and diagnosing cervical spondylotic myelopathy, showing significant improvement in patient performance after surgery.

This study compared the complexity of quadriceps torque fluctuations during maximal isometric contraction between individuals with anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, their contralateral limb, and healthy controls to assess its relationship with patient outcomes.

This study found that patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy showed significant improvements in gait velocity, step length, and postural stability at 3 and 6 months following cervical decompression surgery.

This study provides a comprehensive biomechanical analysis of the rat hindlimb during walking, characterizing spatiotemporal parameters, ground reaction forces, 3D joint kinematics, kinetics, and energetics to establish a baseline for preclinical models of extremity injury.

This paper reviews the corrosion of additively manufactured alloys, correlating their performance to unique microstructural features like porosity, grain structure, and residual stress that result from the manufacturing process.

This study used in situ confocal laser scanning microscopy to investigate the localized corrosion of intermetallic particles on AA 2024-T3, finding that the type and rate of attack are controlled by galvanic coupling between the particles and the alloy matrix.

This paper explains the passivity breakdown and pitting corrosion of binary alloys using a percolation model where a passive oxide layer forms only when the concentration of the more noble element exceeds a critical threshold.

This study uses in situ confocal laser scanning microscopy to investigate trench formation around cathodic particles on AA 2024-T3, concluding that an anodic trench model best explains the observed corrosion behavior.

This study presents a unifying quantitative framework that connects the repassivation potential of stainless steels to key electrochemical and chemical parameters, demonstrating that molybdenum in SS316L enhances repassivation by suppressing anodic and accelerating cathodic kinetics.
This is an editorial titled "How to Do Continuity" from The Electrochemical Society Interface.

This study uses a combined experimental and computational approach to evaluate the effectiveness of a sacrificial ZnNi plating in mitigating galvanically induced environmental-assisted cracking of a Pyrowear 675-anodized titanium assembly.

In this editorial from The Electrochemical Society Interface, the author humorously reflects on his personal struggles with pool chemistry, drawing parallels to his professional life as an electrochemist.

This work experimentally and computationally compares a sol-gel barrier coating and a sacrificially pigmented polymer coating for their effectiveness in mitigating galvanic corrosion on AA7075 coupled to steel.

This first-principles study systematically investigates how 14 different alloying elements affect the generalized stacking fault energy, ideal shear strength, and twinnability of dilute magnesium alloys.

This paper presents a comprehensive first-principles study calculating the temperature-dependent tracer diffusion coefficients for 47 different alloying elements in dilute hexagonal close-packed magnesium.

This study demonstrates the growth of high-mobility La-doped BaSnO3 films by molecular-beam epitaxy in an adsorption-controlled regime, suggesting that defects other than threading dislocations are the primary limiters of electron mobility.

This paper reports a comprehensive first-principles study that calculates and compiles vacancy formation energies, migration energies, and self-diffusion coefficients as a function of temperature for 82 pure elements.

This paper presents a novel thermodynamic theory for first-principles calculations of Seebeck coefficients that, unlike traditional methods, does not rely on assumptions about electron-scattering mechanisms.

This article discusses the opportunities and challenges of developing single-layer, multicomponent rare earth oxide coatings for refractory alloys to serve as thermal and environmental barriers in combustion environments.

This paper develops a hybrid computational thermodynamics framework that combines the Cluster Variation Method and CALPHAD to efficiently and reliably predict chemical short-range order in multicomponent alloys.

This study develops a CALPHAD thermodynamic model of the Hf-Ta-O system, in conjunction with experimental and first-principles data, to improve the understanding of the oxidation resistance of HfC-TaC ultra-high temperature ceramics.

Using advanced electron microscopy and thermodynamic modeling, this study reveals that the surface oxide on tantalum has fewer suboxides and a more abrupt transition to the base metal compared to niobium, potentially explaining its lower loss in superconducting quantum circuits.

This paper quantitatively compares four common algorithms for tracking single fluorescent particles in noisy images, finding that cross-correlation provides the best combination of accuracy and precision for a wide range of particle sizes.

Using a laser trap, this study shows that the actomyosin bond behaves as a "catch" bond, with increasing lifetimes under increasing loads, and surprisingly finds that the myosin-ADP bond is stronger under load than the rigor bond.

Using a laser trap and mean-variance analysis, this study found that single molecules of smooth and skeletal muscle myosin produce similar unitary forces and displacements, suggesting that differences in their force-generating capacity and velocity are due to cross-bridge kinetics rather than individual mechanical events.

Using an optical-trap transducer, this study found that double-headed smooth- and skeletal-muscle myosins produce approximately twice the unitary displacement and force of their single-headed counterparts, suggesting that both heads are required for maximal force and motion.

This paper presents a detailed method for teaching undergraduate students the full scientific publishing process, including anonymous peer review and revision, through a term paper assignment in a cell and molecular biology course.

This paper examines the impact of redesigning a first-year engineering curriculum by integrating a technical design course with a sociotechnical concepts course into a single sequence, aiming to improve students' understanding of the engineering design process.

This patent describes a thermal disinfection system for plumbing that uses a heating device in contact with a liquid-carrying conduit, covered by an insulating layer, to heat the conduit's lumen and prevent microbial growth.

This study demonstrates that a novel electronic tailpiece heater, when set to 75°C, effectively prevents the upward growth of bacterial biofilm from a sink's p-trap, offering a promising approach to prevent the spread of resistant bacteria in hospitals.

This paper explores the impact of experiential learning in biomedical engineering education, arguing that hands-on, real-world experiences like clinical and research projects are crucial for developing problem-solving skills and understanding user needs.

This paper shows that an injectable, interconnected microporous gel scaffold, assembled from annealed microgel building blocks, can circumvent the limitations of traditional hydrogels by facilitating rapid cell migration and tissue regeneration in vivo.

This study shows that slowing the degradation of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) scaffolds by using d-chiral peptides unexpectedly elicits an antigen-specific adaptive immune response that imparts significant regenerative wound healing, including hair neogenesis.

This paper describes the synthesis and characterization of photodegradable hydrogels incorporating ortho-nitrobenzyl groups, which allow for external real-time spatial and temporal control over hydrogel degradation for the staged release of encapsulated cells.

This paper discusses the formation of injectable, in situ forming microporous scaffolds from hyaluronic acid-based microgel particles, an emerging platform that mimics the extracellular matrix while allowing for enhanced cell integration.

This paper presents a photodegradable hydrogel based on an ortho-nitrobenzylether moiety that can be used as a biocompatible photoresist to create both positive and negative features over a broad range of length scales using single- and two-photon degradation.

This study investigates the use of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) gel as an injectable, granular scaffold to enhance islet viability, promote engraftment, and modulate immune responses in both syngeneic and xenogeneic transplantation settings for diabetes management.

This study evaluates microporous annealed particle (MAP) gel as a supportive scaffold for dissociated murine islet transplantation, demonstrating that it enhances engraftment and restores normoglycemia in a syngeneic mouse model of diabetes.

This patent describes compositions and methods for treating Type 1 diabetes by administering a suspension of pancreatic islet cells contained within or encapsulated by an injectable, microporous annealed particle (MAP) scaffold.

This study demonstrates a reliable rabbit model of acute laryngeal injury that reproduces the acute wound process seen clinically, characterized by significant posterior glottic thickening and a shift towards active collagen formation consistent with early scar development.

This study investigates the use of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) gel as a scaffold for islet transplantation, showing that it restores and maintains normoglycemia in diabetic mice when co-transplanted with dissociated islet cells.

This paper discusses the TreadMarks distributed shared memory system, which allows parallel programs to run on a network of workstations by providing the abstraction of a globally shared virtual memory.

This paper presents a parallel algorithm for Metropolis-coupled Markov chain Monte Carlo that retains the ability to explore multiple peaks in the posterior distribution of phylogenetic trees while achieving nearly linear speed improvement through parallelization.

This paper presents a performance evaluation of TreadMarks, a user-level distributed shared memory system, demonstrating good speedups for several applications on an 8-processor ATM network and supporting the viability of DSM for parallel computation on workstation clusters.

This paper presents pSearch, a decentralized, non-flooding peer-to-peer information retrieval system that distributes document indices based on their semantics to reduce search costs and improve efficiency.

This paper describes and evaluates a multiple clock domain processor architecture where the chip is divided into several domains that can be independently scaled in voltage and frequency to achieve significant energy savings.

This paper introduces JSPIM, a skew-aware Processing-in-Memory accelerator that co-designs the algorithm and hardware to accelerate database join and select queries by deploying parallel search engines and redesigned hash tables to achieve significant speedups.

This paper characterizes the performance of a PIM-enabled GPU system when co-executing regular GPU kernels with PIM kernels, finding that memory saturation by PIM can lead to extreme unfairness and proposing a concurrent servicing mechanism to mitigate this issue.

This patent describes the RollingCache system, a method to defend against cache side-channel attacks by dynamically changing the set of addresses contending for cache sets using one or more levels of indirection controlled by whole-cache runtime behavior.

This paper presents RollingCache, a cache design that defends against contention-based side channel attacks by dynamically and non-deterministically changing the mapping of addresses to cache sets based on whole-cache runtime behavior.

This paper presents RELIEF, an online, least laxity-driven accelerator scheduling policy that relieves memory pressure in accelerator-rich architectures by being aware of and prioritizing data movement opportunities like peer-to-peer DMA.

This paper addresses the challenge of specifying system requirements for finite-state verification tools by proposing a pattern-based approach to codify and reuse common property specifications, making them more accessible to practitioners.

This paper describes Bandera, an integrated collection of program analysis and transformation components that enables the automatic extraction of safe, compact, finite-state models from Java source code for use in model checking.

This paper proposes a pattern-based approach to the presentation, codification, and reuse of property specifications for finite-state verification to address the challenge practitioners face in translating informal requirements into formal specification languages.

This paper develops a family of greedy combinatorial interaction testing algorithms that leverage modern Boolean satisfiability solvers to efficiently construct test suites for highly-configurable systems with constraints between parameters.

This paper introduces differential symbolic execution, a novel technique that computes a precise behavioral characterization of a program change by exploiting similarities between program versions to reduce analysis cost and improve results.

This work introduces LoCaL, a new benchmark for code evaluation metrics that includes code pairs designed to be surface-similar but functionally dissimilar, revealing that state-of-the-art reference-based metrics are strongly biased towards surface-level features rather than code functionality.

This paper presents and evaluates NeuralSAT, a high-performance verification tool for Deep Neural Networks that uses the DPLL(T) framework and has demonstrated competitive performance and versatility in recent VNN-COMP competitions.

This systematic literature review analyzes 29 studies to identify instructor strategies for implementing active learning in STEM classrooms and addressing negative student responses, finding that strategies often focus on explaining the benefits of active learning and providing structure.

This systematic literature review of 57 STEM studies examines the reasons behind students' negative responses to active learning, identifying six overarching categories including perceived limited value, lack of time, and increased difficulty.

This review discusses bilevel optimization methods for learning parameters in image reconstruction problems, where prior assumptions are learned from training data to improve the recovery of unknown variables from collected measurements.

This paper presents an overview of a systematic literature review of 412 studies on students' affective responses to active learning in undergraduate STEM courses, finding that responses are overwhelmingly positive but that few studies received a high quality score.

Through interviews with faculty, students, and practicing engineers, this paper investigates instructional factors that influence conceptual understanding of signals and systems, identifying practices like lectures that connect concepts to math and hands-on activities with immediate feedback.

This paper presents the design of an introductory machine learning course for first and second-year undergraduates that emphasizes the mathematical perspective and conceptual understanding behind ML algorithms without requiring advanced math prerequisites.

This research investigates the hardware troubleshooting methods used by undergraduate electrical engineering students when working with breadboarded circuits, aiming to identify common strategies to help educators improve students' troubleshooting ability.

This study examines the efficacy of integrating structured troubleshooting training modules into a chemical engineering laboratory course, finding that the modules improved students' troubleshooting skills during a hands-on exercise.

This study assesses the experimental self-efficacy and troubleshooting abilities of fourth-year chemical engineering students, finding that while students were confident in their conceptual understanding, they often resorted to less effective troubleshooting strategies like simply following directions or random guessing.

This paper presents and characterizes Rodinia, a benchmark suite of applications and kernels designed for heterogeneous computing platforms like multi-core CPUs and GPUs, which covers a wide range of parallel patterns and has led to important architectural insights.

This article discusses the potential of CUDA as a scalable parallel programming model that allows application developers to leverage the increasing number of processor cores in mainstream multicore CPUs and manycore GPUs.

This paper presents PIMsynth, a fully automated compiler framework that takes Verilog as input and generates optimized micro-operation code for both digital and analog bit-serial processing-in-memory architectures.

This paper proposes DReX, a dataset-agnostic, accurate, and scalable dense retrieval acceleration scheme that uses a novel algorithmic-hardware co-design with in-DRAM logic to perform early filtering of embedding vectors for retrieval-augmented generation.

This patent describes an integrated circuit memory device with a processing-in-memory architecture that includes sub-array level processors configured to perform column-oriented processing for tasks like sparse matrix operations.

This patent discloses a Dynamic Random Access Memory-Based Content-Addressable Memory (DRAM-CAM) architecture that can perform concurrent, bit-by-bit exact pattern matching on data organized into specific block formats.

This patent discloses a DRAM-based digital bit-serial vector computing architecture that embeds computation in the DRAM subarray, leveraging massive parallelism to outperform analog techniques and traditional CPU/GPU approaches.

This paper describes the integration of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals into a first-year engineering course in science, technology, and society to guide students in developing innovative technological designs.

This paper describes how ethical frameworks of sustainability, justice, and care were integrated into a first-year engineering course to challenge students to apply both technical and ethical training in generating innovative and socially responsible designs.

This paper analyzes how Mary Shelley's novel Frankenstein was used in a science, technology, and society course to foster ethical reflection among engineering undergraduates on the perils of irresponsible, presumptuous, and biased techno-science.

This paper analyzes papers on communication from the 2019 ASEE Annual Conference, revealing growing interest across divisions and identifying trends such as a focus on disciplinary communication and interdisciplinary collaboration, while also proposing strategies to develop a Communication across Divisions Network.

This study performs a thematic analysis of student reflections on reading Mary Shelley's Frankenstein in an engineering STS course, finding that students were able to articulate ethical themes from the novel and express a commitment to more socially responsible engineering practices.

This paper describes an STS course called "The LEGO Course" that pairs seminar discussions with studio design experiences to integrate social and ethical perspectives with authentic engineering design challenges, leveraging the LEGO Group's philosophy of "learning through play."

This study examines the mechanical properties of three commercially available closed-cell aluminum alloy foams, affirming that curved and wiggled cell walls play a prevalent role in determining stiffness and strength.

This study monitors the evolution of plastic deformation in a cellular aluminum alloy during compression using digital image correlation, identifying three stages: uniform localized straining at nodes, formation of discrete strain bands, and finally, complete plastic collapse of one band.

Using X-ray computed tomography and surface strain mapping, this study establishes that compressive deformation in cellular Al alloys localizes into narrow bands, with yielding initiated by the collective deformation of primarily elliptical cells.

This paper describes the design and testing of Tunabot, a high-frequency robotic platform based on yellowfin tuna and Atlantic mackerel, which achieved swimming speeds of 4.0 body lengths per second at a 15 hertz tail beat frequency, enabling exploration of the high-performance fish swimming space.

This study measured and simulated the bending performance of sandwich construction with thin cellular metal cores, generating a mechanism map to characterize failure phenomena and finding that initial discrepancies with simulations were rectified by using core shear properties measured on materials of the same thickness.

This study presents a single-actuator turning strategy for a bio-inspired robotic fish, the Tunabot, which uses asymmetric tail-beat timing to generate turning forces, achieving a turning radius of 1.42 body lengths with a 66% timing difference.

This research utilizes computational fluid dynamics to study how morphological and kinematic parameters, such as body thickness, affect the hydrodynamic performance and thrust generation of the Tunabot Flex, a high-performance tuna-inspired robotic platform.

This work uses a computational model with two-way fluid-structure interaction to investigate how altering the geometry and stiffness of the median fins on a bio-inspired swimming robot affects vortex interactions and hydrodynamic force production.

This paper studies 100 real-world partial failures in large distributed systems and proposes OmegaGen, a static analysis tool that automatically generates customized watchdogs to detect and localize such failures with high accuracy and low detection time.

This paper addresses the challenge of inefficient concurrent SPARQL query processing on large RDF graphs by proposing a solution that uses RDMA-assisted GPU graph exploration to achieve fast and concurrent query execution.

This paper presents RESIN, a holistic service designed to address the challenge of memory leaks in large production cloud systems by providing a low-overhead, high-accuracy solution for their detection and diagnosis.

This paper investigates the under-studied problem of silent semantic violations in large distributed systems, where bugs cause the system to deviate from its expected behavior without any apparent anomalies, leading to prolonged damage.

This paper advocates for the use of intrinsic, fine-grained software watchdogs to detect complex failure modes in modern systems software and presents an early exploration into automatically generating mimic-type watchdogs that imitate the main program for comprehensive runtime checking.

This paper presents Scalify, a lightweight framework that verifies the semantic equivalence of computational graphs in production-grade distributed machine learning frameworks to expose silent errors, using equality saturation and Datalog-style reasoning to scale to models as large as Llama-3.1-405B.

This paper proposes a method to automatically derive semantic checkers from existing tests to detect silent failures in production distributed systems, addressing the challenge that manually writing good checkers requires deep domain knowledge and substantial effort.

This paper presents Panacea, a holistic framework that automatically detects and mitigates host anomalies causing gray failures in production cloud infrastructure by correlating insights from VMs, applications, and the underlying host.

This work proposes Aerify, a framework that uses equality saturation to automatically verify the semantic equivalence of machine learning models, thereby exposing silent computational errors introduced by parallelism and optimization techniques in modern ML frameworks.

This dissertation enhances the runtime capabilities of cloud systems to detect, localize, and react to complex failures by introducing tools like OmegaGen for partial failures, Oathkeeper for silent semantic violations, and RESIN for memory leaks.

Using data from the 2004 National Study of Postsecondary Faculty, this study found a gendered division of labor among STEM faculty at research universities that is mitigated by the presence of a critical mass of women in the discipline.

This paper chronicles the growth of the ADVANCE leadership program at the University of Washington, which evolved from a campus-based workshop for department chairs to a national program and a web-based toolkit designed to promote gender diversity in STEM faculty.

This ethnography describes an ideology called "majorism" within a university's student culture, which reflects the preferential treatment of science and technology over the Liberal Arts and shapes students' understanding of the institution's values and purpose.

This paper describes the University of Washington ADVANCE program's Mentoring-for-Leadership lunch series, a group mentoring initiative designed to build community and encourage women faculty in STEM to consider leadership roles.

This article uses the concept of consent to analyze the social dynamics and power relations in data science knowledge production, hypothesizing a link between gender harassment in the workplace and the extraction of human experiences to produce Big Data.
This piece from the Digital Technology for Democracy Lab at the University of Virginia questions the societal costs and power dynamics behind the pursuit of convenience enabled by digital technology.

This book, "Cracking the Bro Code," presents an ethnographic study of sexism and racism in contemporary computing cultures, arguing that transforming the field's hostile environment can change who produces technology and the core values of its production.

This article introduces "Sheltering," a set of ethnographic care tactics inspired by "black boxing" and "strong objectivity," designed to protect underrepresented collaborators in technoscience research while protesting epistemic and social injustice.

This introduction to a special section explores the growing trend of collaborative research between STS and STEM scholars, using a feminist politics of care to transform tensions in these collaborations into resources for envisioning more equitable interdisciplinary work.

Drawing on data from the LATTICE program, this paper uses ethnography to examine how a diverse group of women worked across social and professional identities to support early-career women in academic engineering, offering actionable strategies for building coherent communities.

This paper describes SIMPLE, a novel sequential immunoperoxidase labeling and erasing method that enables the simultaneous visualization of at least five markers within a single paraffin-embedded tissue section by using an alcohol-soluble substrate and a rapid antibody dissociation technique.

In a retrospective case-control study of patients with ventricular paced rhythm, this investigation found that the modified Sgarbossa criteria had significantly higher sensitivity than the original criteria for the electrocardiographic diagnosis of acute coronary occlusion myocardial infarction.

This paper describes a method for serial multiple antigen colocalization in paraffin-embedded tissue, addressing the limitations of traditional methods like multi-color immunofluorescence to provide insights into cellular biochemistry and protein interactions.

This commentary on a study of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest outcomes in Japan highlights the importance of bystander intervention, noting that arrests in public areas had the best outcomes due to higher rates of witnessed events and public-access defibrillator use.

Using immunohistochemistry and Western blot analysis on human glioma samples, this study found that β-arrestin 1 is dephosphorylated in glioblastomas compared to nonneoplastic brain tissue, suggesting a potential role for its altered phosphorylation status in gliomagenesis.

This narrative review investigates the frequency of musculoskeletal, neurologic, airway, and vascular injuries in patients following non-judicial hanging events to help emergency clinicians anticipate and manage potential injuries.

This study compares the accuracy of feedforward neural networks and neural machine translation models for converting International Classification of Diseases codes to the Abbreviated Injury Scale, a crucial step for standardizing trauma injury research.

This paper provides a survey of clustering techniques used for analyzing gene expression data from DNA microarrays, a crucial first step in revealing natural structures and identifying interesting patterns within the massive datasets.

This paper proposes WaveCluster, a novel clustering approach for very large spatial databases that uses wavelet transforms to efficiently detect clusters of arbitrary shape at different resolutions, while being insensitive to noise and data order.
