This paper provides a comprehensive survey of causal inference methods under the potential outcome framework, categorizing and reviewing both traditional statistical methods and recent machine learning-based approaches for estimating causal effects from observational data.

This paper proposes WaveCluster, a novel and efficient clustering approach for very large spatial databases that utilizes the multiresolution property of wavelet transforms to effectively identify arbitrarily shaped clusters at different levels of detail.

This paper proposes SITE, a deep representation learning method for estimating individual treatment effects that simultaneously preserves local similarity and balances data distributions by focusing on hard samples in each mini-batch.

This paper presents Chart-RVR, a framework that fine-tunes Large Vision-Language Models for chart reasoning by using reinforcement learning with automatically verifiable rewards, resulting in improved robustness, explainability, and state-of-the-art performance.

This paper presents COCO-Tree, a novel approach that improves the compositional reasoning of vision language models by augmenting their outputs with neurosymbolic concept trees learned from large language models, significantly boosting performance on several compositionality benchmarks.

This KDD 2025 panel will examine the opportunities and challenges in designing cutting-edge AI models for scientific discovery and highlight the transformative potential of cross-disciplinary partnerships in shaping the future of both AI and science.

This special day at KDD 2025 will host a series of talks by leading experts to discuss the transformative potential of AI in scientific discovery and the challenges that must be addressed to realize this potential.

This paper proposes Evidential Alignment, a novel framework that leverages uncertainty quantification to mitigate reliance on spurious correlations in deep neural networks, thereby improving out-of-distribution robustness without requiring external group annotations.

This paper describes the development of a new version of the UVA/PADOVA Type 1 Diabetes Simulator, which incorporates new insights into the nonlinearities of insulin action and glucagon kinetics in the hypoglycemic range.

This paper presents a proof of concept for in silico preclinical trials using a realistic computer simulation environment to test closed-loop control algorithms for an artificial pancreas in type 1 diabetes, demonstrating its value in accelerating development and guiding clinical studies.

In a 16-week randomized trial involving children aged 6 to 13 with type 1 diabetes, a closed-loop insulin delivery system resulted in a significantly greater percentage of time spent in the target glucose range compared to a sensor-augmented insulin pump.

This patent describes a method, system, and computer program product for the real-time detection of sensitivity decline in analyte sensors, which is crucial for maintaining the accuracy of continuous monitoring systems.

This paper presents clinical studies of a fully integrated, modular artificial pancreas system that demonstrated the ability to maintain near-normoglycemia and prevent extreme glucose excursions in both adolescents and adults with type 1 diabetes.

This case study reports on an individual with type 1 diabetes who used capillary ketone monitoring to manually adapt a closed-loop automated insulin delivery system, enabling the safe utilization of a ketogenic diet while minimizing ketosis and improving glycemic control.

This article presents a framework for a personalized decision support system for type 1 diabetes that integrates psychobehavioral factors, such as individual treatment preferences, with glycemic control to provide optimized therapeutic advice.

This work aims to identify the most appropriate meal absorption model for subjects who have undergone Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass surgery by fitting various models to glucose rate of appearance data to better understand and simulate post-bariatric hypoglycemia.

This pilot study assessed the safety and feasibility of a next-generation fully closed loop insulin delivery system that uses a miniature neural network, demonstrating improved time-in-range and reduced hypoglycemia compared to usual care in adults with type 1 diabetes.

This patent describes a unified and scalable system called the Diabetes Assistant (DiAs) platform, which provides monitoring and control of blood glucose levels for diabetic patients, ranging from long-term advisory functions to real-time automated closed-loop control.

This article presents a comprehensive review of the mechanical properties of skin, covering various experimental testing methods and discussing its nonlinear, viscoelastic, and anisotropic behavior, as well as commonly used constitutive models.

This paper details the development of a finite element head and brain model to study blast-related traumatic brain injury, examining both dilatational and deviatoric responses and finding that CSF cavitation significantly increases negative pressures and shear strains.

This review focuses on five fundamental questions regarding brain injuries from blast, including the physical correlates, injury mechanisms in humans, and the challenges of clinically differentiating blast TBI from PTSD.

This study details the development and validation of a highly detailed C4-C5 cervical spine finite element model, which incorporates advanced nonlinear material properties and demonstrates good biofidelity across various loading modes.

This study uses a detailed, validated human cervical spine finite element model to evaluate soft tissue response in frontal impacts, finding that disc strains were highest in the C4-C6 region and increased with crash severity.

This study addresses the challenge of validating computational brain models by creating robust biomechanical response corridors for brain displacement under rotational loading, using a dataset from six specimens and employing numerical techniques to account for experimental variations.

Using a cadaveric model and a 3D biomechanical tracking system, this study quantified the mechanical impact of breast implant placement, finding that prepectoral placement resulted in significantly less deformation of the pectoralis major muscle during shoulder movements compared to submuscular placement.

This study developed and evaluated injury risk functions for traumatic brain injuries of varying severity (AIS 1-4+) based on FEA-derived metrics and head rotational kinematics from real-world frontal automotive collisions.

Using national crash data, this study examined how different types of cervical spine injuries in rollover occupants vary with factors like sex, seat belt use, and ejection status, comparing these patterns to non-rollover crashes.

This study evaluated objective anatomical metrics from CTA images of thrombectomy cases to determine which features, such as arch type or carotid tortuosity, best correlate with a surgeon's perception of navigational difficulty.

This paper describes the design and validation of a semiautomatic neurite tracing technique for fluorescence microscopy images, which was found to be more reproducible and significantly less labor-intensive than fully manual delineation.

This paper introduces MoDL, a model-based deep learning framework for solving inverse problems that explicitly incorporates the forward model, allowing for a smaller network with fewer parameters and reduced demand for training data compared to direct inversion approaches.

This paper introduces kt SLR, a novel algorithm for reconstructing dynamic MRI data from undersampled k-t space by posing the problem as a spectrally regularized matrix recovery problem, which simultaneously determines the temporal basis functions and their spatial weights.

This paper proposes a general, truly 2D approach for designing steerable filters for feature detection by optimizing a Canny-like criterion, yielding operators with closed-form expressions and better orientation selectivity than classical methods.

This paper proposes a novel blind compressive sensing framework to recover dynamic magnetic resonance images from undersampled measurements by modeling the signal as a sparse linear combination of basis functions from a large dictionary, which is estimated simultaneously with the sparse coefficients.

This paper develops a self-supervised and memory-efficient deep factor model for reconstructing 4D non-Cartesian MRI data, which represents a series of 3D multicontrast images using a neural network conditioned by inversion time and learned directly from k-space data.

Using dual-energy CT and a deep learning algorithm, this study developed and automated the calculation of a pulmonary-arterial-to-lung ratio (ArtLR) and found it to be significantly correlated with airway-to-lung ratio and other markers of COPD.

This paper introduces DMoCo, an unsupervised motion-compensated image reconstruction algorithm for free-breathing 3D cardiac MRI that uses a low-rank model to compactly represent the family of diffeomorphisms that describe cardiac motion.

To accelerate the reconstruction of high-resolution multi-shot diffusion weighted images, this paper proposes a method that decomposes the huge 2D block Hankel matrix into small 1D low-rank Hankel matrices from each k-space readout line, addressing the issue of variant low-rankness across k-space.

This paper proposes SS-MuSE, a method that accelerates quantitative MRI by generalizing a plug-and-play multi-scale energy-based model to a regularized subspace recovery setting, which jointly regularizes the 3D multi-contrast spatial factors for computationally efficient reconstruction.

This paper describes EpiSimdemics, a scalable parallel algorithm designed to simulate the spread of infectious diseases in large, realistic social contact networks of up to 100 million individuals by exploiting the semantics of disease evolution and propagation.

By exploiting the superior mechanical properties of VO2 micro/nanocrystals, this study maps the stress-temperature phase diagram over a vastly extended range, revealing new structural and electronic aspects at high-strain states and demonstrating the material's potential for active strain engineering.

This paper describes "first principles" based methods for generating synthetic, national-scale social contact networks by combining real-world data with behavioral theories to model every individual in the US population and their daily activities.

This paper provides a commentary on the influential Imperial College COVID-19 modeling report, discussing a coarse taxonomy of epidemic models and exploring the context and significance of various models in analyzing the pandemic.

This paper models the problem of determining the maximum MAC-layer capacity in ad hoc wireless networks using RTS/CTS protocols as the maximum Distance-2 Matching problem on the underlying graph and presents efficient approximation algorithms.

This paper gives a categorical semantics to e-graphs using enriched monoidal categories and presents a sound and complete combinatorial representation based on a generalization of hypergraphs, enabling double-pushout rewriting for these structures.

This e-book offers a variety of engaging materials, including tasks, puzzles, and games, to teach third and fourth-grade students in Germany about the country's 16 federal states, geography, and history in a playful and action-oriented way.

This article develops an information-theoretic framework for multiple sequence alignments based on sub-sampling, defining a potential that quantifies the expected drop in variation of information between pairs of sites when rows are removed.

This paper presents MacKenzie, a novel HPC-driven multi-cluster workflow system that was used to configure and execute fine-grained, US national-scale epidemic simulations in real-time to support policymakers during the COVID-19 pandemic.

This paper presents the Relational Machine Calculus, a simple, foundational model of first-order relational programming derived from the Functional Machine Calculus, which exhibits a latent duality that gives rise to a sound and complete calculus for string diagrams of Frobenius monoids.

This study investigated whether having introductory CS students generate their own subgoal labels for a programming task was more effective than being given them, finding mixed results that depended on other features of the instructional materials.

This paper critically analyzes how Khan Academy has incorporated gaming elements into its computer science learning platform by mapping the literature on motivational processes to popular games to evaluate the success of their gamification efforts.

This paper reports on a study that adapts a previously developed instrument to measure the intrinsic, extraneous, and germane components of cognitive load in an introductory computer science context, a necessary step for designing instruction that minimizes cognitive overload.

This study found that introductory programming students who were given subgoal labels performed statistically better on a Parsons problem assessment for learning while loops compared to groups that did not receive or had to generate their own labels.

This study implemented subgoal-oriented instruction throughout a semester-long introductory programming course and found that it significantly reduced withdrawal and failure rates and improved student performance compared to typical instruction.
This is a call for attendance for the ACM International Computing Education Research (ICER) Conference to be held in Charlottesville, Virginia, USA, from August 3rd to 6th, 2025.

This is a call for participation inviting attendees to the 21st ACM Conference on International Computing Education Research (ICER), to be held from August 3-6, 2025, at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

This work explores whether ChatGPT can be used to generate high-quality subgoal labels for introductory programming curricula, finding through qualitative analysis that Large Language Models can effectively assist instructors in this time-intensive task.

This paper explains the curriculum development process of a comprehensive, five-course, graduate-level program designed to train in-service teachers with little prior experience to teach computer science in grades 5-12.

This panel session will present and discuss the final report of an NSF-sponsored workshop that created a vision for the next 15 years of computing education, engaging attendees in a discussion about the field's future direction.

This study assesses state-of-the-art machine learning methods from the International Brain Tumor Segmentation (BraTS) challenge for glioma segmentation, progression assessment, and overall survival prediction using multi-parametric MRI scans.

This paper compares various convolving functions for the gridding technique in Fourier inversion, showing that a new function can improve upon the prolate spheroidal wave function in some circumstances for applications like computerized tomography.

This paper describes a flow-independent method for imaging coronary arteries within a single breath-hold on a standard MRI scanner using interleaved spiral k-space scanning, cardiac gating, and fat suppression.

This paper describes the design and implementation of a single excitation pulse that is simultaneously selective in both space and resonant frequency, enabling rapid water and fat imaging free of chemical shift artifacts.

This paper describes a magnetization-prepared, T2-weighted sequence that, when combined with lipid suppression and a multi-slice spiral acquisition, improves the visualization of coronary arteries by suppressing muscle and venous structures within a single breath-hold.
This study evaluates racial and ethnic disparities in the patterns of disease progression assessment among patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma in a routine clinical practice setting.

This study investigated the potential for interoperability between the MIDRC imaging resource and the N3C clinical record resource by using a COVID-19 severity prediction use case, successfully demonstrating patient-level matching and data integration.

This patent describes a computer-implemented method for reconstructing undersampled MRI data by using an image model, such as ADMM with non-convex low rank regularization, and an iterative optimization process to converge to an accurate output image.

This paper develops and validates a 3D MRI-thermometry technique for transcranial MR-guided focused ultrasound using a stack of retraced in-out spirals and a minimized energy deblurring strategy to accurately monitor temperatures during insonation.

This paper develops a single-slab 3D spiral turbo spin-echo imaging sequence for a 0.55T scanner that achieves 1-mm3 isotropic whole-brain T2-weighted imaging with high scan efficiency through interleaved spiral-in-out trajectories, variable-flip-angle refocusing, and concomitant-field compensation.

This chapter reviews the use of high strength and damping capacity shape memory alloys in passive vibration control devices for civil structures, highlighting their potential for energy dissipation and re-centering to protect against dynamic hazards like earthquakes.

This paper introduces the Extended Preisach Neural Network, a universal adaptive model with two hidden layers that can simulate both rate-independent and rate-dependent hysteresis with congruent or non-congruent, symmetric or asymmetric loops.

This paper describes a software called "Neuro-modeller" that uses artificial neural networks to model the nonlinear hysteretic response of concrete gravity dams under earthquake loading, including reservoir and foundation interactions.

This paper introduces the Extended Preisach Neural Network, an adaptive universal model for hysteresis that uses two hidden layers and a hybridized training algorithm to simulate both rate-independent and rate-dependent hysteresis with congruent or non-congruent, symmetric or asymmetric loops.

This study investigates the performance of a super-elastic memory alloy re-centering damper (SMARD) using high-performance NiTiHfPd SMA bars to improve the seismic response of steel frame structures subjected to multi-level earthquake hazards.

This paper discusses the evolution of a mastery grading system in a Calculus I course and investigates its impact on student grade distribution and subsequent performance in Calculus II compared to traditionally graded courses.

This study aims to identify patterns in engineering students' choice of credit/no-credit grading options for applied mathematics courses by correlating survey data on math confidence with registrar data on grades, GPA, and demographics.

This study investigates the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on Applied Mathematics courses for engineering students at the University of Virginia, aiming to identify which students were most affected and to understand their comfort level with online teaching.

This paper proposes five novel topological algorithms based on graph-theoretical methods to optimize the conditioning of structural flexibility matrices, demonstrating that these methods can remarkably reduce round-off errors in numerical simulations.

This study proposes and analyzes a super-elastic memory alloy re-centering damper (SMARD) that uses high-performance NiTiHfPd SMA bars, showing through nonlinear time history analyses that it can enormously mitigate the dynamic response of steel frame structures under various seismic hazards.
